It is a popular food fish targeted throughout its range in commercial and recreational fisheries for its flesh and its swimbladder (China). This species is considered to be recruitment overfished in South Africa and Australia with the spawning component of the stock having been reduced to 1.3% and 7.0-13% of unfished levels, respectively. In Australia, data for New South Wales show declines of commercial catch but no change in catch per unit effort (CPUE); however, recreational fishing has increased dramatically in recent years and is believed to be causing considerable declines in the population. The spawning component of the stock was reduced by approximately 90% from pristine levels in the NSW fishery and there have been 70% declines in the population in Viet Nam. This species was previously captured in China in the 1950s and 1960s, but is rarely caught now. Catch and CPUE in Japan appear stable and increasing, respectively, since the early 2000s, albeit due to restocking. There are no catch data available from the Indian subpopulation and it has not been recorded in landings there. Estuarine degradation (reported for South Africa and Australia) is an additional threat to the juvenile stage of this species, as it is an obligate estuarine dependent species. In South Africa, fishing pressure in estuaries, including illegal use of gillnets, has increased considerably. Evidence of the depressed state of the population in South Africa is genetically apparent from the low effective population size and hybridization with a congener.

Given the severe declines recorded in the populations off South Africa, Australia, and Viet Nam and that these populations make up a large portion of this species' range, it is inferred that there has been at least a 50–80% decline in the overall population. over three generation lengths (69 years). This species is therefore listed as Endangered under criteria A2bd. A review of the stock assessment status of this species is required for South Africa, to assess the fishing regulations that have been put in place. Research to determine the status and impacts of fishing in other parts of the range in Australia (outside NSW) and in other parts of the species global distribution is recommended.
habitat:
This species occurs in nearshore, turbid coastal habitats and is found in estuaries, in the surf zone, and in the nearshore zone to depths of about 100 m. In the nearshore environment, the species rarely ventures onto the soft, flat substrates exploited by trawlers and prefers reefs, especially wrecks or highprofile rocky reefs that are associated with sand. Large individuals tend to occur near the mouths of estuaries, in surf zones, and near rocky reefs and ridges offshore (Silberschneider and Gray 2008). Juveniles are estuary dependent and euryhaline (Wallace and van der Elst 1975) and tend to prefer deeper waters (Silberschneider and Gray 2008) and turbid estuaries (Griffiths 1996) with young adults having a strong proclivity for estuary habitats (Mann 2013). Adults are found predominantly in the near-shore marine environment, from the surf-zone down to 50 m and possibly even 100 m, but also frequent the lower-middle reaches of turbid estuaries (mostly deeper areas) (Griffiths and Heemstra 1995, Griffiths 1996, Cowley et al. 2008, Childs et al. 2015). The species shows a strong affinity to estuarine habitats during early adulthood (up to the age/size at 50% maturity of 6 years/~ 100 cm), with reduced estuarine use thereafter (Childs et al. 2015). The maximum recorded length for this species is 181 cm total length (TL) and has also been reported to over 200 cm (Silberschneider et al. 2009, Anon. 2011). It has a recorded longevity of 42 years (Griffiths and Hecht 1995, Griffiths and Heemstra 1995, Heemstra and Heemstra 2004). This species is considered to be a benthic carnivore but can feed throughout the water column. It predominantly feeds on crustaceans, small teleost fishes, and squid. The proportion of crustaceans in the diet tends to decrease with increasing fish size, with fishes and squid becoming more predominant (Marais 1984, Kailola et al. 1993, Griffiths 1997b). Both males and females of this species possess sonic (drumming) muscles that play a role in reproduction. A study by Ueng et al. (2007) documented females in aquaculture tanks in Taiwan emitting sounds during the spawning season including at the time of actual spawning and that the sounds produced by the females differed from the males. 

Juveniles of this species are generally sedentary while sub-adults and adults can move long distances between estuaries (> 200 km), probably associated with spawning migrations (Silberschneider and Gray 2008). Adults and sub-adults of this species occur in ocean waters and estuary habitats and seem to be more abundant in areas where salinities are closer to that of seawater (Griffiths 1996, Griffiths and Attwood 2005, Childs et al. 2015). Individuals of this species <115 cm TL tend to exhibit a high degree of estuary fidelity (Griffiths and Attwood 2005). While life history patterns vary between regions, studies conducted in South Africa and Australia have shown that juveniles of this species grow rapidly and can attain 35 cm total length in a single year to 87-90 cm TL in five years (Silberschneider and Gray 2008). Juveniles recruit to estuaries around 30 cm TL (Griffiths and Heemstra 1995). 

Varying sizes at sexual maturity have been reported from different regions. In South Africa, 50% of male and females were mature at 92 and 107 cm TL, respectively, and all males and female were mature at >110 and 120 cm TL, respectively; the latter correspond to 5-7 years of age for males and 6-8 years of age (Griffiths 1996). Size at 50% maturity in New South Wales was smaller with about 51 cm TL for males and 68 cm TL for females, corresponding to ~2 years of age and ~3 years of age, respectively. All males and females were mature at >63 cm TL and >79 cm TL, respectively (Silberschneider and Gray 2005, 2008). In South and Western Australia, size and age at 50% maturity for females was 93 cm and 6 years of age and for males was 88 cm and 5-6 years of age (Farmer et al. 2005, Silberschneider and Gray 2008). 

In South Africa, adults undergo a seasonal spawning migration from the south coast to the east coast and spawn in aggregations on well-known inshore reefs and wrecks at night in late winter/spring (Griffiths 1996). In Western Australia A. japonicus form spawning aggregations during the summer in turbid waters around high tide, late afternoons and in early evenings (Parsons et al. 2009). 

The eggs of this species are about 938 ± 24 µm in diameter and are pelagic. In a laboratory environment, eggs hatched 28-30 hours after spawning with larvae length of 2.2-2.3 mm total length (Battaglene and Talbot 1994). Larvae of this species were collected in the highest concentrations below 30 m depth during daytime sampling in coastal New South Wales waters (Gray 1995). Night time sampling revealed highest concentrations of larvae between 20-60 m depth with water temperatures between 21-23°C (Smith 2003). Estimates of fecundity of A. japonicus are not available but hatchery-kept fish around 10 kg were found to produce approximately 1 million eggs and the spawning mode is group synchronous (Battaglene and Talbot 1994). Spawning most likely occurs in nearshore coastal waters although there is evidence to suggest that it may also occur in the lower reaches of estuaries. The time of spawning appears to vary among geographic regions and with latitude and is probably related to water temperature and oceanography (Silberschneider and Gray 2005, 2008). In South Africa (KZN) spawning occurs from August to November (KZN), or October to January (SEC) (Griffiths 1996) and in Australia, it occurs from November to January/February (Silberschneider and Gray 2008). 

Mirimin et al. (2014) demonstrated an estimated hybridization incidence of 0.7% (3 out of 422 sampled fish) between A. japonicus and A. inodorus in the wild on the south coast of South Africa. The absence of F2 hybrids and absence of introgression resulting from backcrossing suggest that F1 hybrids are incapable of reproducing successfully and/or that hybridisation between these species is a rare event. The authors could not determine whether hybridization was the result of natural events (e.g. a shift in distribution range) or anthropogenic pressure (such as size-selective pressure due to overﬁshing). Natural mortality of this species has been estimated at M = 0.1 for South Africa and Australia (Griffiths 1997a, Silberschneider and Gray 2005). Generation length for this species was estimated to be 23 years and calculated using the following equation:  Age at 1st maturity + (max age - age at first maturity) /2.
threats: Overexploitation and habitat loss are the major threats to A. japonicus. This species is an important resource in several fisheries throughout its range but they exhibit intrinsic life history characteristics that make them vulnerable to exploitation including predictable aggregation sites, juvenile estuarine dependence, and strong adult site fidelity. The adults in many areas are being targeted and overfished beyond the recruitment threshold. Juveniles are highly accessible and are targeted by inshore anglers as they are confined to their natal estuaries. Many of the estuaries in their home range in South Africa are degraded owing to poor catch management, and the largest estuary in southern Africa (Lake St. Lucia) has been closed for several years because of drought and poor management. In KwaZulu-Natal, this species aggregates to spawn at well-known reefs and wrecks, where they are targeted at night by boat-based commercial and recreational linefishers resulting in catches of numerous, large, gravid individuals. Similar aggregations also occur in Western Australia which also makes this species vulnerable to capture. In addition to being caught by recreational fishers, this species is also taken in prawn trawl catches, gill nets, and beach seine catches in Australia (Hall 1984, Kailola et al. 1993, Broadhurst and Kennelly 1994, Liggens et al. 1996), where threats include overfishing, habitat degradation, and viral disease (e.g. redspot). Fish kills in estuaries have resulted from acidified and deoxygenated water which have also been cited as possible reasons for the decline in catch numbers (Kearney 2009). Foraging behaviour of A. japonicus is significantly reduced with increased anthropogenic disturbance such as boating (Payne et al. 2015).
population:
In South Africa and eastern Australia, this species is considered to be recruitment overfished (Griffiths 1997a, Silberschneider and Gray 2008). Spawning biomass per recruit was estimated to be between 7.0-13.0% of pristine levels in southeastern Australia (Silberscheider et al. 2009) and was estimated at 1.0-4.5% of pristine values in South Africa which suggests that this population is severely depleted (Griffiths 1997a). A more recent analysis showed that the population accessed by the Eastern Cape shore fishery in South Africa has not improved, with spawning biomass levels estimated at 1.3% of unfished levels (Winker et al. 2015).  

There have been serious declines in the Australian and South African regions due to recreational fishing, and it is estimated that the recreational catches from the Australian states (NSW, Victoria, SA and WA) are at least three times greater than the commercial catches. Total reported commercial catches around 248,598 kg (2001/2002) and total estimated recreational catches of 925,057 kg in 2001 (Henry and Lyle 2003, Silberschneider and Gray 2008) (recreational data may include other sciaenid species). In New South Wales, available data suggest that the commercial catch shows a decline in the proportion of larger and older fish in recent catches compared to that of those from 1986-1990 and 1994-1999 (Kearney 2009). The age composition of commercial landings indicates that the stock is heavily fished, with 98% of the fish being under five years old (A. japonicus has been aged to 24 years in eastern Australia) (Scandol et al. 2008). The data are confusing because as the commercial catch has declined the recreational effort has increased considerably (for example in NSW the recreational catch is somewhere between two to 10 times that of the commercial take); accurate information on the recreational catch is very limited (Kearney 2009). In a survey conducted in coastal waters off New South Wales, Australia, larvae of this species were most abundance in subsurface waters below 30 m depth (Gray 1995). Night sampling revealed higher larval concentration of this species between 20 and 60 m depth (Smith 2003). The commercial fishery in New South Wales was characterized by declining catches and a reduction in the proportion of mature individuals in landings. From 2002–2005 commercial landings were dominated (83%) by fish within 15 cm of the current minimum legal total length of 45 cm and aged 2-3 years (more than 80%), even though individuals of this species can attain lengths of 200 cm and live longer than 30 years (Silberschneider et al. 2009).

In South Africa, A. japonicus is currently managed as a single stock from False Bay to KwaZulu-Natal Province (Griffiths 1997a). West of Cape Agulhas, the relative proportion of A. japonicus found in Argyrosomus spp. catches has declined markedly. Commercial line boat fishermen catch an average of 197 tonnes per annum (1988-1992) in South Africa. Just as in Australia, recreational fishermen often target this species and are believed to catch at least as much as, and possibly more than, the commercial fishermen (Griffiths and Heemstra 1995, 1997a). In the Transkei, CPUE showed a decreasing trend by number and mass during the period 1977-2000 as well as in the Eastern Cape during the period 1982-1998 (0.05 to 0.02 fish/angler/hour) showing a 60% decline (Pradervand and Govender 2003). CPUE shore angling data from KwaZulu-Natal also showed severe declines with an 80% decrease from the period 1994-1996 to 2008-2009 (0.01 fish.angler-1.day-1 to 0.002 fish.angler-1.day-1) (Mann et al. 1997, Dunlop 2011). Retained catch declined by 76% by number and 69% by weight from the period 1994-1996 to 2008-2009 (Mann et al. 1997, Dunlop 2011). Time-series of recreational data are lacking in South Africa; boat-based catches are mainly made at night and neither this facet nor shore angling are monitored. Considerable catches of large A. japonicus continue to be made by recreational and commercial boats at night on spawning aggregations on the east coast of South Africa, but there are no formal records. There is evidence of a genetic bottleneck for the South African population, resulting in low and declining effective population size of between a few hundred and a few thousand mature fish, particularly of individuals born after 2005 (Mirimin et al. 2016). In addition to ongoing excessive fishing pressure and degradation of estuary nursery habitat, these authors link these bottlenecks to unintended consequences of the implementation of management measures and changes in the distribution of fishing effort as well as to environmental perturbations such as drought and anomalous flood events in estuaries. These authors stress that effective population size is not necessarily a reflection of actual population size, but it is an accurate measure of breeding success in the years assessed, with as few as 50 pairs breeding in some years. Illegal gill netting in estuaries on the east coast of South Africa has increased markedly, and the proportion of A. japonicus in these catches from 2010 to 2018 declined by about half (S. Lamberth, Dept of Environment, Forestry and Fisheries, Cape Town, South Africa).

This species was widely distributed in the East China Sea and Yellow Sea until around 1955. By 1965, fish density and its distribution were severely reduced but in later years catch statistics ceased, leaving the stock condition unknown. Annual catches from Japanese trawlers in the East China and Yellow Seas were 456 t in 1955, ~200 t in 1956-57, ~100 t in 1958-59 decreasing to less than 20 t by 1964-1965 with catch statistics ceasing thereafter (Yamada et al. 2007). In the surveys conducted twice a year by Seikai National Fisheries Research Institution, this species has not been captured for 20 years (Yamada et al. 2007). This species occurs in coastal Japanese waters off the Pacific coasts along the Kuroshio Current and probably forms a single stock. Annual catches in the Miyazaki Prefecture were 100-150 t in 2001-2014, ~5 t from the East China Sea in 2004-2014, and ~20-30 t from the Pacific coast with catch trends appearing to increase gradually between the three prefectures. The stock in the Miyazaki Pref. has a tendency of increasing with fluctuations in terms of abundance index and is generally constant. From 1990 - 2006, 300,000-400,000 artificially reared juveniles were released annually but this has ceased in recent years because the stock level was considered to be high (Sasaki 2016). The stock has completely collapsed in the East China Sea (Yamada et al. 2007) but is considered to be stable in western Japan, Miyazaki, Ooita and Kagoshima prefectures. In the Miyazaki Pref. catches increased from 60-170 t in 2000-2014 and CPUE is increasing with fluctuations, likely because of restocking. CPUE of hook and line fisheries in Miyazaki Pref. has increased by about 3x between 1992 and 2013 (Miyazaki Prefecture Fisheries Institute 2016).

In China in the 1950s-1960s this species was commonly caught; however, since the 1970s the species has rarely been caught. It is unclear why it is no longer captured, but the original population was thought to be small (Chu 1963, J.-H. Cheng pers. comm. 2009). In Viet Nam, from 1990-2000 the CPUE has been reduced by 70% mainly by electro-fishing (N. Van Quan 2004). This species has not recently been reported from India and fisheries data are not available (R. Nair pers. comm. 2019).
range: Argyrosomus japonicus is a pantropical species occurring throughout the Indo-West Pacific from South Africa to Beira, Mozambique (Sasaki 2001, Oceanographic Research Institute, unpubl. data), the coast of Oman and the Gulf of Aden to Pakistan (Silberschneider and Gray 2008) and the western and eastern coasts of India (Sasaki 2001, Psomadakis et al. 2015) and Sri Lanka. This species is also known from northern Pacific, from Viet Nam (Kimura et al. 2018), Hong Kong north to South Korea, southern Japan (Sasaki 2001), Indonesia (as A. amoyensis; Sasaki 2001) and from the Burnett River, Queensland, Australia to the North West Cape in Western Australia (Kailola et al. 1993). This species occurs from the nearshore zone to depths of 150 m (Sasaki 2001, Psomadakis et al. 2015).
useTrade:
Total worldwide estimates of catch for this species are not possible to determine as landed catches from many countries are unknown or not reported (Silberscheider and Gray 2008). This species is considered the premier angling species of the inshore environment (estuaries and surf zone) along the South African east coast from Cape Agulhas to KwaZulu-Natal. It is one of the most important species in recreational, commercial, and subsistence fisheries in South Africa (Griffiths 1996). The flesh is generally sold fresh, but sometimes frozen. In Australia, it is an important commercial and recreational angling species known as the "mulloway". It is caught in estuaries, in the surf and offshore, using hook and line, gill nets, seine nets and trawl nets (Griffiths and Heemstra 1995). It is considered a commercial marine food-fish species in Taiwan. Fishermen in the Penghu Archipelago culture this species in saltwater net cages (Ueng et al. 2007). This species is caught in the Miyazaki Prefecture, the Ooita Pref. and the Kagoshima Pref by set net, long line, and fishing rod. It is cultivated in Miyazaki and Kagoshima Pref. in small-scale facilities.

Juveniles of this species are frequently taken as bycatch in estuarine and oceanic prawn trawl fisheries and are often discarded with the majority of fish measuring <20 cm total length (Liggins et al. 1996, Liggins and Kennelly, 1996, Kennelly et al. 1998). This species is also taken as bycatch in estuarine gillnet and beach seine fisheries (Gray 2002, Gray and Kennelly 2003). 

In Australia, there is an aquaculture industry for A. japonicus (Gooley et al. 2000). The potential for culture of this species is also being investigated in South Africa (Viljoen 2019). It is considered a commercial marine food-fish species in Taiwan - fishermen in the Penghu Archipelago culture this species in saltwater net cages (Ueng et al. 2007). There have been considerable efforts at re-stocking in Japan (Sasaki 2016).  This species is also caught for their swim bladders, which are eaten in China.
conservationActions:
In South Africa, several management policies have been set up with the minimum legal lengths (MLL) set at 60 cm TL, (depending on the region) along with a recreational bag limit of 1 per person/day, and license requirements. There is no limit for commercial fisheries but they may only land one individual > 110 cm TL per person/day. These MLLs are not based purely on biological data but attempt to take misidentification with other Argyrosomus species in to account. There is regional variation in regulations considering the similarity between the three harvested Argyrosomus spp that occur in South African waters (Childs and Fennessy 2013). Its range currently overlaps with a number of MPAs, which afford the species some protection, and it will benefit from additional protection from the expansion and additional of several other MPAs in 2019. 

In Australia, this species is managed by spatial and temporal fishing restrictions, gear regulations, MLLs and recreational bag limits. The MLLs vary among state jurisdictions, with most MMLs set at 40 cm total length. Its range also overlaps with several Marine Protected Areas in Australia. 

Various bycatch reduction devices to exclude juveniles from capture in prawn fisheries have been developed in Australia (Broadhurst and Kennelly 1994); however, the potential benefits of these changes in fishing gear on stocks have not been assessed. The impacts of recreational and commercial hook and release on survival remains largely unquantified, particularly from deeper waters where fish may suffer stress from barotrauma (Silberschneider and Gray 2008). This species has also been artificially reared to supplement wild stocks in Australia (Silberschneider and Gray 2008) and Japan (Sasaki 2016). 

The species is under study by various fishery jurisdictions but more detailed data from consistent research is lacking (Scandol et al. 2008, Kearney 2009, Silberschneider and Gray 2008). More knowledge of detailed stock structure is required, as is knowledge of fish population movements along coasts and estuaries. Future studies using genetic markers as indicators of stock structure should be very useful (Silberschneider and Gray 2008).

Research to update its population status, and to assess the impacts of fishing and estuarine degradation, is recommended. The extent to which the subpopulations are distinct and worthy of separate species designation also needs to be resolved urgently, as this has implications for the status of this species.

rationale: Argyrosomus thorpei has a relatively restricted range and is confined to eastern South Africa and southern Mozambique, where it is exposed to several fisheries sectors. The population has declined markedly due to observed overfishing trends, possibly compounded by reduced river flow. Spawning biomass per recruit was at about 20% of the unfished level in South Africa in the mid-1990s. Occurrence as juveniles in bycatch of prawn trawling at that time negatively affected the adult population. Modelling of standardized commercial catch per unit effort data from South Africa’s commercial line fishery data from 1994 projected to 2017 (23 years = three generations) indicates a 67% decline in the South African population. There is only a slight suggestion of recovery in 2015, the last available year of the time series of catch data. A similar trend in catch rate is apparent for the recreational boat-based sector which also targets this species. This is despite bag and size limit regulations in South Africa, and substantial declines in trawling and commercial line fishing effort since 2007 and 2003 respectively. Data from Mozambique are limited but the populations there also appears to have declined substantially due to over-fishing. Although not estuarine-dependent, there are also concerns about habitat impacts, as the species is dependent on riverine input, which is increasingly being compromised in South Africa and Mozambique. A newly-promulgated Marine Protected Area in South Africa will provide considerable protection from harvesting of juveniles and adults. This species is listed as Endangered under criterion A2bd due to observed levels of exploitation. Improvements in monitoring of catches are required; urgent consideration should be given to creation of a protected area in appropriate habitats in Mozambique.
habitat:
This shoaling species inhabits coastal waters (Heemstra and Heemstra 2004). Juveniles are found on shallow sand or mud substrata, particularly the Thukela Bank prawn trawling grounds (Fennessy 1994), and the adults occur predominantly on low relief, shallow (<50 m) reefs (Fennessy 1994, Fennessy and Mann 2013). In South Africa, it is mostly caught beyond the surf zone to depths of 80 m and is seldom found south of Port St. Johns in the Eastern Cape although larvae are reportedly common inshore as far south as Algoa Bay (Pattrick and Strydom 2008). The size at 50% sexual maturity for this species is about 33 cm total length (TL) and age at 50% sexual maturity is about ~2.5 years for females (poorly estimated). Spawning occurs from June to September near Thukela Banks in central KwaZulu-Natal (S. Fennessy, ORI, pers. obs., van der Elst et al. 1991) and probably occurs near Xai-Xai as well (S. Fennessy, ORI, pers. comm.). Maximum weight recorded is 7 kg, maximum length recorded is 110 cm, and the maximum recorded age is 13 years (Griffiths and Heemstra 1995, Mann 2013, Fennessy unpubl. data). Lamberth et al. (2009) demonstrated a relationship between flow of the Thukela River and catches of A. thorpei (30% of catch variability was explained by flow rates), implying a reliance of this species on riverine flow. Natural mortality for this species was estimated at 0.34 yr-1 (van der Elst et al. 1991), but this is probably over-estimated and its likely to be closer to 0.2 yr-1. 

Generation length for this species is 7.75 years using the following equation: age at first maturity + (maximum age - age at first maturity) / 2
threats:
Large numbers of juvenile A. thorpei were captured as bycatch in the inshore prawn trawl fishery off the east coast of South Africa particularly during the 1980s and 1990s. This species mainly occurred in trawl catches, during January and February each year (Fennessy 1994). An incrementally lengthened closed season for the trawl fishery was instituted from around 1996 and currently is of 6-months duration (September-October inclusive). Since 2003, trawling effort declined sharply owing to non-viability of the targeted prawns, and since 2007 has been negligible. In August 2019 a large MPA was promulgated in the main habitat of this species, which will preclude trawling, as well as eliminating line fishing on large areas of reef habitat for adults. Although KwaZulu-Natal commercial line-boat fishermen no longer target the reefs where large catches of this species traditionally used to be made, recreational boat fishermen in the north of the province continue to catch this species. Anecdotal reports from commercial line-fishermen are that the traditional areas for catching this species have not been worth fishing in since the early 1990s and indications are that the stock collapsed at this time. In 2003, a substantial (50%) reduction in the number of issued commercial fishing licenses occurred, so as to control overall reef line fishing effort. Notwithstanding this, and the demise of the shallow water trawl fishery, the population does not appear to have recovered, although there is some sign of increased catch rates from 2014. 

In South Africa, the majority of the population occurs on the river-influenced Thukela Banks ecosystem in northern KwaZulu-Natal. If planned additional dams on the Thukela River are built, there will be a consequent reduction in turbidity and habitat, assuming a 44% reduction in flow in the Thukela River, there will be an estimated reduction in catches of 28% for A. thorpei (Lamberth et al. 2009). Further ecological stresses could be imposed by proposed offshore mining on the Thukela Banks (Mann 2013), although the recently declared MPA in the area should preclude this type of activity.

In southern Mozambique, the situation is analogous, but with limited data available. Semi-industrial line fishing effort there has been excessive for several years and trawling for shallow-water prawns off the Limpopo River has probably resulted in substantial juvenile bycatch. Ongoing reduction in flow of the Limpopo River as a result of water abstraction for agriculture is likely to be causing similar declines in habitat availability. There are recent reports of additional industrial fishing gears (including fish trawls and demersal gill nets) being permitted for use, which pose additional threats.
population:
This species has declined due to overfishing and possibly reduced river flow into the sea. In 1994, when it was exposed to trawling (as bycatch of a prawn-directed fishery) and line fishing (targeted), the spawning biomass level per recruit was estimated to be around 20% of the pristine (unfished) level in South Africa (Fennessy 1994). The growth model parameters (and hence some of the biological reference points) that this stock assessment is based on were poorly estimated owing to the limited availability of large specimens and inadequate numbers obtained during the spawning season. Trawling effort was subsequently reduced incrementally to reduce bycatch, culminating in a 6-month seasonal closure which provided protection during the months when trawl catches of this species were highest (Fennessy 1994). Since 2007, trawling effort has been negligible owing to non-recruitment of prawns (Fennessy unpubl. data.).
 
CPUE for this species has decreased in both recreational and commercial linefish fisheries in South Africa from 1994-1996 to 2008-2009. Based on two separate surveys, for 1994-1996 CPUE was 2.64 (fish-outing -1) and 2.71 (kg fisher-day -1) for recreations and commercial fisheries respectively decreasing to CPUE of 1.47 (fish-outing -1) and 1.47 (kg fisher-day -1) in 2008-2009 (Dunlop and Mann 2013). In 1990, the total commercial catch from KwaZulu-Natal declined from 132.7 mt to 14.2 mt in 1998 (S. Fennessy, ORI, unpubl. data.; Fennessy and Mann 2013). Catch composition in the recreational boat sector decreased since the 1990s with A. thorpei comprising 8.8% numerically and 3.9% by weight of catches in 1994-1996 decreasing considerably to 0.6% and 0.29% numerically and by weight, respectively (Mann et al. 1997, Dunlop and Mann 2013). Contribution to commercial catch composition for this species also decreased from 37% by weight in 1990 to 5% by 1998 (S. Fennessy, ORI, unpubl. data.). From 1994-1996 to 2008-2009 commercial catches for this species continued to decline from 1.9% numerically and 2.5% by weight to 0.46% and 0.61% numerically and by weight, respectively (Mann et al. 1997, Dunlop and Mann 2013). Standardized CPUE data from the commercial hook and line fishery in KwaZulu-Natal indicate a substantial decline from the early 1990s until 2015 (see Supplementary Material). Over three generation lengths (22.5 years) this represents a 67% decline for the South African population. Commercial fishers indicate that they no longer fish on the reefs which are the main adult habitat in central KwaZulu-Natal, owing to sub economic catch rates. Examination of nominal catch data from recreational boats (which still fish on these reefs) reveal a similar decline over this period, with a slight increase at the end (see Supplementary Material), which supports anecdotal reports of signs of recovery of this species – perhaps due to a combination of reduced/negligible trawling effort on juveniles (as bycatch) since 2007 and reduced commercial linefishing effort (by means of permit reduction) from 2003. 

Information from Mozambique was lacking for the assessment, but populations there are also thought to have declined due to over-fishing, and may have even collapsed – inferred from excessive semi-industrial linefishing effort in the southern region and over-fished status of several other co-occurring reef fishes in this region (Fennessy et al. 2012); perhaps compounded by the highly reduced flow from the Limpopo River with negative implications for juvenile habitat. Recent increases in industrial effort using fish trawls and demersal gill nets are a concern for this species. Port sampling of semi-industrial lineboats in Maputo in the late 1990s indicated that at times A. thorpei (recorded as A. hololepidotus which does not occur there) contributed substantially to landings but made much reduced contributions in subsequent years (van der Elst et al. 2003, Fennessy et al. 2012). The non-random and discontinuous nature of the sampling precludes further interpretation, although Mutombene et al. (2015) report that, from limited onboard observer data, aggregated from 2007-2010, it contributed 10% to semi-industrial catches (units unspecified) and from 2011-2014 less than 4% (exact proportion not determinable from the report).
range: This species occurs on the southeast African coast from Port Elizabeth, South Africa to Xai Xai, Mozambique, but its main abundance is in central KwaZulu-Natal and the northern part of southern Mozambique (Gaza province) where suitable habitats are found. Reports from the west coast of Madagascar (Griffiths and Heemstra 1995) are likely in error (M. Griffiths pers. comm. 2018) as no substantiating records can be found. This species occurs from the surf zone to 100 m depth (Fennessy 1994).
useTrade:
In KwaZulu-Natal (South Africa), this species is captured by commercial lineboat fishermen, by the recreational line-boat sector, and to a limited extent by shore anglers. It is also caught by semi-industrial line-boat fishermen in southern Mozambique (Griffiths and Heemstra 1995) and possibly by demersal fish trawlers and demersal gill netters (both industrial). Although KwaZulu-Natal commercial line-boat fishermen seldom target the reefs where large catches of this species traditionally used to be made, recreational boat fishermen continue to catch this species. It is not clear whether stocks are recovering but if they do recover, it is likely that they will be targeted again. Lamberth et al. (2009) estimated an annual value of $300,000 for South African commercial and recreational catches combined over the period 1985–2001. 

Juveniles of this species were frequently taken as bycatch in the prawn trawl fishery between January and February on the Thukela Bank but a 6-month closed season reduced these catches significantly and there is currently little prawn trawling conducted in the area (Fennessy 1994, S. Fennessy ORI unpubl. data.).
conservationActions:
In 1996 a closed season for shallow-water prawn trawlers operating on the Thukela Banks in KwaZulu-Natal (South Africa) was implemented for January and February, specifically to reduce trawl catches during the months when juvenile A. thorpei are more abundant in the area. This was based on a study which demonstrated that trawl catches were impacting commercial linefishing catches of this species (Fennessy 1994). The closed season was subsequently extended to six months to reduce bycatch generally. Trawling on the Thukela Banks has virtually ceased since 2005 owing to non-viability of prawn catches (Fennessy unpubl. data). The newly-promulgated (August 2019) extensive Thukela MPA will exclude trawling and will also reduce line fishing effort. Other regional MPAs may provide some protection for this species, specifically the iSimangaliso MPA, although this is not the preferred habitat of A. thorpei. This species also receives some protection from the Ponta Ouro Partial Marine Reserve in southern Mozambique waters and within the Pondoland MPA in the Eastern Cape province of South Africa (B. Mann, ORI, unpubl. data.). Protection of this species is needed in the Xai-Xai area of southern Mozambique where suitable habitat exists (Fennessy and Mann 2013). 

For recreational linefishermen fishing from a boat in the province of KwaZulu-Natal, there is a minimum size limit of 40 cm and a daily bag limit of 5, but only one fish >110 cm may be kept. The sale of fish by recreational anglers is prohibited. For commercial linefishermen in South Africa, there is a size limit of 40 cm and an unlimited bag limit for the province of KwaZulu-Natal, but only one fish > 110 cm allowed per person per day. Commercial linefishing effort in South Africa has been reduced by about 50% because far fewer licenses were issued as of ca. 2003, although it is not clear whether this only removed latent effort. Up until 2016 in KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa, the regulations were fairly well policed, and regular monitoring of recreational fishers was undertaken, but deployment of personnel has been much reduced subsequently, and there are concerns that compliance has declined markedly.

rationale: Hippocampus capensis is an estuarine seahorse species that inhabits river mouths in South Africa. This species is assessed as Endangered under criterion B1ab(iii,iv,v)+2ab(iii,iv,v) because it has an estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of 300 km², an area of occupancy (AOO) of 27 km², and it is only found in three locations (and has previously been lost from at least one other location). Also, the species is experiencing continuing decline in quality of habitat and number of mature individuals. Additional long-term monitoring is needed to determine population size and trends for this species. Habitat protection and water management measures need to be implemented to secure the future of this species.
habitat:
Hippocampus capensis are found at depths between 0.5-20 m (Toeffie 2000 in Bell et al. 2003) in association with submerged aquatic plants. Within Knysna, H. capensis are associated with five dominant aquatic plants: Zostera capensis, Caulerpa filiformis, Codium extricatum, Halophila ovalis and Ruppia cirrhosa (Teske et al. 2007), though they are most likely to be found grasping Zostera capensis eelgrass holdfasts (Bell et al. 2003). This species is also associated with Pyura stolonifera (a large ascidian) and sponges, but significantly more adult and juvenile seahorses are found at sites characterized by high vegetation cover (75%) than at sites with lower cover (Teske et al. 2007). Vegetated sites make up approx 11% of Knysna estuary (Teske et al. 2007), thus large areas of habitat in the Knysna estuarine system may be unsuitable for H. capensis because of the absence of submerged vegetation (Toeffie 2000 in Lockyear et al. 2006). H. capensis can also tolerate a wide range of environmental conditions (Lockyear et al. 2006), such as salinities ranging from 1-59 g/kg (Whitfield 1995). The species is also known to use artificial habitats extensively (Claassens 2016).

Juvenile H. capensis are often found in low frequencies during surveys, likely because they spend time in the plankton, at least initially, and older juveniles may use different habitat from the adults sampled (Bell et al. 2003). Juvenile length is strongly dependent on temperature and photoperiod, with higher temperatures and longer photoperiods resulting in juveniles being smaller in captivity (Lockyear et al. 1997).

Hippocampus capensis adults feed predominantly on small crustaceans which are sucked from submerged leaf surfaces or from the water column (Whitfield 1995).

This species is ovoviviparous, and the males brood the young in a pouch prior to giving live birth (Foster and Vincent 2004). Breeding occurs in the austral summer, when water temperatures approach 20°C and sexual maturity is attained in about one year at 65 mm standard length (Whitfield 1995). In captivity, H. capensis are diurnally active and have an elaborate courtship and mating ritual involving brood pouch inflation, tail grasping and ‘face-to-face’ positioning (Grange and Cretchley 1995).
threats:
This species’ primary habitat, the Knysna estuary, is among the most heavily used water bodies in South Africa (Bell et al. 2003) and human settlements and associated industrial, domestic, and recreational activities are increasing around all estuaries where this species has been recorded (Mkare et al. 2017).

The area is under threat from urban expansion and land-use changes in the catchment; stormwater runoff has increased in volume, and peak flows carry suspended sediment into the estuary (strong currents sweep animals and plants out into the sea and silt depositions result in the smothering of habitat and the clogging of gills); rising population and developments to provide piped water threatens freshwater inflow; and waste water disposal brings in chemical and biological pollutants (Marker 2003). Development surrounding the estuary is known to deposit trace metals, hydrocarbons, pesticides and organic wastes into the estuary (Chmelik 1975 in Bell et al. 2003). Within the estuary, the cumulative impact of boats may significantly affect the seagrass habitats of this species (Lockyear et al. 2006). Pollution events or other disturbances which affect the submerged plant beds of these estuaries will have a direct and indirect impact on H. capensis populations (Skelton 1987 in Whitfield 1995), yet construction developments and pollution continue (Lockyear et al. 2006, Teske et al. 2007).

Hippocampus capensis also appears to be vulnerable to water temperature increases. In 1991, 3,000 dead seahorses were found along the shores of the Swartvlei estuary after heavy rainfall and flooding caused a breach in the estuarine mouth and partially drained the estuary, leaving many individuals trapped in small pockets of remaining water. Mortality was attributed to the sudden increase in water temperature following the reduction in water level (Russell 1994). When the water levels drop and individuals are restricted to smaller pools, they are also susceptible to high levels of predation (P. Joubert pers. comm. 2010). Furthermore, large-scale flooding may substantially alter the estuaries in which this species is found (C.A.P.E. Estuaries Management Programme 2010). The present rate at which construction developments and other human activities are increasing along the estuary is alarming; the resulting habitat degradation may make recovery of populations after a naturally occurring disaster, such as a freshwater flood, increasingly difficult (Teske et al. 2003).

Furthermore, recently observed specimens of H. capensis also appear to be infected with lesions; the disease appears most often in individuals using artificial habitats (P. Joubert pers. comm. 2010).
population:
Recent surveys and molecular studies on the species indicate ongoing declines in the number of mature individuals in each of the three inhabited estuaries, but these have not been quantified (Mkare et al. 2017). Declines are thought to be in addition to those described below. Further research is needed to determine the level of decline and how the population fluctuates between years. 

The total population estimate for Hippocampus capensis in the Knysna estuary (mean, with range representing 95% confidence intervals) was 89,000 seahorses (range 30,000–148,000) in 2000 (Bell et al. 2003) and 62,000 (range 41,000–82,000) in 2001. In 2002, the Swartvlei and Keurbooms supported 995,000 (range 390,000–1.7 million) and 836,000 (range 242,000–1.7 million) seahorses, respectively. In 2003, the Swartvlei estuary supported only 176,000 (range 83,000–280,000) seahorses, and no seahorses could be found in the Keurbooms estuary (Lockyear et al. 2006).

As of 2003, assuming the total population of H. capensis in the Knysna estuary remained relatively constant at 62,000 individuals between 2001 and 2003, the estimated total population in all estuaries was 238,000 seahorses (range 124,000-360,000), down from 1.9 million seahorses (range 675,000-3.5 million) between 2001 and mid-2002 (Lockyear et al. 2006). Juveniles typically constitute 5-20% (average 13%) of individuals sampled (Lockyear et al. 2006), resulting in an estimated mean population size of approximately 207,000 mature individuals as of 2003.

In 2005, the Knysna and Swartvlei population sizes appeared to be healthy (M. Cherry pers. comm. 2010), and in 2010, populations were reported anecdotally to be seen in abundance in many of the marinas in the Knysna estuary and as being present in the Swartvlei estuary (T. Meintjes pers. comm. 2010, P. Joubert pers. comm. 2010). Similar to the 2003 surveys, preliminary surveys of the Keurbooms estuary in 2011 found no seahorses, despite the availability of suitable habitat (Appleby 2011). However, anecdotal evidence indicates individuals may occasionally be seen in this estuary (T. Meintjes pers. comm. 2010; Appleby 2011).

Recently constructed artificial habitats (e.g., marinas/boat harbours) appear to act as protective habitat for H. capensis (P. Joubert pers. comm. 2010) and, as relatively large numbers of individuals are seen in these habitats (B. Allanson pers. comm. 2010), they may have a beneficial effect on population size.

It is unknown whether extreme fluctuations of population size occur for this taxon. In 2002, seahorse densities were high in the Swartvlei and Keurbooms estuaries but, in 2003, seahorses were absent from the Keurbooms estuary and the population size in the Swartvlei estuary had decreased by more than 80% (Lockyear et al. 2006). The population size in the Knysna estuary declined approximately 30% between 2000 and 2001 (Bell et al. 2003, Lockyear et al. 2006). Since 2003, individuals have been seen in abundance in the Knysna and Swartvlei estuaries, although population size has not been quantified recently. Populations may not yet have recovered in the Keurbooms estuary, according to preliminary 2011 surveys (Appleby 2011). These results suggest that populations may occasionally undergo extreme fluctuations in the smaller estuaries, but experience fluctuations to a lesser degree in the larger Knysna estuary. It is expected that fluctuations are not due to changes in life stages or dispersal, but rather that individuals are susceptible to being washed out of the smaller estuaries as a result of floods and increased stormwater run-off from developments (Marker 2003, Lockyear et al. 2006). With H. capensis’ poor swimming ability and reliance on plant holdfasts, strong currents could sweep animals and plants out into the sea and silt depositions could result in the smothering of habitat and the clogging of gills. Individuals remaining in small pockets of water in the drained estuaries after floods may be subject to mortality from increased water temperatures (Russell 1994) and predation (P. Joubert pers. comm). The larger Knysna estuary thus may act as an infrequent but continuous exporter of colonists to the smaller estuaries (Teske et al. 2003). The rates of recolonization are after large population declines are unknown. However, anecdotal evidence indicates that the populations in the Knysna, Swartvlei, and Keurbooms estuaries have increased in numbers since the 85% decline in population observed in 2003 (T. Meintjes pers. comm. 2010, P. Joubert pers. comm. 2010).

Overall, the wild population of H. capensis is inferred to have declined by at least 50% over the past 10 years. Pressures that led to earlier declines have not ceased and are likely increasing, and although unquantified recent declines have been documented.
range:
Hippocampus capensis currently is found in the Knysna, Swartvlei, and Keurbooms estuaries in South Africa. Historical and anecdotal records indicate that this species could previously be found in Klein Brak, Groot Brak, Goukamma, Groot, Kromme, Kabeljous and Gamtoos estuaries (Bell et al. 2003, Lockyear et al. 2006), but surveys carried out between 2001 and 2003 could only locate individuals in the Knysna, Swartvlei, and Keurbooms estuaries (Lockyear et al. 2006).

The combined water surface of these estuaries is approximately 27 km².
useTrade: As this species is protected, it is not commercially traded or used for subsistence. Small numbers of specimens, however, were previously provided to researchers (McPherson and Vincent 2011). Historically, individuals were taken for the aquarium trade (Skelton 1987 in Whitfield 1995). The species may hold value on international markets similar to other seahorses (Vincent et al. 2011), but this has not been recorded.
conservationActions:
Hippocampus capensis is protected by law in the Knysna estuary (Sea Fisheries Act of 1973) and both the Swartvlei and Knysna estuaries fall under the protection of the National Parks Board (Whitfield 1995).

A conservation breeding program was started in 1998 to help mitigate the natural and anthropogenic threats to this species (Galbusera et al. 2007). Offspring of this founding stock was transferred from the Zoological Society of London to the Royal Zoological Society of Antwerp (RZSA), currently the only zoo in Europe where this species is being bred in captivity (Galbusera et al. 2007).

This species is listed on Appendix II of CITES.

rationale: Evynnis cardinalis occurs in the Indo-West Pacific from Japan to Viet Nam and Indonesia to depths of 100 m. This species is a very popular marine resource throughout most of its range and there is evidence of significant stock reductions. In Viet Nam, a stock decline of 58% was recorded over a period of five years, while in Taiwan reductions of 60% from 1993-2008 were reported, and annual catch reductions recorded also after the 1980s in China. This species also exhibits life history characteristics that predispose it to impacts from heavy exploitation, including longevity and late maturity. We assume that the population was higher before the period over which the declines were recorded. Therefore, the population declines over the past 39 years (three generations) is at least 50% based on the rapid declines recorded over shorter periods which are exacerbated by the intrinsic life history characteristics of E. cardinalis. It is therefore listed as Endangered under criterion A2bd. We recommend careful monitoring of this species and the consideration of additional management regulations.
habitat:
Evynnis cardinalis is primarily distributed from 30 m to 60 m depth (Chen and Qiu 2005) but can occur to 100 m. This species is found over a wide range of bottom types, but is more common close to reefs or on rough bottoms. Small individuals are very common at some localities in shallow, sheltered bays; larger fish often occur in deeper water (Eggleston 1974). The maximum age for this species is ~30 years (Hou et al. 2008) and it has a maximum length of 40 cm TL (Eggleston 1974). Evynnis cardinalis grows rapidly in the first two years of life and attains maturity at around seven years of age (Ye 2004, Hou et al. 2008a), at a length of about 11.2 cm (Chen 1999).

Evynnis cardinalis undertakes a seasonal migration in the Beibu Gulf, China, towards the northeastern part of the gulf in late autumn and winter. Spawning takes place in the spring and the recruits disperse widely in the gulf. Juveniles inhabit coastal waters. 

Generation length for E. cardinalis is estimated to be approximately 13 years, using the following equation for a gonochoristic fish species: Generation length = Σxlxmx/Σlxmx
threats: Evynnis cardinalis is threatened by overexploitation. This species has experienced significant population declines in the Beibu Gulf and the south Fujian and Taiwan bank fishing ground (Ye 2004, Chen and Qiu 2005a, Feng et al. 2009, Wang et al. 2011). Values of spawning biomass per recruit (SBR) <25% of unexploited levels indicate stock collapse, as defined in Griffiths (2000) for South African line-fish species. Spawning biomass per recruit for E. cardinalis in the Beibu Gulf has been estimated to be below 20% of unexploited levels, indicative of stock collapse. In Viet Nam, stocks have declined by 58% during 2001–2005 (Nguyễn 2006). This species constitutes 17.9% of the otter trawl and 8.6 (<20 m) and 11.6% (21–30 m) of the pair trawl bycatch landings in northern Viet Nam waters (Son et al. 2005). In China, the annual catch decreased after the 1980s, indicating a strong decline in the numbers and biomass of older fishes (i.e., the spawning stock) (Ye 2004, Chen and Qiu 2005).
population:
Evynnis cardinalis is more common in the southern part of its range and in northern Viet Nam and the South China Sea (Y. Iwatsuki pers. comm. 2009). From 1993 the catch was recorded at 400 tonnes and in 2008 had declined to 150 tonnes in Taiwan (Liao pers. comm. 2009). There have been declines in the numbers and biomass of the spawning stock in China as well (Xia et al. 2007).

In the Gulf of Tonkin, Viet Nam, this species is most abundant at depths from 30–50 m, and the stock density and biomass increases from shore to 50 m depth. A high variation in catch rates of this stock in all strata is also observed: mean catch rates estimated for the depth stratum of 50–100 m in 2001 and 2005 were respectively 15.5 kg/h and 1.7 kg/h. In general, the catch rate of this stock has decreased significantly from 28.8 kg/h (2001) to 11.1 kg/h (2005), with p < 0.05. Corresponding to this decrease in catch rate, biomass of the stock has also declined considerably; the estimates of the stock biomass in 2001; 2003; 2004 and 2005 are 33,952 tonnes (CV= 16%); 12,150 tonnes (CV= 29%); 21,389 tonnes (CV= 23%) and 14,414 tonnes (CV= 34%), respectively. Therefore, during 2001–2005, this stock has declined by 58% (Nguyễn 2006).

The spawning biomass per recruit (SBR) of E. cardinalis in the Beibu Gulf is estimated to be 16.76% of its unfished level, indicating that the fishery is overfished and has also experienced recruitment failure (Feng et al. 2009a). Additional analysis suggests that SBR in the Beibu Gulf is 12.51% of the unexploited level (Feng et al. 2009a). The status of this stock was also assessed using the egg production per recruit model (EPR) which was estimated to be 15.49% of the unexploited level under the current fishing mortality rate, which also indicated that the fishery is over-fished (Wang et al. 2011). The catch rates for E. cardinalis in the Beibu Gulf were found to be higher during winter and spring than in autumn and summer, with the highest catches from March to May. The catch rates of biomass were 10.27 kg/h and catch rates of  individual numbers were to 700.9 ind/h (Chen and Qiu 2005). Data from trawl surveys in the Beibu Gulf indicate that the stock has annual variation with seasonal changes in catch rates caused by immigration during the spawning period and catch rates higher in March and May. Catches rates fluctuated between 35.8 kg/hour in 2000 and 2.73 kg/hour in 1992 (Chen and Qiu 2005). This species is considered to be overexploited in the south Fujian and Taiwan bank fishing ground due to overfishing of immature individuals (Ye 2004). 

Catches from the three provinces of mainland China including Guangdong, Guangxi and Hainan, facing the South China Sea were 2,452,958 tonnes in 1995 and largely exceeded the estimated stock size of 1,200,000 tonnes (discounting catches of Fujian Province, Taiwan, Hong Kong, Macau and Viet Nam). Catches of high value species including Lutjanus erythropterus, Larimichthys crocea, E. cardinalis, and Saurida spp. have also declined (Chen 1999). This species is considered to have three geological stocks: Taiwan Strait stock, South China sea stock and the Beibu Gulf stock (Zeping 1983).
range: Evynnis cardinalis is distributed in the northwest Pacific from China, Japan and Korea to Viet Nam and Indonesia (Chen and Qui 2005, Xia et al. 2007). This species is primarily distributed from 30–60 m depth (Chen and Qui 2005) but occurs to 100 m depth.
useTrade: This species is one of the most valuable and popular marine fish resources in China (Xia et al. 2007). In Taiwan, mariculture of wild caught juveniles has been established (Yeh 2009).
conservationActions: In the Beibu Gulf, a closed season and closed fishing areas are recommended to improve SBR under current fishing mortality, in addition to a minimum landing size of 10.4 cm. The proposed measures could restore SBR to 28.39% of the unfished level, increase yield per recruit (YPR) in mass up to 31.95% and prevent the fishery from collapsing. It is also recommended that fishing effort be reduced by 32.5% in order to attain a level of sustainable exploitation (Feng et al. 2009). The closed fishing season was found to be most effective when implemented from July to August or September and would improve SBR and YPR considerably (Feng et al. 2009). Similarly, a closed fishing season and larger length of capture would improve egg production per recruit (EPR). It is suggested that relevant fishing effort be reduced by 15.53% or to extend the age at capture to allow the EPR to reach at least 20% of the unexploited level (Wang et al. 2011). Although the distribution of E. cardinalis overlaps with MPAs throughout its range (World Database of Protected Areas, accessed March 2014), this species is heavily exploited in the Beibu Gulf where additional protected areas have been recommended.

rationale: Amblycirrhitus earnshawi is a shallow water reef species that only known from Ascension Island in the Eastern Atlantic. There are little data available on the population size and biology of this species. The calculated area of occupancy (AOO) of this species is 22 km² (50 m depth layer). This is assuming continuous suitable habitat within this depth layer. Due to habitat preferences and possible habitat specificity the suitable habitat for this species is smaller than the calculated AOO of 22 km². Military development, industrial development related to refuelling of large vessels, as well as developing fisheries and the recent development of tourism on the island, are likely to impact this species throughout its range, and have been implicated in the degradation of suitable habitat. Therefore, this species is assessed as Endangered B2ab(iii).
habitat: Amblycirrhitus earnshawi is a tropical species that inhabits shallow waters and can attain about 7 cm in length (Rocha in press). It occurs among rocks and coralline algae (Randall 1990).
threats: This species has an extremely limited area of occupancy (AOO) and inhabits shallow waters. Some of the species in this family are of commercial value in the aquarium trade although little data for A. earnshawi are available. The human population of Ascension Island is less than 1,000. Military development, industrial development related to re-fueling of large vessels, as well as developing fisheries and the recent development of tourism on the island, are likely to impact this species and have been implicated in the degradation of suitable habitat.
population: Population information for this species is limited.
range: Amblycirrhitus earnshawi is endemic to Ascension Island and has a depth range of three to 25 m (Rocha in press). The area of occupancy (AOO) for this species is 22 km2.
useTrade: Some species in the family Cirrhitidae are of commercial value in the aquarium trade (Rocha in press).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation efforts in place for this species. There is a need for additional information about the population size, trend and biology of this species.

rationale: Priolepis ascensionis is endemic to the central mid-Atlantic islands, and is found only at the Ascension Islands and St. Helena (Wirtz et al. 2014). Little information is available on the abundance, population status and ecology of this species. Individuals have been collected from tidepools at depths of 1.1 m, and other members of the genus are generally found in shallow waters (<25 m). The estimated area of occupancy (AOO; depth zero to 20 m) is approximately 110 km2. This estimate includes the entire depth range from zero to 20 m, whereas the actual available habitat for this species is likely much less due to habitat specificity. This species is known from less than five locations, and subpopulations are extremely susceptible to current and potential threats. Military development, industrial development related to refueling of large vessels and the recent development of tourism on the islands are likely to impact this species and have been implicated in the degradation of suitable habitat. Therefore, P. ascensionis is assessed as Endangered B2ab(iii).
habitat: Habitat information for this species is unknown but it is probably a reef species.
threats: Military development, industrial development related to refueling of large vessels and the recent development of tourism on the islands are likely to impact this species and have been implicated in the degradation of suitable habitat.
population: There are no population data available for P. ascensionis.
range: Priolepis ascensionis is known from Ascencion Island (Greenfield 1989, Miller and Murdy in press) and St. Helena (Wirtz et al. 2014). Priolepis ascensionis in the Western Atlantic is primarily coral-associated and a shallow-water species occurring at depths of roughly less than 20 m (Smith-Vaniz pers. comm. 2014). A lot with four individuals from tidepool at depths of 1.1 m was found in a search of FishNet2 datbase collections (FishNet2 database searched July 2014).
useTrade: Priolepis ascensionis is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: Scorpaena ascensionis is found off Ascension Island in the South Atlantic Ocean. It has be found between 16-27 m, often around the continental slope in areas that have rocky or soft bottoms. Little can be said about the population since there are few records. The calculated area of occupancy (AOO) of this species ranges from 4.45 km2 (depth layer of zero to 25 m) to 21.88 km2 (50 m). This is assuming continuous suitable habitat within this depth layer. Due to habitat preferences and possible habitat specificity the suitable habitat for this species could be smaller. Additionally, this species is known from few locations. Military development, industrial development related to refueling of large vessels, as well as developing fisheries and the recent development of tourism on the island are likely to impact this species and have been implicated in the degradation of suitable habitat. Therefore, this species it is assessed as Endangered B2ab(iii).
habitat: Species of Scorpaena are bottom-dwellers, often found around the continental slope in areas that have rocky or soft bottoms. They often eat invertebrates and small fish. The fin spines have venom glands in grooves (Smith-Vaniz in press).
threats: This species is likely threatened by continued degradation of habitat on Ascension Island, including military development, industrial development, and the recent development of tourism and fishing.
population: Little is known about the population since few individuals have been recorded.
range: Scorpaena ascensionis is found off Ascension Island in the South Atlantic Ocean (Poss in press). It has be found between 16 and 27 metres.
useTrade: There is no specific fishery for this species but it can be caught as by-catch in bottom trawls.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation efforts.

rationale: Scorpaena mellissii is found off St. Helena in waters between 10-110 m, often around the continental slope in areas that have rocky or soft bottoms. Little can be said about the population since there are few records. The calculated area of occupancy (AOO), based on a one to 100 m depth layer, is 490 km2. This is assuming continuous suitable habitat within this depth layer (one to 100 m). Additionally, this species is known from few locations. Military development, industrial development related to refueling of large vessels, as well as developing fisheries and the recent development of tourism on the island are likely to impact this species and have been implicated in the degradation of suitable habitat. Therefore, this species it is assessed as Endangered B2ab(iii).
habitat: Species of Scorpaena are bottom-dwellers, often found around the continental slope in areas that have rocky or soft bottoms. They often eat invertebrates and small fish. The fin spines have venom glands in grooves (Poss in press). The maximum size is 20 cm.
threats: St. Helena fisheries primarily target tuna and other large pelagics via longline fisheries and small boats operating at depths of up to 100 m. There is interest in the development of commercial trawling in the vicinity of St. Helena. The island is inhabited, and there has been some development of the tourism industry.
population: Little is known about the population since few individuals have been recorded.
range: Scorpaena mellissii is found off St Helena in waters between 10 and 110 m (Smith-Vaniz in press).
useTrade: There is interest in the development of commercial trawling in the vicinity of St. Helena.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation actions in place.

rationale: This recently described, valid species is restricted to shallow coral reef habitat off Grand Cayman Island (one location). Little is known on its population or life history. Its estimated EOO is 460 km<sup>2</sup> and its AOO is 92 km<sup>2</sup>, which meet the thresholds for Endangered under B1 and B2 and Vulnerable under D2. It is threatened by coral reef decline and possibly the invasive lionfish throughout its entire distribution. Therefore, it is listed as EN B1ab(iii)+B2ab(iii).
habitat: This species was collected by hand over coral reef.  Little is known on its ecology and life history, however, it likely exhibits cleaning behaviour. Its maximum size is 2.3 cm SL (Victor 2014).
threats: Between 1970-2011 (41 years), an overall 59% decline in coral cover was directly observed in the Caribbean, which was caused by anthropogenic stressors, Diadema antillarum decline, and coral disease (Jackson et al. 2014). It could be consumed by the invasive lionfish, however, some evidence shows that cleaner gobies are not preferred by this predator (Green and Cote 2014). Elacatinus prochilos, also a cleaner goby, is the only species within this genus that has been confirmed in the diet of the invasive lionfish (Villasenor-Derbez and Herrera-Perez 2014). To date, at least 13 species of Gobiidae have been recorded in the invasive lionfish diet.
population: Little is known on the population of this species as it is has only recently been described. Eleven specimens were used to describe this species (Victor 2014).
range: This recently described species occurs in the western Atlantic where it has only been recorded from Grand Cayman Island (Victor 2014). Its depth range is presumably shallow (within recreational scuba limits). It has an estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of 460 km<sup>2</sup> (based on a minimum convex polygon drawn around the extent of its range on a coral reef layer). It has an estimated area of occupancy (AOO) of 92 km<sup>2 </sup>(calculated by clipping the distribution polygon to the coral reef layer from WCMC 2013).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place. It is not known if the population occurs in protected areas.

rationale: This recently described, valid species inhabits shallow reef habitat off Grand Cayman Island. Little is known on its habitat, population, ecology or life history. Its estimated EOO is 361 km<sup>2</sup> and its estimated AOO is 58 km<sup>2</sup>, which meets the thresholds for Endangered under B1 and B2.<sup> </sup>It is potentially threatened by the invasive lionfish, which is known to occur off Grand Cayman. The invasive lionfish has been observed to cause an overall 65% decline in prey biomass over a period of two years. However, species-specific decline nor generation length are available at this time. Therefore, it is considered to be restricted to two locations with a continuing decline projected for mature individuals and is listed as EN B1ab(v)+B2ab(v).
habitat: This species was collected by hand over reef. Little is known on its ecology and life history. Its maximum size is 2.1 cm SL (Victor 2014).
threats: This species may be easily targeted by the invasive lionfish given its small, shallow body and demersal habits (Green and Cote 2014). To date, at least 13 species of Gobiidae have been recorded in the invasive lionfish diet. Due to the lionfish's ability to consume a variety of fishes smaller than 15 cm, both adults and juveniles of this species would likely be consumed. In the Bahamas, a 65% decline in lionfish prey biomass over a period of two years was observed (species-specific data are not available at this time) (Green et al. 2012).
population: Little is known on the population of this species as it is has only recently been described. Six specimens were used to describe this species (Victor 2014).
range: This recently described species occurs in the western Atlantic where it is endemic to Grand Cayman Island (Victor 2014). Its depth range is presumably shallow (within recreational scuba limits) and if similar to its sister species (Tigrigobius redimiculus and T. multifasciatus), it is inferred to be restricted to depths shallower than 10 m. It has an estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of 361 km2 (based on a minimum convex polygon drawn around the extent of its range on a zero to 10 m bathymetric layer). It has an estimated area of occupancy (AOO) of 58 km2 (calculated by clipping the distribution polygon to the zero to 10 m bathymetric layer extracted from ETOPO).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place. It is not known if the population occurs in protected areas.

rationale: This recently described, valid species inhabits sponges on shallow reef habitat in the Cayman Islands. Little is known on its population or life history. Its estimated EOO is 2,995 km<sup>2</sup> and its AOO is less than 200 km<sup>2</sup>, which meet the thresholds for for Endangered under B1 and B2. It is potentially threatened by the invasive lionfish, which occurs in both Grand and Little Cayman. The invasive lionfish has been observed to cause an overall 65% decline in prey biomass over a period of two years. However, species-specific decline nor generation length are available at this time. Therefore, it is considered to be restricted to two locations with a continuing decline projected for mature individuals and is listed as EN B1ab(v)+B2ab(v).
habitat: This species was collected by hand over reef on sponge habitat. Little is known on its ecology and life history. Its maximum size is 3.8 cm SL (Victor 2014).
threats: This species may be easily targeted by the invasive lionfish given its small, shallow body and demersal habits (Green and Cote 2014). Elacatinus prochilos, also a cleaner goby, is the only species within this genus that has been confirmed in the diet of the invasive lionfish (Villasenor-Derbez and Herrera-Perez 2014). To date, at least 13 species of Gobiidae have been recorded in the invasive lionfish diet. Due to the lionfish's ability to consume a variety of fishes smaller than 15 cm, both adults and juveniles of this species would likely be consumed. In the Bahamas, a 65% decline in lionfish prey biomass over a period of two years was observed (species-specific data are not available at this time) (Green et al. 2012).
population: Little is known on the population of this species as it is has only recently been described. Eight specimens were used to describe this species (Victor 2014).
range: This recently described, valid species occurs in the western Atlantic where it has only been recorded from the Cayman Islands (Victor 2014). Its depth range is presumably shallow (within recreational scuba limits). It has an estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of 2,995 km<sup>2</sup> (based on a minimum convex polygon drawn around the extent of its range on a zero to 50 m bathymetric layer). It has an estimated area of occupancy (AOO) of 206 km<sup>2 </sup>(calculated by clipping the distribution polygon to the zero to 50 m bathymetric layer extracted from ETOPO), but since it is restricted to patchily distributed sponge habitat across this area, its AOO is likely less than 200 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place.

rationale: The Ornate Eagle Ray (Aetomylaeus vespertilio) is a large (to 240 cm disc width), uncommon eagle ray that has not been sighted in any great numbers since its description more than 160 years ago. It has a widespread but patchy distribution in the Indo-West Pacific. The species is highly susceptible to a variety of fishing methods in regions where the level of exploitation of marine resources is intense and increasing (for example, India, Thailand, Taiwan, and Indonesia). It is occasionally caught by the rhynchobatid gillnet fishery that operates in Southeast Asia. In the Gulf of Thailand, eagle rays are now extremely rare, and this may be representative of other areas where the Ornate Eagle Ray occurs. In Australian waters the fishing pressure would not be very high but it is rarely observed there. It is suspected to have limiting life history parameters similar to other myliobatid rays, including low fecundity. The Ornate Eagle Ray is assessed as Endangered due to suspected population declines exceeding 50% over the last three generations (45 years) as a result of very high, ongoing (and increasing) levels of fishing pressure across the majority of its distribution.
habitat: The Ornate Eagle Ray is a little known species. It occurs on the inner continental shelf to depths of 110 m over soft sandy substrate (Compagno and Last 1999). It reaches a maximum size of 240 cm disc width (W. White, unpubl. data). Reproductive biology is unknown for this species but it is suspected to have low fecundity as with other myliobatids, which bear litters of up to four offspring (Compagno and Last 1999, Last and Stevens 2009). Age and growth estimates are not available, although generation length can be inferred as approximately 15 years based on parameters from the Bat Ray (Myliobatis californicus), which matures at five years and reaches a maximum age of 24 years (Martin and Cailliet 1988).
threats: This eagle ray is highly susceptible to a variety of inshore demersal fisheries, including trawls, gillnets and trammel nets which operate intensively throughout its range (for example, India, Thailand, Taiwan, and Indonesia). All individuals caught are retained in most areas. Local eagle ray species are marketed in considerable numbers in Thailand and Malaysia (Compagno and Last 1999). The Ornate Eagle Ray is occasionally landed in low numbers in the fish markets of Jakarta (Indonesia) by trawlers and is occasionally caught by the rhynchobatid gillnet fishery that operates in Southeast Asia (W. White, unpubl. data). Even though once common, eagle rays are now rare in the Gulf of Thailand (Compagno and Last 1999). Intensive demersal fisheries occur in India, within the species' known distribution (Hanfee 1999). There is very high level of exploitation across the habitat that this species occurs in throughout its range, with the exception of northern Australia.
population: The species appears to be naturally uncommon and is rarely observed. Nothing is known of its overall population size or structure. However, based on the intrinsic sensitivity of this eagle ray to overexploitation (see the Habitats and Ecology section below), and the presence of unregulated fisheries throughout its entire range (see the Threats section below), the species is suspected to have undergone a population decline exceeding 50% over the past three generations (45 years).
range: The Ornate Eagle Ray has a sporadic distribution in the Indo-West Pacific from Mozambique, the Red Sea, India, the Maldives, Southeast Asia and the Philippines, China and Taiwan, and across northern Australia (Bonfil and Abdallah 2004, Compagno et al. 2005, Last and Stevens 2009, Benjamin et al. 2012).
useTrade: This species is probably widely utilized for meat and cartilage when caught across its range (for example, Indonesia; White et al. 2006), with the exception of northern Australia.
conservationActions: There are currently no species-specific conservation measures in place. Given the rarity of this species, its occurrence in heavily fished inshore areas and its susceptibility to capture in a variety of fishing gear, it is likely to need legal protection in order to manage harvest and trade. However, this can be difficult to enforce in many countries where it occurs.

rationale: The Pelagic Thresher (Alopias pelagicus) is a large (to 365 cm total length), wide-ranging Indo-Pacific pelagic shark that occurs from the surface to depths of 300 m. It has a low fecundity (average two pups per litter) and a very low annual rate of population increase of 0.033. The species is caught as target and bycatch in pelagic and coastal commercial and small-scale longline, purse seine, and gillnet fisheries. The species is often retained for its meat and fins unless domestic or international regulations prohibit retention. However, high at-vessel mortality remains a threat even where retention is prohibited. The Pelagic Thresher is especially susceptible to fisheries exploitation because its epipelagic habitat occurs within the range of many largely unregulated and under-reported, small-scale and artisanal gillnet and longline fisheries, in which it is readily caught. The species is estimated to be declining in both the Pacific and Indian Oceans. Across its Indo-Pacific distribution, the Pelagic Thresher is estimated to have reduced by 50–79% over the last three generations (55.5 years), based on abundance data and levels of exploitation, and therefore the species is assessed as Endangered A2bd.
habitat: The Pelagic Thresher is epipelagic and mesopelagic from the surface to depths of 300 m (Weigmann 2016). It attains a maximum size of 365 cm total length (TL), males and females mature at 250–300 cm TL (Ebert et al. 2013). Reproduction is lecithotrophic viviparous with oophagy, and a litter size of only two, very large (158–190 cm TL) pups and the reproductive cycle is likely annual (Liu et al. 1999). The potential annual rate of population increase under sustainable fishing is thought to be very low and has been estimated at 2–4% (Smith et al. 1998), or 0.033 (i.e. 3.3%) (Dulvy et al. 2008), compared with the Common Thresher, which is 4–7% (Smith et al. 1998) or 0.254 (Dulvy et al. 2008).
