This has been aided by progressive reductions in Total Allowable Catches (TACs) for targeted deepwater species such as Orange Roughy (Hoplostethus atlanticus) and Gemfish that encouraged commercial fishing to operate at depths shallower than those inhabited by Greeneye Spurdog (Walker and Gason 2007);
  • Commonwealth licensed commercial fishing is prohibited at depths below 700 m to prevent targeting of deepwater species (750 m in the Great Australian Bight), which provides some refuge for Greeneye Spurdog (since 2007);
  • Implementation of the Management Plan (operational since 1 July 2013) for the South-East Marine Parks Network (proclaimed in 2007) that prohibits demersal otter trawl and Danish seining, and in some areas, all other fishing methods, in 14 Commonwealth marine reserves covering ~388,464 km² over a diverse range of temperate marine environments on the continental shelf, continental slope, and abyssal plain;
  • A large deepwater dogfish fishing closure on the continental slope from the inner margin of various depths of 250–850 m to the outer margin of 1,000 m depth extending from the New South Wales–Queensland border south to off the Hawkesbury River (latitude ~33°35´S) (NSW Government Official Notice 19 February 2013) and a smaller more southerly closed area (NSW Government Official Notice 29 April 2011) that may provide conservation benefits for Greeneye Spurdog;
  • A trip catch limit of 10 kg (carcass mass with fins attached) of deepwater dogfish per day in New South Wales ocean waters (NSW Government Official Notice 29 April 2011) that discourages targeting of Greeneye Spurdog; and,
  • A reduced overall TAC adopted to include all deepwater dogfishes (including Greeneye Spurdog), together with other management measures that have reduced the overall catch of deepwater dogfishes.

rationale: The Coastal Stingaree (Urolophus orarius) is a small-sized ray (to 31 cm total length) which is endemic to the eastern Great Australian Bight in the state of South Australia. It has a restricted distribution in shallow inshore waters at depths of 5-50 m with an estimated extent of occurrence of ~40,000 km² (the previous assessment underestimated this at <5,000 km²). Stingarees have limited biological productivity (annual or biennial reproductive cycles with small litter sizes). The Coastal Stingaree is considered sparsely-distributed with low abundance. During trawl surveys in the Spencer Gulf in 2007, the species was recorded at 11 sites (14 individuals) while during surveys in 2013, only a single individual was recorded. The 2007 surveys, however, consisted of 120 sites, whereas the 2013 surveys consisted of 65 sites; a decrease in records was therefore expected. Nonetheless, the recording of only a single individual in 2013 is of concern. During both surveys, the Coastal Stingaree was only recorded at sites with low trawling intensity, which might indicate that it cannot sustain trawling pressure. The South Australian Prawn Fisheries operate over about half of the known range of the Coastal Stingaree. Commercial prawn trawling in South Australia commenced in the 1960s and historically, fishing pressure has been intense in parts of this fishery, particularly in the Spencer Gulf. Based on the overlap between the species' distribution and South Australian trawl fisheries, the long history of trawling within its range, its likely low productivity, and its occurrence only at sites of low trawling intensity, it is suspected that the species has undergone a population reduction of >50% over the last three generations (27 years), and is therefore assessed as Endangered A2d.
habitat: The Coastal Stingaree has been recorded from inshore waters of the continental shelf at depths of 5-50 m (Last et al. 2016). It reaches a maximum size of ~31 cm total length (TL); male maturity is ~23 cm TL (Last and Stevens 2009). Like other urolophids, it is likely to have low fecundity (as low as 1-2 pups/year) (White et al. 2001, Kyne et al. 2016). Age data are not available for this species, but data from the Lobed Stingaree (Urolophus lobatus) from White et al. (2001) can be used to estimate a generation length of 9 years.
threats:
The range of the Coastal Stingaree is outside of fishing grounds of the Great Australian Bight Trawl Sector of the Southern and Eastern Scalefish and Shark Fishery (SESSF), although there is some overlap with the Commonwealth Trawl Sector at the eastern edge of its range (Patterson et al. 2017).

The South Australian Prawn Fisheries operate over about half of the known range of the Coastal Stingaree (PIRSA 2017). These are the Spencer Gulf Prawn Fishery (30 licences), Gulf St. Vincent Prawn Fishery (10 licences), and West Coast Prawn Fishery (3 licences) (PIRSA 2010, 2014, 2017). Commercial prawn trawling in South Australia commenced in the 1960s and historically, fishing pressure has been intense in parts of this fishery, particularly in the Spencer Gulf. The Coastal Stingaree was recorded as a bycatch of the Spencer Gulf Prawn Fishery by Burnell et al. (2015), but given overlap between all three fisheries and the species' geographic and depth, it is suspected to be a bycatch in all of these fisheries. 

Where the species is taken as bycatch, a concern is the demonstrated low post-release survivorship of trawl caught stingarees (Campbell et al. 2018), and the fact that urolophids frequently abort pups upon capture and handling; even if gravid females survived capture, their reproductive output can be lost (White et al. 2001, Trinnie et al. 2009, Adams et al. 2018).
population:
No data are available on population size and structure of the Coastal Stingaree, although it is considered sparsely-distributed with low abundance (Walker 2004, Last et al. 2006). During trawl surveys in the Spencer Gulf in 2007, the species was recorded at 11 sites (14 individuals) while during surveys in 2013, only a single individual was recorded (Burnell et al. 2015). The 2007 surveys, however, consisted of 120 sites, whereas the 2013 surveys consisted of 65 sites; a lower number of records is therefore expected (Burnell et al. 2015). Nonetheless, the recording of only a single individual in 2013 is of concern. During both surveys, the Coastal Stingaree was only recorded at sites with low trawling intensity, suggestive that it cannot sustain trawling pressure. 

Based on the overlap between the species' distribution and South Australian trawl fisheries, the long history of trawling within its range, and its occurrence only at sites of low trawling intensity, it is suspected that the species has undergone a population reduction of >50% over the last three generations (27 years). It may find refuge in shallower waters outside of the trawl fisheries (<10 m), however, the bulk of the species' depth range (5-50 m) overlaps with those of the trawl fishery.
range: The Coastal Stingaree is endemic to southern Australia in the Eastern Indian Ocean where it is known from eastern Great Australian Bight between Ceduna and Beachport, South Australia (Last and Stevens 2009, Last et al. 2016). The previous assessment (Last et al. 2006) estimated extent of occurrence to be <5,000 km², however it is ~40,000 km² (TSSC 2009).
useTrade: This species is not known to be utilized, and it discarded when taken in commercial fisheries.
conservationActions:
Critical data gaps exist for the Coastal Stingaree, a poorly-known threatened species. Given its restricted distribution which overlaps with trawl fishing, spatial management may be key to securing the species. Habitat use and movement/residency patterns are unknown for this species, thus it is difficult to assess the benefits of South Australia's inshore marine park network (National Parks South Australia 2018) with regards to the Coastal Stingaree. Research is needed to focus on these aspects of the species' ecology in order to establish effective management and conservation measures. Bycatch monitoring and mitigation are a priority. 

South Australian prawn trawl fisheries are managed by traditional measures such as limited entry, vessel and gear restrictions as well as seasonal closures and rotation of trawling grounds. The use of hoppers to sort the catch reduces handling time of bycatch and can increase survival of discards (PIRSA 2014).

rationale: The Maugean Skate (Zearaja maugeana) is unique among skates in that it is restricted to brackish estuarine waters (occurring almost to freshwater). The Maugean Skate is only recorded from Macquarie and Bathurst Harbours on the west coast of Tasmania in Australia; these may represent two distinct subpopulations. The Maugean Skate is assessed as Endangered due to its small geographic range, presence in only two locations, and a continuing decline in quality of habitat. The extent of occurrence (EOO) is <1,900 km² and the area of occupancy (AOO) is <300 km². One location (Macquarie Harbour) is facing increasing human activity, which is projected to lead to a decrease in EOO, AOO and quality of habitat due to increasing pressures from fish-farming and pollution. Macquarie Harbour currently has anoxic conditions, particularly in the depth range where the eggs are found (20-50 m), and these conditions are continuing. Habitat conditions will need to improve in order for this species not to qualify for a higher threat category in the future. The second subpopulation (Bathurst Harbour) has not been verified in approximately 20 years, despite dedicated surveys, and may be locally extinct.
habitat: The Maugean Skate is a medium-sized skate (to ~84 cm total length (TL)) and is unique among skates in that it is found only in brackish water (Last and Stevens 2009). The estuarine systems in which it lives are high in tannin content, with low light penetration and silty bottoms, resulting in the encroachment of several deepwater invertebrate species into relatively shallow depths. The morphology of this skate resembles that of Dipturus species found on the continental slope (Last and Stevens 1994). Males mature at ~65 cm TL (Last and Stevens 2009) but little else is known of the biological or ecological requirements of this species. Specimens have been caught in a broad range of brackish salinities to almost freshwater (P. Last, pers. obs.). Eggs are deposited at depths of 20-50 m (N. Barrett, pers. comm. 2015).
threats:
Both subpopulations of this skate are in scenic and important recreational areas facing increasing pressure from ecotourism (Edgar et al. 2010). They are also regularly caught by recreational and commercial gillnetting in Macquarie Harbour (Lyle et al. 2014).

Macquarie Harbour is an estuary heavily polluted by prolonged mining operations. A recently rapid expansion of fish-farming has also coincided with considerable reduction in water quality, including extreme hypoxic conditions beyond 15 m depth (Anon. 2014), the habitat used by the skate for egg deposition. Persistent water quality issues could drastically reduce breeding success over coming years and could be catastrophic for this population. It is estimated that due to the hypoxic conditions at least one full year class has been lost, with others expected (N. Barrett, pers. comm. 2015).

The isolation of Bathurst Harbour in the Tasmanian Wilderness World Heritage Area affords some habitat protection for this species. Unfortunately, there are rising anthropogenic stressors including boating, fishing, dive tourism, introduced species, global climate change, nutrient enrichment, and onshore development (Edgar et al. 2010). Of great concern is the lack of sightings of this species in Bathurst Harbour in the last twenty years, despite dedicated survey efforts, indicating that the population may be locally extinct there (Treloar et al. 2013).
population:
The total population size has previously been estimated at <1,000 individuals (P. Last, pers. obs.). A recent tagging study of the Macquarie Harbour subpopulation (unpublished), combined with reports of the species being commonly captured by recreational and commercial gillnetting, suggests this may be a significant underestimate (N. Barrett, pers. comm. 2015).

Concerns for the Macquarie Harbour population remain, in part due to the species primarily utilizing the shallow waters (5-15 m depths) of the harbour (Lyle et al. 2014), where it is most likely to be caught by netting. The harbour is heavily stratified, with water dramatically increasing in salinity between 3 and 10 m, depending on the time of year, whereas the waters below 15 m have low dissolved oxygen (Anon. 2014). These physical parameters likely restrict the species to a narrow depth band within the harbour. Recent reductions in water quality in the harbour between 2009 and 2014, primarily increasingly anoxic conditions below 15 m (Anon. 2014), further restrict the species to this narrow band of ~5-15 m. This time period coincides with a dramatic expansion of salmon aquaculture in the harbour. Declining water quality at depth is of greater concern for breeding success of this species. The Maugean Skate deposits egg cases in the deeper waters of the harbour (Treloar et al. 2013), and the recent reduction in quality of these waters have potential to negatively impact breeding success over coming years.

There have been no confirmed sightings of the species at the second location, Bathurst Harbour, in the past 20 years, despite dedicated survey efforts (Treloar et al. 2013). This is of great concern, especially given the increasing human impacts within Macquarie Harbour.

The two subpopulations (Bathurst Harbour and Macquarie Harbour) are separated by ocean and, to date, no individuals have been captured in the marine environment. Due to the physical segregation of these populations, the two subpopulations may be genetically distinct.
range: The Maugean Skate is a temperate Australian species, confined to two large estuary systems in western Tasmania, Bathurst and Macquarie Harbours. The Maugean Skate appears to be mainly in the upper estuary to freshwater sectors of Macquarie Harbour, however, recent studies have shown that they do move quite extensively throughout the harbour (J. Lyle, pers. comm., 01/04/2015). The total available habitat is no more than 200-300 km², therefore, the species' area of occupancy (AOO) is <300 km<sup></sup>².
useTrade: This species is protected under Australian law and is not utilized or traded.
conservationActions: The species is listed as Endangered on the Commonwealth Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act and the Tasmania Threatened Species Protection Act, and is therefore protected by Australian and Tasmanian law. Bathurst Harbour is part of the Tasmanian Wilderness World Heritage Area, which provides some protection for Maugean Skate habitat, however, dedicated scientific surveys have failed to find the species there in the past 20 years. There are ongoing research projects being conducted by the University of Tasmania's Institute for Marine and Antarctic Studies (IMAS) in Macquarie Harbour aiming to better identify the preferred habitat and distribution of this skate within the estuary (J. Lyle, pers. comms., 01/04/2015). Urgent study is needed into egg deposition and likely impacts of rapidly declining water quality on egg viability and juvenile survival.

rationale: This species is restricted to patchily distributed lagoonal coral reefs off southern Belize. It has an estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) of 871 km<sup>2 </sup>and an area of occupancy (AOO) of 360 km<sup>2</sup>. Mangroves and corals off Belize have experienced declines due to coastal development and poor land use practices, therefore, this is considered to represent a single location. Most of its range occurs within marine reserves managed by the government, however, mangrove clearing is known to continue in some parts and corals have declined as a result of increased sedimentation due to this activity as well as other factors, including climate change impacts. Therefore, it is listed as Endangered B1ab(i,ii,iii)+2ab(i,ii,iii). In addition to improving protections on the sensitive habitats it inhabits, additional survey work and research on its biology are needed.
habitat: Adults of this species primarily utilize coral patch reefs in lagoonal areas surrounding mangrove islands/cays. Juveniles may occur amongst mangrove roots (Moran et al. 2019). Its maximum standard length is 9.4 cm (Lobel 2011). Members of this genus are known to be synchronous hermaphrodites with individuals alternating male and female "roles" during spawning (Fischer 1981).
threats: The Mesoamerican Barrier Reef System (dominated by Belize) has experienced significant declines in coral and mangrove cover due to coastal development and increased sedimentation from extensive and unsustainable use of watersheds and inland deforestation (Garcia-Salgado et al. 2008). Coral reef loss is the primary major threat. Removal of mangroves increases sedimentation which then directly degrades reefs. This species is potentially consumed by the invasive lionfish during subadult stages.
population: This species was common and abundant when collected by Lobel (2011) in Tunicate Cove in the 1990s, but surveys conducted in 2017 in Tunicate Cove and nearby areas observed only two individuals (Moran et al. 2019). The reduction of coral in the Tunicate Cove to rubble may have caused a population reduction in this species. In contrast, the 2017 surveys found the highest densities of this species in Laughing Bird Cay National Park where there are healthier stands of Acropora corals (Moran et al. 2019).
range: This species is endemic to a 50 km section of the Mesoamerican Barrier Reef System off Belize from Wee Wee Cay (South Water Marine Reserve), throughout the Pelican Cays and the Sapodilla Cays (Lobel 2011, Moran et al. 2019). A record taken several kilometres further north off Alligator Cay was found in uncharacteristic habitat (oceanic side of a reef) and is considered a waif. The depth range is 0-15 metres. The species is considered to exist in a single location, with the major threat identified as habitat degradation. Based on a minimum bounding polygon drawn around this range, the extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated as 871 km2. Based on the area of coral reef within this polygon according to WCMC-008 Global Distribution of Coral Reefs (UNEP-WCMC et al. 2010), the maximum area of occupancy (AOO) is estimated as the area of 90 grid cells of 2 x 2 km size, which totals 360 km2.
useTrade: This species could have value in the aquarium trade, but is not known to be in the trade yet (B. Moran pers. comm. 2020).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures. The majority of this species' range occurs within the South Water Cay Marine Reserve and the Sapodilla Cays Marine Reserve which were both established in 1996. It is currently managed under a plan developed by the government of Belize. Mangrove clearing is known to continue in some parts (B. Moran pers. comm. 2020). Research needs include further population surveys throughout this area, especially in the patch reefs on the interior of the Mesoamerican Barrier Reef System between Laughing Bird Cay and the Sapodilla Cays. Further research is also needed on the frequency of breeding between other co-occurring hamlet species (B. Moran pers. comm. 2020).

rationale:
Lucifuga lucayana has a highly patchy and restricted distribution. It has only been known to occur to a depth of 20 m in three inland cave or sink hole systems in the northern Bahamas: the Lucayan Caverns, the Zodiac Caverns, and one or two inland sink holes on Abaco Island. Its estimated area of occupancy (AOO) is less than 100 km² and its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,705 km², which meets the thresholds for Endangered under criteria B1 and B2.

The taxonomy of the Lucifuga genus is not yet complete, but is currently being researched. Although data are limited, the population size of L. lucayana is potentially very small. The characteristic low levels of oxygen within these caves is another significant limiting factor. Data on the life history of L. lucayana are limited, and few mature females have been found. It has been inferred that Lucifuga species have a long generation length.

Threats to cave-dwelling species in the Caribbean include habitat degradation through rock removal or siltation, hydrological manipulations caused by water removal, environmental pollution, and the introduction of alien species. Typically, a cave that is near high densities of human populations is more threatened. Currently, Lucayan Caverns is protected within the Lucayan National Park, which is managed by the Bahamas National Trust and restricts recreational scuba diving to special permission only. The status of conservation in the Zodiac Caverns is unknown. A proposal for cave conservation of 17 blue holes on Great Abaco Island was submitted in 2010, but an updated status is not available. Further research on these restricted populations is needed. Lucifuga lucayana is assessed as Endangered (EN B1ab(iii)+B2ab(iii)).
habitat:
Lucifuga lucayana is a small, viviparous fish with greatly reduced eyes that shies away from direct light where it lives in landlocked cave systems. It has been collected to a maximum size of 12.5 cm standard length (SL).

The environmental conditions of the sink holes are unknown, but both of the caves are anchialine in nature, where the top layer of water is fresh and the bottom is salty due to a subterranean connection to the sea. This species has been collected and observed from the fresh layer at Lucayan Caverns and from the salty layer at Zodiac Caverns, indicating that it is euryhaline in nature (Moller et al. 2006). Caribbean anchialine caves have very low levels of oxygen in the water and sediments, often with a boundary layer of hydrogen sulphide separating the fresh and salty (Hutchinson 1999, Bishop et al. 2004). The biogeochemistry of individual holes/caves vary widely, with particular sensitivity to solar insolation, water flow velocities, and organic matter inputs (Hutchinson 1999, Gonzalez et al. 2011). Due to the already harsh nature of this environment, even slight changes in cave water quality can negatively affect troglobitic organisms, which have already adapted with very low metabolic rates and small size so as to efficiently use energy when oxygen and food supply are scarce (Hutchinson 1999, Bishop et al. 2004, Gonzalez et al. 2011).

Food availability is a significant limiting factor for these cave fishes. Gonzalez et al. (2011) reported that food webs in these caves may be dependent on indigenous bacterial primary production. Populations of Lucifuga spp. seem to remain stable throughout the year, but the populations of the invertebrates that constitute their diet fluctuate significantly (Garcia-Machado and Hernandez 2012). The highest densities of Lucifuga spp. are usually observed hiding under ledges and in dark alcoves near the entrance where prey items tend to congregate (Trajano 2001). Lucifuga spp. are opportunistic, passive foragers that primarily prey on troglobitic amphipods and mysids, but will also eat crustaceans and shrimp (Trajano 2001, Moller et al. 2006, Garcia-Debras and Gonzalez 1999). Vegetable matter was found in the digestive tract of the holotype of L. simile. Populations of Lucifuga spp. are significantly more abundant in caves that bats also inhabit because their guano fertilizes the water and promotes growth of food sources for the fish (Garcia-Debras and Gonzalez 1999).

Data on the reproductive strategy of L. lucayana are limited, however, two other species of Lucifuga that are endemic to freshwater caves in Cuba have a breeding peak in March, with females carrying 2-15 embryos that are approximately 2.5 cm SL at birth (Eigenmann 1909). The ovaries in female fishes of the Lucifuga and Ogilbia genera are very similar, however, sexual structures of the male, though both intromittent, are different (Møller et al. 2016). Male fishes are characterized by the presence of an external reproductive organ anterior to the anal fin, which it uses to facilitate internal fertilization of females (Nielsen et al. 1999). It is thought that mating begins as soon as the female reaches maturity, when the female is able to carry and even nourish the delivered spermatozoa within their body for long periods of time. Throughout their five stages of development, the embryos of Ogilbia spp. obtain nutrients from yolk and ovigerous tissue produced within the female. Fecundity levels among bythitids vary greatly (Wourms 1981). The significantly smaller brood size of L. lucayana compared to other bythitid species, is probably due to a longer gestation of the embryos, which allow them to reach a more advanced stage of development, and consequently, allow for a greater chance of survival after birth (Suarez 1975). Reproduction may be infrequent and fecundity relatively low, but further research is needed (Trajano 2001, Garcia-Machado and Hernandez 2012). Definitive data on the longevity of L. lucayana are unknown, but it may be inferred that Lucifuga spp. have a long generation length because their populations are small and there have been very few captures of juveniles or pregnant females (Garcia-Machado and Hernandez 2012).
threats:
Lucifuga lucayana may be experiencing direct threats from habitat degradation and introduced alien species. Proudlove (2001) described five main threats to cave-dwelling species: habitat degradation through rock removal or siltation, hydrological manipulations caused by water removal, environmental pollution, overexploitation, and the introduction of alien species. On multiple occasions, people have reported evidence of trash, sewage, industrial pollution, and competition from introduced species in caves throughout the range of all Caribbean Lucifuga spp. (Hutchinson 1999, Proudlove 2001, Proudlove 2006, Moller et al. 2006, Garcia-Machado et al. 2011). The level of impact and rate of occurrence of these disturbances directly correlates to the location of the cave/hole in relation to human population density. A hole/cave that is distantly located and difficult to access will remain more pristine and unaltered (Proudlove 2001). In contrast, increasing human population density around a subterranean habitat is a threat. There is concern that caves that are proximal to dense human populations could be exposed to insecticide spraying (Hutchinson 1999). Caves used intensively for swimming might be affected by sun screens and eutrophication. 

Scuba divers can be detrimental to these caves when they disturb the stratification of bacterial mats that lie near the halocline, enrich the levels of oxygen in the water, and perhaps introduce flora and fauna to the system. Some opinions, however, are that any information gained from further exploration of these environments may overcome the possible negative effects especially because a small proportion of these holes are likely to be affected by such activity (Hutchinson 1999, Proudlove 2001).
population:
Cave-diving expeditions can be logistically challenging and dangerous to undertake, therefore population data for L. lucayana are limited. The Lucifuga genus continues to evolve due to the discovery of new species in previously unexplored caves throughout the Caribbean. It will be difficult to grasp a complete understanding of the populations of Lucifuga spp. until a more detailed picture of their diversity and distribution is realized (Moller et al. 2006, Garcia-Machado et al. 2011). Garcia-Machado and Hernandez (2012) reported that populations of Lucifuga spp. tend to remain stable throughout the year.

This species was originally described from six specimens collected between the years 1980 and 1984 from two caves and one or two sink holes in the northern Bahamas. Due to very few specimens having been identified, the population size of L. lucayana may be small. Møller et al. (2006) calculated the population size of L. spelaeotes, a closely related species with a wider distribution but also endemic to the Bahamas, as less than 1,000 individuals. Since the description in 2006, to our knowledge no additional specimens have been collected. A seventh specimen collected September 8 also in Lucayan Cavern was donated by Jill Yager to the Natural History Museum of Denmark.
range:
In general, Lucifuga spp. have highly patchy distributions, where they are only found in inland karst caves located near coastal margins (Garcia-Machado et al. 2011).

Lucifuga lucayana has been found in at least three inland cave or sink hole systems in the northern Bahamas to a depth of 20 m: the Lucayan Caverns in central southern Grand Bahama Island, the Zodiac Caverns on Sweetings Cay in eastern Grand Bahama, and one or two inland sink holes on Abaco Island (Little Bahama Bank). The range of this species is separated from that of L. spelaeotes by the deep waters of the Providence Channels. When L. spelaeotes was listed as Vulnerable on The IUCN Red List in 1996 (World Conservation Monitoring Centre 1996), its AOO was calculated as less than 100 km² with the number of recorded locations as less than five (Moller et al. 2006). This species is currently only known from three localities with an estimated EOO of 2,705 km² (based on a minimum convex polygon drawn around the extent of its range). Since not all caverns are mapped in the Bahamas, the AOO is currently unknown, however, it is inferred to be less than 100 km².
useTrade: Lucifuga lucayana is not utilized.
conservationActions:
Lucifuga species play an important ecological role in the balance of caves that they inhabit (Garcia-Debras and Gonzalez 1999). The threats of ongoing habitat degradation by human activities within the extremely limited distribution and the more recent widespread introduction of alien species that deplete the limited food supply of Lucifuga spp. require the attention of conservationists. Since species diversity for the Lucifuga genus is likely underestimated due to the incomplete exploration of their highly fragmented distribution, implementing conservation could be difficult without a more complete list of specific holes/caves that currently harbour populations (Garcia-Machado et al. 2011).

Some Lucifuga species have been successfully bred in captivity, which could prove beneficial if a population needs replenishment (Proudlove 2001). Lucifuga simile has been raised successfully on a diet of Troglocubanus spp. (cave shrimp) (Garcia-Debras and Gonzalez 1999). Further research on rearing L. lucayana should be explored.

The Lucayan Caves are contained within the Lucayan National Park, which is managed by the Bahamas National Trust, an organization tasked with the conservation of the country's natural resources. Diving in the Lucayan Caves is regulated to certain areas and is allowed only by special permission from the Underwater Explorers Society to experienced and trained divers. Details on diving in the Zodiac Caverns and holes on Abaco Island are not available at this time. The Bahamas Caves Research Foundation, drafted a proposal in the year 2010 that would protect 17 blue holes on Great Abaco Island and create awareness about cave conservation (Kakuk and Patterson 2010). Efforts to contact both the BNT and BCRF via email to request further information on conservation measures specific to these cave environments were largely unanswered. Proudlove (2001) reported that most Lucifuga species listed as threatened or more are not receiving necessary conservation attention. Habitat management, monitoring, education, and economic activities surrounding subterranean cave systems should be considered during the planning process (Garcia-Machado et al. 2011, Garcia-Machado and Hernandez 2012).

rationale:
This species has a very limited distribution within the Gulf of Mexico where it is only known from four locations in the lagoons along the Yucatan Peninsula, Mexico (Celestun, Ria Lagartos, Bocas Dzilam, and Yucalpeten). It has been suggested that more coastal areas around its present distribution should be surveyed to confirm the full extent of this species' range. It inhabits shallow coastal lagoons where it is often associated with seagrass. Its estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 14,563 km2 and its area of occupancy (AOO) is estimated at less than 500 km2. Based on this information, the highest category the species qualifies for is Endangered under criterion B2 (EN B2ab(i,ii)).

It can be locally abundant, but is generally uncommon and little is known of its biology. The species is impacted by habitat degradation due to pollution and there is a suspected general decline in its population size; however, further research is needed to confirm this. Ria Lagartos is a UNESCO Biosphere Reserve that is well-protected and funded.

The species is listed as PR (Vulnerable) on Mexico's list of imperilled species.
habitat: This benthopelagic, non-migratory species occurs in shallow, fresh-to-brackish habitats within tropical climates. It is usually associated with seagrasses but it can tolerate low oxygen levels (M. Vega-Cendejas pers. comm. 2014). It inhabits a salinity range between 35.0-89.0 psu (Vega-Cendejas and Hernández de Santillana 2004, Peralta-Meixueiro and Vega-Cendejas 2011). Its maximum size is 15 cm TL (Huber 1996). It feeds on zooplankton, plants, invertebrates (especially insects) and small fishes (Vega-Cendejas et al. 1997, Vega-Cendejas and Arreguin-Sanchez 2001). Little is known of its life cycle. It may spawn in the dry season (Arceo-Carranza and Vega-Cendejas 2009).
threats: This species may be threatened by habitat degradation due to pollution and urban development within parts of its restricted range. It may also be used as bait in some locations (M. Vega-Cendejas pers. comm. 2014).
population: Although this species has a restricted range and is generally uncommon, it can be locally abundant. It is suspected that there has been a general decline in the number of mature individuals, however direct quantitative information is lacking (M. Vega-Cendejas pers. comm. 2014). In a study conducted in the Ría Lagartos lagoon (Mexico), this species was recorded with a 0.38 %N (percentage of total numbers) and 0.28 %W (weight in grams) of all the representative fishes collected (Vega-Cendejas and Hernández de Santillana 2004). In Dzilam lagoon (Yucatan), it had a relative abundance of 18.18 %N and biomass of 20.77 %W (Arceo-Carranza and Vega-Cendejas 2009).
range: This killifish is restricted to the Gulf of Mexico where it is known from Celestun, Ria Lagartos, Bocas Dzilam, and Yucalpeten lagoons (four locations) along the northern part of the Yucatan Peninsula, Mexico. It is thought that other coastal localities should be surveyed for this species since it occurs in brackish waters and may have a larger extent than previously estimated (Snoeks et al. 2009). Records from Madre Bay and Laguna Tamiahua, Mexico require verification (R. Robertson pers. comm. 2014). Its estimated EOO is 14,563 km2 (based on a minimum convex polygon drawn around the extent of its range on a 0-5 m bathymetric layer). Its estimated AOO is 2,644 km2 (calculated by clipping the distribution polygon to the 0-5 m bathymetric layer extracted from ETOPO), but since it is restricted to four lagoons that are patchily distributed across this area, its AOO is likely less than 500 km2.
useTrade: This species is typically not utilized, but may be used as bait in some locations (M. Vega-Cendejas pers. comm. 2014).
conservationActions: This species is protected in Mexico and is listed as PR (Vulnerable) on the list of imperilled species (NOM-59 2010). It occurs within the Ria Lagartos UNESCO Biosphere Reserve, which is a well-protected and well-funded conservation area.

rationale: Neostethus geminus is only known from brackish water among Nipah forest, of the Belait district and Kuala Tutong, of the Tutong district within Brunei Darussalam. It is possible, given these areas probably face threats of deforestation and results of palm oil plantation or urbanisation pollution within the water systems, that this species has fewer than 5 locations. Although it is not known if the population is in decline, with an ongoing decline in the quality of habitat, and the extent of occurrence estimated at 4,494 km2, this species is assessed as Endangered, but in need of research into population and localities, as it may have fewer locations.
habitat: Neostethus geminus can be found in brackish water in coastal streams and rivers. Its body is translucent and it has a maximum size of 2.6 cm SL (Parenti 2014). Species in the genus Neostethus can be distinguished by a complex reproductive organ in males called the priapium, which is used to clasp females during internal fertilisation (Kottelat et al. 1993). Females lay fertilised eggs which attach to substrates such as plants via adhesive filaments (Parenti 2014).
threats: This species is probably impacted by habitat degradation and loss resulting from existing and planned dams within Borneo (Tang 2019), as well as deforestation and expansion of palm plantations. These degrade freshwater habitats by severely increasing bank erosion and sediment yield, decreasing forest shading and increasing forest litter, which has reduced water quality across the Sundaic region (Chellaiah and Yule, 2017, Zieritz et al. 2016, Hon and Samejima 2019).
population: This species is abundant in collections from Brunei Darussalam (Parenti 2014), although its population trend is unknown.
range: Neostethus geminus is only known from brackish water among Nipah forest, Kuala Belait, Belait district and Kuala Tutong, Tutong district within Brunei Darussalam (Parenti 2014, Sulaiman, Tan and Lim 2018). This species' extent of occurrence is estimated at 4,494 km2 and it is estimated to occur within less than 5 locations, as it is known from only two forest areas within two districts of Brunei Darussalam, both facing threats of dams (Tang 2019), deforestation and expansion of palm plantations, greatly reducing habitat quality (Chellaiah and Yule, 2017, Zieritz et al. 2016, Hon and Samejima 2019).
useTrade: There is insufficient information regarding the use and trade of this species.
conservationActions: There is no information regarding conservation for this species.

rationale:
Epinephelus akaara is a reef-associated species distributed from Japan to the Gulf of Tonkin. Historically both adults and juveniles have been heavily exploited throughout its range, and it is highly valued in markets for live trade. Much of the information on past and present abundance of Hong Kong grouper is anecdotal or incomplete, but several accounts support evidence for severe declines in many parts of its range, especially mainland China, the main area where this species occurs after Japan and South Korea. Populations in Korea, Japan, mainland China, Hong Kong and Taiwan had collapsed by the mid-1990s due to overexploitation. Since this initial severe decline, populations have remained at very low levels. Few fishing areas still have this fish and these are mainly offshore islands with severe reductions (>90%) in all inshore areas of China, including Hong Kong, where the species was abundant before the 1980s. Trade also declined substantially. In China, declines in sizes caught and extension of fishing grounds to maintain catches also support evidence for severe overfishing. Reported catches are now negligible almost everywhere, except in one area of western Japan. There is still use of wild broodstock and juveniles for growout culture and low success of hatchery production. There is also a possibility for loss of significant levels of natural genetic diversity and for reduction of first sexual maturation in age and size given severely reduced populations. No effective conservation measures are known.

The apparent dire state of stocks and continued high fishing pressure on this fish and damage to its habitat throughout almost all of its geographic range mean it maybe heading towards extinction in the wild in some areas. This information is worrying enough to support the precautionary approach adopted here. It is suspected that the global population declined by approximately 50 to 80% over the past three generations (i.e., 33 years; 1983-2016), with increases only noted in one area in western Japan over the last decade and extremely low levels indicated throughout the rest of its geographic range. It is therefore listed as Endangered A2d. The following research is greatly needed: genetic structure of populations, fishery catch and effort data and underwater census surveys. Conservation measures are needed to reduce fishing effort and monitor populations.
habitat:
This species inhabits coral and rocky reefs to at least 55 m depth, and juveniles tend to occur in shallower depths than adults (Sadovy and Cornish 2000, Craig et al. 2011). Its maximum standard length is 35 cm (Masuda et al. 1984). Tseng and Ho (1988) reported that fishers from Hong Kong operating in the East and South China Seas take adult and spawning fish along the continental shelf at depths of 27 to 55 metres. In Byonsan Peninsula of Korea, spawning occurs from late July to early August. Hermaphrodites measured about 28 to 32 cm, and males were 40 cm (Lee et al. 1998). An age and growth study found that individuals with total lengths ranging from 12 to 24 cm were about one year of age, 16 to 28 cm at two years, 20 to 32 cm at three years, 22 to 36 cm at four years, 32 to 42 cm at five years, 36 to 48 cm at six years or older; within the same age group, there could be a variability in length of 10 to 14 cm (Kayano 2012). Its longevity is 19 years and sexual maturation occurs at three years and about 23-24 cm standard length (Tseng and Ho 1988). There is no published literature that identifies this species as an aggregate spawner. One report from a recreational diver in Hong Kong observed up to 50 individuals close together on the reef on several different occasions in the summer season (P. Chan pers. comm. 2001). Most fishery catches occur or occurred during the short reproductive season, but there is no clear evidence of spawning aggregation. Further studies on the reproductive biology of this species in captivity, including sexual maturation, sexual lability and sex change were reported by Ukawa et al. (1966), Zhang et al. (1988), Lee and Hur (1997, 1998), Okumura et al. (2002), Li et al. (2006), He et al. (2011), Lee et al. (2014), Kim et al. (2015), and Liu et al. (2016).

Based on a longevity of 19 years, age of first maturity of three years, and applying the mean generational turnover formula in Depczynski and Bellwood (2006), one generation length is estimated to be 11 years.
threats: Overexploitation is a major threat to this species throughout its range. There is also a possibility for loss of significant levels of natural genetic diversity and for reduction of first sexual maturation in age and size given severely reduced populations in most of its range. Nearshore habitat degradation, which is extensive in the region, may also be a threat to this species.
population:
This species once supported significant fisheries through much of its range, but is now uncommon to rare in almost all areas according to data from both fishery landings and underwater visual surveys. Most of the current landings of this species are comprised of juveniles, which indicates that growth overfishing is likely occurring. Interviews and consultation with 31 grouper fishers, 42 farmers, 30 fish hatchers, 21 traders and fisheries departments were conducted in mainland China (Zhejiang, Fujian, Guangdong, Guangxi and Hainan Provinces) between 2007 and 2008 (Liu and Sadovy de Mitcheson 2009). Interviews were also conducted elsewhere in E. akaara's range, including Hong Kong, Taiwan, South Korea and Japan. Results showed that, E. akaara was historically common in these areas, but has seriously declined since due to unsustainable fishing effort, including on juveniles. Supporting evidence included a reported decline in catch per unit effort (CPUE) and a shift to offshore fishing grounds as adults declined beyond the level that could support a viable nearshore fishery (Liu and Sadovy de Mitcheson 2009). Maximum annual catches once peaked at several hundreds of tonnes in regions of China, but reported catches are now negligible almost everywhere, except in one area of western Japan (2013 – 43 tonnes). Mariculturists have successfully bred and raised the species in mainland China and Japan (Tseng and Ho 1988; reviewed in Liu and Sadovy de Mitcheson 2009), but the species is still predominantly taken from the wild for trade due to slow growth and poor production in captivity and restocking conducted in Japan and mainland China either long-term or occasionally is rarely demonstrated to be successful to date. Quantitative population data are very limited to non-existent for this species. The Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) annual landings statistics reported by Hong Kong show a near 100% decline over the past two generations (1993 to 2013). Given the anecdotal data presented below, this species' global population is suspected to have declined by at least 50-80% over the past three generation lengths, which is estimated as 33 years (1983-2016).

Genetic structure and phylogenetic relationships across the range of this species have been studied with varying results; the only substructuring indicated is between Japan and South Korea (Yokogawa 1997, Chen et al. 2008, Han et al. 2014).

Japan: In the 1950s and 1960s, this species supported a seasonal fishery in Japan with catches averaging about 20 to 28 tonnes in Okayama Prefecture. Catch subsequently declined by about 85-95% to one to three tonnes in the 1990s due to overfishing and changes in the fishing grounds (Kayano 2012). To supplement the population, the release of hatchery-produced young into Japanese coastal waters has increased in recent years (about 43 tons in 2013). Catch data for E. akaara are generally scarce in Japan; however, there is a recent dataset from Toyama Prefecture (website: "Toyama Prefecture Fisheries Information System." http://www.fish.pref.toyama.jp/) that indicates population increases are almost certainly the result of restocking in this area (Kayano 2012). Kayano (2012) found that most fish were caught at three years and then two years of age, with mode at size of capture being 20–22 cm, which is too young for the species, given its age of sexual maturation.

Korea: There are no fishery catch or effort data on this species available from the South Korean government. Lee et al. (1998) described the stock of this species as sharply declining year by year in the 1990s due to overfishing. From 1992 to 1994, annual landings declined from about 2.25 to about 1.3 tonnes and fishing yields in coastal Byonsan Peninsula of Korea declined by more than 10% during the same time period (Lee et al. 1998). 

Taiwan: No fishery catch or effort data are available in Taiwan, but it once supported a viable commercial fishery. Anecdotal reports indicate it is now considered rare in the area presumably due to overfishing (K-T. Shao pers. comm. 2016).

Hong Kong: In the 1960s and 1970s, local hand line fishers once frequently targeted this previously common species in islands off the mainland to the north of Hong Kong and in eastern waters, and was commonly sold live in Hong Kong city markets (Chan 1968, P. Chan pers. comm. 2014). By the late 1970s, fishermen began to supplement this high demand by capturing wild juveniles in large amounts and raising them in captivity for growout in floating cages, which contributed to growth overfishing (P. Chan pers. comm. 2014). Hong Kong grouper landings could not keep up with demand by the late 1970s and that prices had risen from HK$ 33-50/kg in 1978 to HK$ 50-70/kg in 1979 as a result (Tseng and Ho 1988). Juveniles are no longer readily available from Hong Kong (Sadovy and Cornish 2000). The population significantly declined in the 1980s, and the species was no longer common by the 1990s (P. Chan pers. comm. 2001, Liu and Sadovy de Mitcheson 2009). It is now rare or absent from commercial catches of today (Chan 1968, Sadovy and Cornish 2000). According to fisher interviews and anecdotal data, the substantial declines in landings are assumed to reflect declines in Hong Kong/regional grouper stocks since fishing effort has remained constant (Liu and Sadovy de Mitcheson 2009). FAO annual fishery landings statistics for E. akaara are very low to non-existent in recent years. According to the Hong Kong government’s Agriculture Fisheries and Conservation Department, there were few records of catch of this species prior to 2010 in their field studies (for example, less than five individuals were found between 2001 to 2004 in eastern waters; J. Lee pers. comm. 2016). Divers also reported that this species was relatively abundant in the 1960s and moderately common in the 1990s, but is now rarely observed in Hong Kong waters (Sadovy and Cornish 2000, To et al. 2013). During more than 700 underwater visual surveys conducted between 1996 to 1999, less than 10 individuals of this species were observed (To et al. 2013, A. Cornish and S. Shea pers. comm. 2016). 

Mainland China: This was once an abundant species in the early 1980s, but became very rare by the mid-1990s. In 1979, Hong Kong culturists purchased at least 180,000 kg (200,000-450,000 fish of 100-200 g) of this species for grow-out that had been wild-caught in southern China. Supply of early-stage juveniles was abundant in Fujian Province of mainland China in the early 1980s, but became very rare by 1994 and remains rare to the current day (Sadovy 2000, Liu and Sadovy de Mitcheson 2009).
range: This western Pacific species occurs in southern Japan, Republic of Korea and southern China, including Hong Kong and Taiwan (Heemstra and Randall 1993). According to Seno (2013), its range in Japan is the Tsugaru Strait (between Honshu and Hokkaido islands) southward to the East China Sea coasts and Pacific coasts from southern Kyushu east to Sagami Bay. Reports from the Ogasawara Islands of Japan are questionable (Randall et al. 1997). In Japan, the range of this species may be extending northward, likely due to warming waters in the region. The species is also reported from the Gulf of Tonkin (Tseng and Ho 1988), making it likely that it also occurs in Viet Nam.
useTrade: Historically this species has been heavily exploited by recreational and commercial fisheries throughout its range. Trade mainly occurred between mainland China, Taiwan and Hong Kong and sometimes with Japan but, due to population declines, it is relatively uncommon to rarely available for sale in the current day. Juveniles were also frequently exploited and grown in captivity prior to population exhaustion by the mid-1990s. It is a highly-valued species in the market, and is particularly favoured in the live seafood trade. The wild-capture fishery for this species in mainland China primarily supplies the live food fish trade in the Hong Kong market, and secondarily in domestic markets. A market survey of groupers sold in Hong Kong from 2004 to 2006 reported that wild-caught individuals of this species ranked 12th out of 18 local grouper species, and that 86 individuals (37% of which were juveniles) were recorded in the market during this time (<1% of total groupers; n=10,640 groupers) (To and Sadovy de Mitcheson 2009). Despite considerable effort, larval survival in captivity is low and highly variable due to this species' slow growth rates, sex ratios (sperm supply) and feeding of larvae (Okumura et al. 2002, Li et al. 2007, He et al. 2011). There is growing interest in obtaining broodstock for spawning and hatchery rearing (P. Chan pers. comm. 2002). Japan has had some success in restocking the species with hatchery produced animals (K. Hoshino pers. comm. 2016).
conservationActions:
Despite its known historical population decline due to overexploitation, this species is not managed effectively anywhere in its range. There is a very small no-take marine reserve at Cape d'Aguilar in Hong Kong where this species may be increasing in number (A. Cornish pers. obs. 2016), but no information is available on its status in protected areas located elsewhere in Hong Kong, southern Japan, Republic of Korea, Taiwan and mainland China. There is a need for time-series data, including annual landings, catch per unit effort and underwater visual surveys in all parts of its range. Such data would greatly increase the accuracy of future assessments. Furthermore, formal stock assessments of this species would increase the general knowledge of its population size and rates of decline. Genetics studies are needed to determine boundaries between subpopulations/stocks, if present. Studies are also needed on its reproductive behaviour in the wild, particularly whether the species aggregates to spawn.

Japan: Hatchery production started in the 1960s in Japan, but logistical problems hindered development, and a viral disease in the 1990s greatly reduced seed production. Broodstock for hatcheries are usually wild-caught near Seto Island in the Japan Inland Sea. Hatchery-produced young are released in efforts to rebuild the wild stock, mainly along the coasts of the Japan Sea (e.g., Yamaguchi, Tottori and Toyama) and the Seto Inland Sea (Okayama, Seto) (Liu and Sadovy de Mitcheson 2009, K. Hoshino pers. comm 2016).

China: Fishery regulations designed to reduce overall fishing effort were implemented in mainland Chinese waters (Yellow Sea and East China Sea) in 1995 and in 1999 in the South China Sea. These regulations include varying bans on fishing gear type as well as closed periods. In the South China Sea and Gulf of Tonkin, all fishing gear types are banned except single-layer gill nets, hook and line and trap fishing from May 16 to August 1. In the East China Sea, there is a closed period for light fishing from May 1 to July 1, for sail stake net fishing from May 1 to September 16, for shrimp trawling, trap and gill net fishing from June 1 to August 1 and for trawl fishing from June 1 to September 16. In the Yellow Sea, there is a closed period for trawl and sailing stake net fishing from June 1 to September 16. It is not known if these regulations reduce effort on populations of Epinephelus akaara specifically, but the primary gear used to capture this species are hook and line, traps and gill nets, which are gear types that only recently began to be managed in the East China Sea. Information is limited on the level of enforcement, but this is generally poor in China, so it is unlikely to be effective.

Hong Kong: There are no fishing restrictions specifically for this species in Hong Kong. Beginning in 2013, take of this species by bottom trawl may have been reduced in Hong Kong waters; however, overall fishing in the Hong Kong area has increased over recent decades and fishing by hook and line and other gears (trap and spear) has not declined. Moreover, illegal bottom trawling has continued in Hong Kong, and a recent trawling ban is not expected to significantly allow recovery of this species. A ban on electrofishing may have reduced catch of juveniles, but other methods during which juveniles of this species are captured are still permitted. This species was categorized as 'endangered' in 2015 during a Hong Kong Regional Red List assessment workshop that was sponsored by the government’s Biodiversity Strategic Action Plan under the Convention on Biological Diversity (Y. Sadovy pers. comm. 2015).

rationale: This species inhabits coastal rocky reef areas and the majority of its global population occurs only in Mexico from Baja California and the Gulf of California. It is heavily exploited by fisheries, including direct pressure on spawning aggregations. Since about the 1940s, catch, aggregation size and individual body size have declined by 50 to 90% and fishing pressure is expected to continue. It is inferred that its global population has declined by at least 50% and possibly more over the past three generation lengths (about 80 years); therefore, it is listed as Endangered A2bd. There is an urgent conservation need to reduce fishing effort on this species, particularly at spawning aggregation sites when adults are most vulnerable to fishing. There is also a need for basic biological information and increased monitoring of juvenile and adult populations.
habitat:
This species inhabits rocky reefs, seamounts and kelp beds (Heemstra and Randall 1993, Craig et al. 2011). Adults mainly occur at depths between five to 30 metres, but may inhabit depths to 45 metres in summer months, and it has been observed on deep reefs to 100 metres (Heemstra and Randall 1993, Sala et al. 2003, Aburto-Oropeza et al. 2010). Juveniles have been observed at shallow rocky reefs and artificial reefs as well as in estuaries, mangroves, and bays on the islands and coastlines throughout the northern and central Gulf of California (Aburto-Oropeza et al. 2008, Turk-Boyer et al. 2015). The maximum recorded total length is 198 cm and weight is 91 kg (Eschmeyer et al. 1983), although it is presumed that it may obtain larger sizes. Adults feed on large fishes, lobsters and slipper lobsters (Aburto-Oropeza et al. 2008).

Its estimated age at first sexual maturity is six to seven years and 98 cm total length (Aburto-Oropeza et al. 2008). Adults form spawning aggregations of 40 or more individuals from April to June in areas larger than 1,000 m² in the southern Gulf of California (T. Rowell, B. Erisman, O. Aburto-Oropeza unpub. data). Aggregations have been observed over rocky reefs or on seamounts with sharp drop-offs and an abundance of gorgonians and black coral (Sala et al. 2003, Aburto-Oropeza et al. 2008), but also over sand adjacent to reefs (e.g., Cabo Pulmo National Park). Spawning occurs in pairs, and individual males will spawn with multiple females during a single spawning period with an operational sex ratio of about three to five females per male (T. Rowell, B. Erisman, O. Aburto-Oropeza unpub. data). Since observed males appear to be much larger than females, sex ratios are biased towards females, spawning occurs in pairs, large males invest considerable energy in aggressive behaviour with males in adjacent territories, and there is no evidence of sperm competition, it is likely that this species is a protogynous hermaphrodite (B. Erisman pers. comm. 2016). However, this still requires confirmation by microscopic analyses of histological preparations. Longevity is estimated to be 48.3 years (Aburto-Oropeza et al. 2008), but no empirical studies on growth or longevity have been published. Based on a longevity of 48 years, age of first maturity of six years, and applying the mean generational turnover formula in Depczynski and Bellwood (2006), one generation length is estimated to be 27 years.
threats: This species is experiencing a major threat from heavy fishing pressure by recreational and small-scale commercial fisheries through most of its range (Heemstra and Randall 1993, Sáenz-Arroyo et al. 2005, Aburto-Oropeza et al. 2008, Erisman et al. 2010). Secondary threats include the following: (1) bycatch in the commercial shrimp industry, (2) bycatch in the illegal totoaba fishery, (3) habitat degradation, (4) shrimp aquaculture, and (5) climate change (Dennis 2015). This species may be particularly susceptible to increasing water temperatures due to climate change since the centre of its abundance occurs within a Gulf that has a northern land boundary (i.e., it may not be able to expand to cooler waters) and indirect impacts from the potential loss of forage due to distribution shifts in their prey (Dennis 2015). The life history characteristics (form spatio-temporally predictable spawning aggregations; slow growth; late age at maturity; long lifespan) and restricted geographic range of this species are associated with high intrinsic vulnerability to fishing pressure (Jennings et al. 1998).
population:
This species is naturally rare where it ranges north of Bahía Magdalena on the Pacific coast of Baja California, Mexico into southern California, USA. Juveniles are unknown in California waters and few large adults have been taken there, probably as expatriates from a more southerly breeding population (Rosenblatt and Zahuranec 1967). It was once common along the southern Pacific coast of the Baja California peninsula and in the Gulf of California in Mexico, but has severely declined throughout its range, and is now rarely observed. It was abundant in central Baja California in the Gulf of California in the past and probably dominated the rocky-reef fish community in terms of biomass; however, its population declined dramatically in the 1970s and is now scarce and in danger of localized extirpation. From the 1940s to present, the numbers of individuals within spawning aggregations has declined by at least 99% (Sáenz-Arroyo et al. 2005). Therefore, according to fisheries data, this species is inferred to have declined by at least 50% and possibly more over the past three generation lengths (1935-2016) and the threat from fishing is expected to continue in to the future.

Fishery independent: Underwater surveys of rocky reef fishes have been conducted during the summer at sites throughout the Gulf of California continuously since 1998 by the Gulf of California Marine Program (GCMP; http://gulfprogram.ucsd.edu/) and Comunidad y Biodiversidad (COBI). From 1998 to 2010 (12 year period), over 2,500 transects were conducted and this species was observed only 50 times, which accounted for less than 0.005% of all fishes counted, making it one of the rarest species recorded. Forty-percent of those 50 observations were made during surveys conducted in 2009 and 2010, which were also the years when 32% of all transects across the entire time period were conducted. Nearly all observations of adult individuals (>100 cm total length) in the 2009 and 2010 surveys occurred during transects within the Cabo Pulmo National Park. According to recreational citizen science diver surveys in the Reef Environmental Education Foundation (REEF) database, the overall sighting frequency of this species in the Gulf of California is 2.1 (http://www.reef.org/db/reports/dist/species/TEP/0055/1993-01-01/2016-09-13, accessed 13 September 2016).
Fishery dependent: Due to its naturally rarity in U.S. waters, fisheries data are not collected there. Fisher interviews indicate a 50 to 70% decline since 1950 in the Gulf of California (Aburto-Oropeza et al. 2008, Ainsworth 2011). On a good fishing day in the 1940s, it was common to capture 25 or more individuals of this species, each more than 80 cm in length, but by 2000, the capture of even one or two individuals of less than 60 cm in length was considered a good fishing day. Fishers in the northern Gulf of California reported that abundance and relative biomass were high in the 1950s, but much lower in the 2000s (Ainsworth 2011). Interviews of 108 randomly selected fishers in fishing communities of central Baja California that were conducted in 2002 found that older (~ 55 years old) fishers caught up to 25 times as much Mycteroperca jordani as younger (15 to 30 years old) fishers on their best-ever fishing day and that the average size of individuals captured declined significantly over the fisher generations (Sáenz-Arroyo et al. 2005b). In 1959 and 1960, this species comprised 45% of the total state finfish landings in Baja California Sur, and by early 1972 it had declined to 6% (Sáenz-Arroyo et al. 2005a). By the 1990s, it was estimated to comprise less than 1% of the total finfish catch (Rámirez-Rodriguez 1996). In general, fish stocks in most areas of the Gulf of California had collapsed by the 1980s (Aburto-Oropeza et al. 2008). The reported mean annual commercial landings of this species in the southwest Gulf of California from 1999 to 2007 was 9.7 tons, which represented 0.54% of the total reef fish species (Erisman et al. 2010). A fishery survey conducted in Bahía de Los Angeles in the northern Gulf of California in 2004, reported that immature individuals comprised approximately 99% of the commercial catch (Aburto-Oropeza et al. 2008). In northwest Mexico, fisheries data were first identified to the level of species groups (i.e., several species of the same genus or family) in 2001 (Erisman et al. 2010). During a survey of the artisanal fishery of La Paz Bay, Baja California Sur, this species (incorrectly identified as Epinephelus quinquefasciatus) comprised 5.4% of the total catch from 1998 to 2005 (Vazquez-Hurtado et al. 2010). According to Mexican fisheries statistics for “garropa”- a category that includes Mycteroperca jordani, M. xenarcha, Epinephelus quinquefasciatus and Stereolepis gigas - catch increased by 153% from 78 metric tons in 2006 to 197 metric tons in 2014 and the majority of landings occurred in Baja California Sur (CONAPESCA, http://www.conapesca.gob.mx/wb/cona/informacion_estadistica_por_especie_y_entidad, accessed 13/09/2016). Over the last 20 years (1990s to 2000s), landings have declined by 90% through much of the Gulf from an average of 50 tons per year to less than five tons per year (Aburto-Oropeza et al. 2008). As of 2005-2010, this species comprised less than 1% of the total annual catch in the small-scale, commercial reef fish fishery of the Southern Gulf of California (Aburto-Oropeza et al. 2008, Erisman et al. 2010). An estimated 29% of the remaining population of this species are caught in the Gulf each year (Aburto-Oropeza et al. 2008).
range: This species is distributed in the eastern tropical Pacific from San Carlos, Mexico, south to Mazatlán, Mexico, through the Gulf of California and the Revillagigedos Islands (Erisman et al. 2011, Robertson and Allen 2015). Records of this species from San Diego, California, USA from the 1940s and 1950s (Craig et al. 2006) are likely based on waifs. Its depth range is 5-100 metres.
useTrade: Despite low landings volumes, this relatively large species is still considered one of the most valuable species of grouper in commercial and recreational fisheries in the Gulf of California (Aburto-Oropeza et al. 2008). In a 2003 survey of recreational fisheries in the northern Gulf of California, it was reported to be the 8th most important (as measured by % capture) fish species caught (Turk-Boyer et al. 2015). In the northern Gulf, it is commercially harvested by diving, gillnets (as bycatch), longline and hand line (Moreno-Baáez et al. 2010, 2012). It has been a primary target of recreational spearfishers since at least the 1950s (Aburto-Oropeza et al. 2008). It is also taken by hook and line, especially at spawning aggregation sites in late Spring. This species is also taken as bycatch in the Gulf of California shrimp trawl fishery.
conservationActions:
There are no species-specific national regulations in place for Mycteroperca jordani in Mexico (Dennis 2015). Fishing is allowed in many zones within protected areas, and enforcement of no-take zones is very poor in most areas (Rife et al. 2013). However, there is evidence for effective protection of this species in Cabo Pulmo National Park (Aburto-Oropeza et al. 2011, B. Erisman pers. comm. 2016). A fishermen-led, voluntary marine reserve off Isla Magdalena, Baja California Sur established in 2009 also has a higher biomass of this species inside the reserve as compared to unprotected sites (Villaseñor-Derbez et al. 2016).

This species was listed as 'endangered' under the U.S. Endangered Species Act (ESA) in 2016, which bans anybody subject to U.S. jurisdiction to harvest this species in U.S. waters or on the high seas (http://www.nmfs.noaa.gov/pr/species/fish/gulf-grouper.html, accessed 15 September 2016). However, given that this species is historically rare in U.S. waters, such a measure is unlikely to have a measurable impact on the preservation of the species.

Given the widespread declines of landings and regional populations of this species throughout its range due to fishing, there is an urgent conservation need to reduce fishing effort on this species, particularly at spawning aggregation sites when adults are most vulnerable to fishing. In addition, there is a need for basic biological information on this species (recruitment, growth and longevity, sexual maturity, etc.) and increased monitoring of juvenile and adult populations. Such information is crucial for managers to assess and monitor populations and set fishery regulations that ensure population recovery.

rationale: The Borneo Guitarfish (Rhinobatos borneensis) is a small (to at least 90 cm total length) guitarfish that occurs in the Western Central Pacific in the South China Sea off the north coast of Borneo. It is likely demersal on the insular shelves and its depth is unknown, but like other guitarfishes, is presumably less than 100 m. The species is mainly taken as retained bycatch of industrial and artisanal demersal trawls and gillnets and the meat is consumed locally, and fins of larger individuals are possibly traded. There is a high level of fisheries resource use and increasing fishing pressure across the range of this species. Population reduction is inferred from actual levels of exploitation, as well landings declines of rays of 60–88% consistent with population reductions of 50–79% over the past three generation lengths (27 years). These levels of declines are not species-specific but are informative for understanding the broader levels of guitarfish decline in the region. It is suspected that the Borneo Guitarfish has undergone a population reduction of 50–79% over the past three generation lengths (27 years) due to levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Endangered A2d.
habitat: The Borneo Guitarfish is presumably demersal on the continental shelf and its depth is unknown, but like other guitarfishes, is presumably less than 100 m (Last et al. 2016). It reaches a maximum size of at least 90 cm total length (TL), males mature at 63 cm TL and female size-at-maturity is unknown (Last et al. 2016). Reproduction is presumably lecithotrophic viviparous, but relatively little is known of the biology of the species. There is no information on this species' age-at-maturity and maximum age and hence, generation length was inferred based on data for the Common Guitarfish (Rhinobatos rhinobatos). The Common Guitarfish has an age-at-maturity of four years and a maximum age of 24 years and, thus, a generation length of 14 years (Başusta et al. 2008). The Borneo Guitarfish has a smaller maximum size (90 cm TL) than the Common Guitarfish (162 cm TL), therefore generation length was scaled to be 9 years.
threats:
Globally, guitarfishes are subject to intense fishing pressure on their coastal and shelf habitats that is unregulated across the majority of their distributions. Guitarfishes are captured in industrial, artisanal, and subsistence fisheries with multiple fishing gears, including gillnet, trawl, hook and line, trap, and seine net and are generally retained for their meat, and only the fins of the largest individuals are generally retained (Moore 2017, Jabado 2018). There is a high level of fisheries resource use and increasing fishing pressure across the range of the Borneo Guitarfish, and demersal coastal fisheries resources have been severely depleted in significant areas of the Indo-West Pacific, including India and Southeast Asia (Stobutzki et al. 2006, Mohamed and Veena 2016). In general, fishing effort and the number of fishers has increased in recent decades across the range of this species, with demand for shark and ray product increasing over the same period due to the shark fin trade (Chen 1996, Jabado et al. 2017).

Sharks and rays, including guitarfishes, may be targeted and now heavily exploited across the region by net and trawl fisheries and increasing fishing effort has put significant pressure on all giant guitarfish species in the Indo-West Pacific. The Borneo Guitarfish is likely retained and landed throughout its range and Malaysia a ranks among the top ten shark fishing nations globally (Oakes and Sant 2019).

In Malaysia, fisheries significantly contribute to the national economy through employment opportunities, and protein supply (A. Bin Ali unpubl. data 2020). Fishing effort in Malaysia has been increasing since 1950 across subsistence, artisanal, and industrial fisheries (Pauly et al. 2020). The number of vessels across all sectors has more than doubled from 22,800 vessels in 1950 to 50,150 vessels in 2014 (Pauly et al. 2020). However, the substantial increase over this period has been in engine power which has dramatically increased by ~30 fold (Pauly et al. 2020). Consequently, fisheries were fully exploited by the late 1970s (Teh and Teh 2014). Nevertheless, fish consumption continues to rise and most (~85%) comes from the Malaysian Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) (Fowler et al. 2002, A. Bin Ali unpubl. data 2020). Small-scale inshore fisheries provide the main supply for local consumption. Fisheries operating within 30 nautical miles (nm) from the coast contribute 85% to the total marine fish landings with vessels <70 Gross Tonnage (GT). In waters beyond 30 nm from the coast, trawls and purse seines are the main fishing gears, deployed from large vessels >70 GT. These fisheries have contributed significantly to habitat destruction and reduced abundances of all commercially important fishes in the area (Teh et al. 2009).

There is a large amount of IUU in the Indo-Pacific region with reported catch estimated to represent only 0.9–19.4% of the true catch (Tull 2014). In some areas, including near marine protected areas (MPAs), IUU catch of sharks was estimated to equal 77% of the reported catch, indicating much higher levels of depletion (Varkey et al. 2010). The shallow, inshore soft-bottom habitat preferred by the species is threatened by habitat loss and environmental degradation (Stobutzki et al. 2006, White and Sommerville 2010, Jabado et al. 2017, Moore 2017). In Southeast Asia, there has been an estimated 30% reduction in mangrove area since 1980 (FAO 2007, Polidoro et al. 2010).
population:
There are no species-specific population trend data for this species. Despite the lack of species-specific trend data, landings data from 1950 to 2014 are available on combined whipray species from fisheries within the Malaysian Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) (Pauly et al. 2020). Whiprays live in similar habitat and would have similar catchability to guitarfishes. Although landings data are not a direct measure of abundance, these can be used to infer population reduction where landings have decreased while fishing effort has remained stable or increased. There are two lines of evidence  that can be used to infer population trends including catch reconstructions for Sabah and Sarawak in Borneo.

In Sabah, whipray catches steadily increased from 1950 to 1994. In 1995, whipray catch peaked at ~11,550 t. It has since decreased to just over 6,000 t by 2015, despite the constant effort (Pauly et al. 2020). This level of decline equates to a population reduction of 60% over three generation lengths (27 years) of the Borneo Guitarfish.

In Sarawak, there was a 37.5-fold increase in whipray catches from ~200 t per year in the mid-1960s to ~7,500 t in the mid-1970s. The catch remained high for less than a decade before declining to under 3,000 t per year for 10 years, despite increasing effort. A decline of at least 50% can be inferred through this time. Catch then increased again to over 6,000 t per year, coinciding with a steep increase in effort, peaking at 7,700 t in 1997 before decreasing to ~4,500 t per year since 2004; a 52% decline (Pauly et al. 2020). Overall, in Malaysia, whiprays (and presumably guitarfishes) are suspected to have been reduced by over 50% across all regions in the past 10–20 years. This level of decline equates to a population reduction of 88% over the three generation lengths (27 years) of the Borneo Guitarfish.

This species is only found in a small area that is easily accessible and adjacent to heavily populated areas. Actual levels of exploitation are extremely high across the range of this species; therefore, it is suspected that the Borneo Guitarfish has undergone a population reduction of 50–79% over the last three generation lengths (27 years) due to actual levels of fishing pressure, and it is assessed as Endangered A2d.
range: The Borneo Guitarfish occurs in the Western Central Pacific in the South China Sea off the north coast of Borneo (Last et al. 2016).
useTrade: Guitarfishes are heavily utilized across their range for their meat which is of good quality and is consumed fresh locally, although it also enters the international trade in dried and salted form (e.g. Moore 2017, Jabado 2018). Guitarfish fins are utilised, however, due to their smaller size their value is lower than the value of fins from Giant Guitarfishes or Wedgefishes and fins from smaller individuals are generally discarded. The skin may be traded internationally as a luxury leather product to be made into accessories (e.g. handbags) (Haque et al. 2018).
conservationActions:
No specific measures are in place. In Malaysia there are 51 Marine Protected Areas (MPAs) making up 5,462 km2 that may provide some refuge to this species (CTI 2020).

To conserve the population and to permit recovery, a suite of measures will be required that may include species protection, spatial management, bycatch mitigation, and harvest and trade management measures (including international trade measures). Effective enforcement of measures will require ongoing training and capacity-building (including in the area of species identification). Catch monitoring is needed to help understand population trends and inform management.

rationale: The Indian Sharpnose Ray (Telatrygon crozieri) is a small (to 40 cm disc width) ray occurring in the northern Indian Ocean, in India and Bangladesh, and possibly Pakistan. It is demersal on the inner continental shelf from the surface down to a depth of 50 m. It is captured in shrimp trawl and gillnets and rays tend to be targeted by industrial and artisanal fleets. Species-specific data remain limited due to species misidentifications and recent taxonomic changes. Declines in batoids from intense and increasing fishing has been reported for India, Bangladesh, and Pakistan. This species has not been recorded recently on the west coast of India in regular trawl surveys and this historically widely distributed species now has a much narrower distribution. Even on the east coast (Tamil Nadu to West Bengal) of India, few individuals have been encountered and this number has declined during 2010–2018 surveys and the Indian Sharpnose Ray is now only regularly observed in the east coast from Odisha to West Bengal. The entire geographic range of the species is subject to intense and increasing fishing pressure with little refuge at depth. The steep decline in landings of batoids in India, Bangladesh, and Pakistan is consistent with a population reduction of 54–84% over three generation lengths (26 years). Hence, it is suspected that the Indian Sharpnose Ray has undergone a population reduction of 50–79% over the past three generation lengths (26 years) due to levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Endangered A2cd.
habitat: The Indian Sharpnose Ray is demersal on continental and insular shelves down to depths of 50 m, but typically caught at 20–30 m depth (Last et al. 2016b, K.V. Akhilesh and K.K.
