The 2012 benchmark stock assessment found that the American Eel population is depleted in U.S. waters. The stock is at or near historically low levels due to a combination of historical overfishing, habitat loss, food web alterations, predation, turbine mortality, environmental changes, toxins and contaminants, and disease (ASMFC 2012). Through multiple addendums to the American Eel Fishery Management Plan some  small reductions in mortality across some life stages has been achieved, however, the need for, and extent of, additional quotas and/or reductions on the  glass and yellow eels life stages have not been resolved (ASMFC 2013).

Dam removal and installation of eel ladders along the U.S. portion of the range is now a common restoration strategy, however, strategies to protect downstream migration though hydroelectric facilities are rare. Eel passage is currently being addressed on Conowingo Dam and some eel passage has been provided. Fish passage on other large hydro dams is addressed during the U.S. Federal Energy Regulatory Commission’s licensing or relicensing process. Most states are working to improve upstream eel passage on unregulated dams. A recent study shows that dam removal can increase American Eel abundances in the upstream areas (Hitt et al. 2012).

Increasing spawner escapement is critically important in recovery strategies, particularly involving fishing and turbine mortality, which need to be reduced and mitigated (MacGregor et al. 2013), however, governance remains a major problem for the American Eel and integrated management for this panmictic species is lacking. Another possible mitigation measure involves supplementary stocking. Such stocking programs were undertaken from 2005 to 2010 in the St. Lawrence River system, on the Richelieu River, and in the upper St. Lawrence River and Lake Ontario. The contribution of these stocked eels to the production of silver eels and subsequently to recruitment in the next generation is unknown; however, there were unexpected effects. For example, a study by Pratt and Threader (2011), of the stocking programme in the upper St.Lawrence River system showed strong evidence that stocked eels survived and grew quickly - female stocked eels started to emigrate within four years after stocking at a small size (compared to wild females), similar to the size reported for migrating wild females in their site of original capture in Nova Scotia. This said, a considerable number of the stocked eels became male in an environment where only females had previously been observed (Pratt and Mathers 2011, Pratt and Threader 2011) and the effects of this shift in sex bias and reduced size are unknown. The authors themselves highlight the limitations of this study in the context of the species' range and more long-term data are required to fully determine the effectiveness of stocking programmes. Restocking programmes, while having been shown to increase escapement in some instances, must be carefully planned and executed in river systems that will benefit from an increase in freshwater population. It is obvious that conservation concerns about the status of the American Eel are now considerable and that international cooperation and coordinated management are needed to protect a species that now has substantially reduced habitat and increasing anthropogenic stressors, with greatly reduced abundance and distribution.

rationale: This species is only found in the Amami-oshima and Okinawa islands in Japan. It has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 678 km<sup>2</sup> and an area of occupancy (AOO) of 12 km<sup>2</sup>. There are three locations corresponding to the three subpopulations that are individually threatened by river and coastal development. This development is also leading to a continuing decline in the AOO, the extent and quality of habitat, and population size. Therefore, this species is assessed as Endangered.
habitat: Muddy and sandy bottoms of brackish water areas of river mouths and adjacent shallow coastal waters constitute its preferred habitat.
threats: Population declines are resulting from environmental degradation caused by river and coastal developments, including wetland drainage. Stream channelisation and water pollution have also caused a decline.
population: The number of subpopulations is very limited (three) and the population is in decline (Tachihara 2015).
range: This species is only found in the Amami-oshima and Okinawa islands in Japan. It is the only Acanthogobius species distributed from Amami-oshima southward (Tachihara 2015, Kunishima 2017).
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: No conservation actions are in place for this species.

rationale: This species is endemic to Japan where it occurs in Yamaguchi, Fukuoka and Oita Prefectures. It is extinct in numerous other prefectures. This species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 1,559 km<sup>2</sup> and an area of occupancy (AOO) of 184 km<sup>2</sup>. There are two locations and these correspond to the two remaining spawning sites of the species, which are at threat from coastal development. There are continuing declines in distribution area, habitat extent and quality, the number of subpopulations and the population size as a result of coastal development. Therefore, this species is assessed as Endangered.
habitat: This species heavily depends on tidal flats and requires good quality substrates. It depends on food resources such as bivalves and other benthic invertebrates (Shigeta 2015).
threats: Loss of tidal flat habitats because of coastal development is the primary threat to this species. This leads to a reduction in the abundance of benthic invertebrates that are important to the species as a food resource. Additionally, this causes substrates to become muddy and of too poor quality for the species (Shigeta 2015).
population:
This species has experienced large population declines resulting from stream channelisation and loss of tidal flat habitats during coastal development (Shigeta 2015).

In 1999, 953 mature individuals were caught in Oita Prefecture but in 2011-2012, only 23 mature individuals were caught (Shigeta et al. 2014).
range:
This species is endemic to Japan where it occurs in three prefectures: Yamaguchi, Fukuoka and Oita Prefectures (Shigeta 2015). It is extinct in Tokyo, Kanagawa, Chiba, Aichi, Mie, Wakayama, Tokushima and Kagoshima Prefectures (Shigeta and Osuki 2011).

This species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 1,559 km2 and an area of occupancy (AOO) of 184 km2. There are two locations and these correspond to the two remaining spawning sites of the species, which are at threat from coastal development.
useTrade: This species is used for food and sport fishing (Shigeta 2015).
conservationActions: There are no conservation actions in place for this species.

rationale: This species is assessed as Endangered. It has an area of occupancy (AOO) of 312-400 km<sup>2</sup>, occurs in five locations based on the threat of drought and associated habitat loss and degradation, and there is projected continuing decline in its habitat.
habitat:
The Australian Mudfish is a nocturnal and cryptic (hiding within dense habitat) species occupying freshwater habitats which are typically semi-permanent, shallow and often-muddy with dense vegetation. It is capable of burrowing into mud or sheltering in moist substrates under rocks or debris helping it to tolerate partial or full drying of habitat (Fulton 1986, Koehn and Raadik 1991). This ability to survive without surface water for a short period is known as aestivation, and is one of several physical and ecological adaptations ‘Mudfish’ as a group have developed to adapt to life in harsh swampy conditions (Waters and McDowall 2005). 

It is the only member of the genus that is considered amphidromous (McDowall 2010) but it always facultative as some populations occur in landlocked systems or without obvious indication of migrations (Andrew 1991, Hammer et al. 2011, Koehn and Raadik 1991). Its amphidromous movements involve spawning late in winter with newly hatched larvae washed downstream and spend their first two to three months at sea or in estuaries. The 'whitebait' juveniles migrate upstream from estuaries into freshwater habitats.
threats: The species is threatened by the loss of suitable wetland habitat across its range due to water availability and drainage and clearing of swamps and development. Stock access is a threat and can result in habitat degradation (and the loss of aquatic vegetation). Barriers to hydrological connectivity impact its movement patterns. Introduction of alien species such as Brown Trout (Salmo trutta), Rainbow Trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss) and Redfin Perch (Perca fluviatilis), and application of herbicides and fertilisers may cause a significant threat to the health of habitat and continuation of species (Koehn and Raadik 1991, DELWP 2003). The overriding influence of climate change will strongly impact this species.
population: The status of the species across its range is largely unknown. Whilst still occurring broadly across Tasmania and Victoria, there is insufficient understanding of changes over time. In South Australia, it appears stable across the two altered drain systems within some wetland habitat that occurs (Hammer et al. 2010, Veale and Whiterod unpublished data), with it considered extinct from the historical record locality (Bool Lagoon).
range: This species occurs across southern Australia, from the coastal habitats of Tasmania, Flinders Island, southern Victoria from Wilsons Promontory and the Otway Ranges and two drain catchments (lower Drain M/Sutherland Drain and Drain L/Lake Hawdon/Bray Drain) from south-eastern South Australia.
useTrade: This species is not used.
conservationActions: This species is listed as Threatened under the Victorian Flora and Fauna Guarantee Act (1988) and as Critically Endangered in Victoria under the Advisory List of Threatened Vertebrate Fauna (DSE 2013). In South Australia, it is considered Critically Endangered (Hammer et al. 2009). Protection and enhancement of its swampy seasonal vegetated habitats is recommended but through consideration of water and inundation regimes and protection of aquatic vegetation. Given its amphidromy addressing barriers to movement to allow hydrological connectivity is important. A greater understanding of the status of the species is required.

rationale: This shallow, demersal species is relatively poorly known and is inferred to be restricted to a small area in southeastern Tasmania, Australia. The estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 1,262 km2 and area of occupancy (AOO) is 12 km2. The three subpopulations from which it is known are considered severely fragmented due to the low dispersal capabilities of this species. Extensive surveys targeting handfish species have been carried out throughout this area in the shallow habitats that this species occupies, but no individuals have been found, and the last record was confirmed in 1999. Other better-known, shallow handfish species that are endemic to this same area are highly restricted in range and have experienced documented serious declines. Serious impacts from historical scallop dredging that took this species as bycatch and destroyed habitat are likely to have occurred. Therefore, it is listed as Endangered B1ab(v)+2ab(v). Further research and monitoring is needed on the population trends and biology of this species.
habitat: This demersal species inhabits shallow, inshore soft bottoms probably near or on hard substrates (rocky/rubble) amongst thick coverage of macroinvertebrates (R. Stuart-Smith and P. Last pers. comm. 2018). Its maximum total length is 13.6 cm (Last and Gledhill 2009). Handfish species do not have a pelagic larval stage, and dispersal of propagules is very limited (Edgar et al. 2017). Females lay small clusters of large eggs attached to the substrate by filaments and some level of parental care is provided until they hatch (Last and Gledhill 2009).
threats: Other shallow handfish species (e.g., Brachionichthys hirsutus) that occur in the same region as this species have experienced significant population declines due to their very limited dispersal capabilities, small subpopulations and impacts from invasive species, impacts from historical scallop dredging, habitat loss and pollution (Edgar et al. 2017). A large scallop fishery that was active in southeastern Tasmania from the 1800s until its collapse in the D'Entrecasteaux Channel by 1967 probably caused population declines due to habitat destruction and direct take of individuals as bycatch (Edgar and Samson 2004, Last and Gledhill 2009, R. Stuart-Smith and P. Last pers. comm. 2018).
population: This species is known from only five specimens, the most recent record is from 1999 and it has not been observed for the past 20 years despite considerable sampling effort by commercial, recreational and scientific entities across its known range (Last and Gledhill 2009, Edgar et al. 2017). Due to their low dispersal capabilities and relatively low reproductive rate, handfish species occur in isolated subpopulations (T. Lynch pers. comm. 2018); therefore, this species is considered severely fragmented since more than half of the individuals are in small and isolated patches. In recent decades, extensive underwater surveys targeting shallow handfish species have been carried out across south and eastern Tasmania, but no individuals of this species were found (Edgar et al. 2017). For example, a total of 100 hours were spent by 19 experienced divers at 22 sites across southern Tasmania from February to June 2015 to specifically search for Ziebell’s Handfish (Brachiopsilus ziebelli) and the Red Handfish (Thymichthys politus), which are similar in ecology and distribution to this species (Edgar et al. 2015, Edgar et al. 2017). Survey work was repeated in 2017 and 2018 off the Tasman Peninsula, but no individuals were recorded (R. Stuart-Smith pers. comm. 2018). Based on well-documented declines in the Red Handfish, Ziebell's Handfish and the Spotted Handfish, it is inferred that this species has also undergone declines in the number of mature individuals (Last and Gledhill 2009, Edgar et al. 2017).
range: This species is distributed in southeastern Tasmania, Australia from three localities: the Tasman Peninsula, the mouth of the Huon River and off Dennes Point in the D'Entrecasteaux Channel. Its depth range is about 15-38 metres (Last and Gledhill 2009). Many handfish species have highly restricted ranges and subpopulations are severely fragmented due to their low dispersal capabilities; therefore, despite being known from a low number of records, it is inferred that this species is restricted to this area of southeastern Tasmania. Based on a minimum bounding polygon drawn around the three known points, the extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated as 1,262 km2. Since handfish subpopulations are typically restricted to areas less than 100 metres in diameter (Edgar et al. 2015, Edgar et al. 2017), the area of occupancy (AOO) is estimated as the area of three 2 x 2 km grid cells, which is 12 km2.
useTrade: This species is not utilized. It was taken as bycatch in the historical scallop fishery and may also be caught in lobster traps currently (R. Stuart-Smith and P. Last pers. comm. 2018).
conservationActions: There are no protected areas or species-specific conservation measures. Further research is urgently needed on this species, as little is known on its biology, distribution and population, and there is a high potential that declines may have occurred similar to other handfish species (Last and Gledhill 2009, Edgar et al. 2017).

rationale: This demersal, deep-living species is relatively poorly known. It occurs in at least five subpopulations in a small area off New South Wales and Victoria, Australia and was last recorded in 1996 (about 22 years ago). The estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 6,791 km2. The area of occupancy (AOO) is estimated at a minimum of 20 km2, and is highly unlikely to exceed 500 km2. Its global population is severely fragmented due to the species' low dispersal capability and serious impacts from trawl and dredge fisheries that are active within its range are likely to have occurred. Other better-known, shallow handfish species that are endemic to this same area are highly restricted in range and have experienced documented serious declines. This species qualifies for Vulnerable under Criterion B1 and Endangered under Criterion B2, and is therefore listed as Endangered B2ab(iii,v). Further research and monitoring is needed on the population trends and biology of this species.
habitat: This demersal species inhabits relatively deep depths on the outer continental shelf where it probably occurs amongst macroinvertebrates (P. Last pers. comm. 2018). It may have special habitat requirements given its rarity and narrow distribution. Its maximum known total length is 6 cm (Last and Gledhill 2009). Handfish species do not have a pelagic larval stage, and dispersal of propagules is very limited (Edgar et al. 2017). Females lay small clusters of large eggs attached to the substrate by filaments and some level of parental care is provided until they hatch (Last and Gledhill 2009).
threats: It is likely that the prolonged trawl and dredge effort within the range of this species has caused both habitat destruction and direct mortality (Last and Gledhill 2009, P. Last pers. comm. 2018). Other handfish species (e.g., Brachionichthys hirsutus) have experienced significant population declines due to their very limited dispersal capabilities, small subpopulations and impacts from invasive species, habitat loss and pollution (Edgar et al. 2017).
population: This species is known from only seven specimens taken in 1983 and 1996. It has not been observed since despite considerable sampling effort by commercial, recreational and scientific entities (Last and Gledhill 2009, Edgar et al. 2017). As very few specimens have either been caught or observed, its population status is poorly understood. Due to their low dispersal capabilities and relatively low reproductive rate, handfish species occur in isolated subpopulations (T. Lynch pers. comm. 2018); therefore, this species is considered severely fragmented since more than half of the individuals are in small and isolated patches. Trawl and dredge fisheries that are active within its range are likely to be impacting this species, and this activity could easily extirpate subpopulations very rapidly (P. Last pers. comm. 2018). Based on well-documented declines in the Red Handfish (Thymichthys politus), Ziebell's Handfish (Brachiopsilus ziebelli) and the Spotted Handfish (Brachionichthys hirsutus), which are similar in ecology and distribution to this species, it is inferred that this species has also undergone declines in the number of mature individuals (Last and Gledhill 2009, Edgar et al. 2017).
range: This species is patchily distributed in southeastern Australia from New South Wales and Victoria. Specimens have been collected from five localities: east of Bermagui, New South Wales, east of Disaster Bay, New South Wales, north-east of Eden, New South Wales, east of Mallacoota, Victoria and off Cape Conran, Bass Strait, Victoria. Specimens have been taken between 74-121 metres (Last and Gledhill 2009). Many handfish species have highly restricted ranges and subpopulations are severely fragmented due to their low dispersal capabilities; therefore, despite being known from a low number of records, it is inferred that this species is restricted to this area of southeastern Australia. Based on a minimum bounding polygon drawn around these points, the extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated as 6,791 km2. Since handfish subpopulations are typically restricted to areas less than 100 metres in diameter (Edgar et al. 2015, Edgar et al. 2017), the minimum area of occupancy (AOO) is estimated as the area of five 2 x 2 km grid cells, which is 20 km2, and the maximum is highly unlikely to exceed 500 km2.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no protected areas or species-specific conservation measures. Further research is urgently needed on this species, as little is known on its biology and population (Last and Gledhill 2009, Edgar et al. 2017). A comprehensive survey of the Bass Strait is needed to clarify the status of this and other deep-living handfish species (P. Last pers. comm. 2019).

rationale: This demersal, deep-living species is relatively poorly known. It occurs in at least two subpopulations in a small area off Victoria, Australia and was last recorded in 1996 (about 22 years ago). The estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,388 km2. The estimated area of occupancy (AOO) is 8 km2, and is highly unlikely to exceed 500 km2.  Its global population is severely fragmented due to the species' low dispersal capability and serious impacts from trawl and dredge fisheries that are active within its range are likely to have occurred. Other better-known, shallow handfish species that are endemic to this same area are highly restricted in range and have experienced documented serious declines. This species qualifies for Endangered under Criterion B1 and B2, and is therefore listed as Endangered B2ab(iii,v). Further research and monitoring is needed on the population trends and biology of this species.
habitat: This demersal species inhabits relatively deep depths on the outer continental shelf and upper slope where it probably occurs amongst macroinvertebrates (P. Last pers. comm. 2018). It may have special habitat requirements given its rarity and narrow distribution. Its maximum known total length is 5.8 cm (Last and Gledhill 2009). Handfish species do not have a pelagic larval stage, and dispersal of propagules is very limited (Edgar et al. 2017). Females lay small clusters of large eggs attached to the substrate by filaments and some level of parental care is provided until they hatch (Last and Gledhill 2009).
threats: It is likely that the prolonged trawl and dredge effort within the range of this species has caused both habitat destruction and direct mortality (Last and Gledhill 2009, P. Last pers. comm. 2018). Other handfish species (e.g., Brachionichthys hirsutus) have experienced significant population declines due to their very limited dispersal capabilities, small subpopulations and impacts from invasive species, habitat loss and pollution (Edgar et al. 2017).
population: This species is known from only two specimens taken in 1984 and 1996. It has not been observed since despite considerable sampling effort by commercial, recreational and scientific entities (Last and Gledhill 2009, Edgar et al. 2017). Rather than biases due to lack of sampling, the paucity of records is possibly due to natural rarity and a patchy distribution (Last and Gledhill 2009). As very few specimens have either been caught or observed, its population status is poorly understood. Due to their low dispersal capabilities and relatively low reproductive rate, handfish species occur in isolated subpopulations (T. Lynch pers. comm. 2018); therefore, this species is considered severely fragmented since more than half of the individuals are in small and isolated patches. Trawl and dredge fisheries that are active within its range are likely to be impacting this species, and this activity could easily extirpate subpopulations very rapidly (P. Last pers. comm. 2018). Based on well-documented declines in the Red Handfish (Thymichthys politus), Ziebell's Handfish (Brachiopsilus ziebelli) and the Spotted Handfish (Brachionichthys hirsutus), which are similar in ecology and distribution to this species, it is inferred that this species has also undergone declines in the number of mature individuals (Last and Gledhill 2009, Edgar et al. 2017).
range: This species is known from only two localities in southeastern Victoria, Australia: south of Cape Everard, Victoria and south-east of Lakes Entrance, Bass Strait, Victoria. Specimens have been taken between 112-218 metres (Last and Gledhill 2009). Many handfish species have highly restricted ranges and subpopulations are severely fragmented due to their low dispersal capabilities; therefore, despite being known from a low number of records, it is inferred that this species is restricted to this area of southeastern Australia. Based on a minimum bounding polygon drawn around these points, the extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated as 2,388 km2. Since handfish subpopulations are typically restricted to areas less than 100 metres in diameter (Edgar et al. 2015, Edgar et al. 2017), the minimum area of occupancy (AOO) is estimated as the area of two 2 x 2 km grid cells, which is 8 km2, and the maximum is highly unlikely to exceed 500 km2.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no protected areas or species-specific conservation measures. Further research is urgently needed on this species, as little is known on its biology and population (Last and Gledhill 2009, Edgar et al. 2017). A comprehensive survey of the Bass Strait is needed to clarify the status of this and other deep-living handfish species (P. Last pers. comm. 2019).

rationale: This demersal, deep-living species is relatively poorly known. It occurs in at least five subpopulations in a small area off southeastern Australia and was last recorded in 2003 (about 15 years ago). The estimated extent of occurrence (EOO) is 25,394 km2. The area of occupancy (AOO) is estimated at a minimum of 20 km2, and is highly unlikely to exceed 500 km2. Its global population is severely fragmented due to the species' low dispersal capability and serious impacts from trawl and dredge fisheries that are active within its range are likely to have occurred. Other better-known, shallow handfish species that are endemic to this same area are highly restricted in range and have experienced documented serious declines. The low numbers of individuals collected and insufficient sampling of the area and depth in which this species occurs introduces a not insignificant level of uncertainty to this assessment; however, given the known major threat from active bottom trawl fisheries combined with its inferred intrinsic susceptibility to declines, Data Deficient is not the most appropriate category. This species qualifies for Near Threatened under Criterion B1 and Endangered under Criterion B2, and is therefore listed as Endangered B2ab(iii,v). Further research and monitoring is needed on the population trends and biology of this species.
habitat: This demersal species has been captured using benthic sleds or demersal trawls at a relatively deep depth on the outer continental shelf and upper slope where it likely occurs amongst macroinvertebrates (P. Last pers. comm. 2018). Little is known on its specific habitat preferences or biology. The largest specimen is 6.1 cm total length (Last and Gledhill 2009). Handfish species do not have a pelagic larval stage, and dispersal of propagules is very limited (Edgar et al. 2017). Females lay small clusters of large eggs attached to the substrate by filaments and some level of parental care is provided until they hatch (Last and Gledhill 2009).
threats: It is likely that the prolonged trawl and dredge effort within the range of this species has caused both habitat destruction and direct mortality (Last and Gledhill 2009, P. Last pers. comm. 2018). Other handfish species (e.g., Brachionichthys hirsutus) have experienced significant population declines due to their very limited dispersal capabilities, small subpopulations and impacts from invasive species, habitat loss and pollution (Edgar et al. 2017).
population: This species is only known from five specimens that were taken in 1984, 1994, 1996 and 2003 (Last and Gledhill 2009). As very few specimens have either been caught or observed, its population status is poorly understood. Due to their low dispersal capabilities and relatively low reproductive rate, handfish species occur in isolated subpopulations (T. Lynch pers. comm. 2018); therefore, this species is considered severely fragmented since more than half of the individuals are in small and isolated patches. Trawl and dredge fisheries that are active within its range are likely impacting this species, and this activity could easily extirpate subpopulations very rapidly (P. Last pers. comm. 2018). Based on well-documented declines in the Red Handfish (Thymichthys politus), Ziebell's Handfish (Brachiopsilus ziebelli) and the Spotted Handfish (Brachionichthys hirsutus), which are similar in ecology and distribution to this species, it is inferred that this species has also undergone declines in the number of mature individuals (Last and Gledhill 2009, Edgar et al. 2017).
range: This species is known from five localities in southeastern Australia: east of Cape Howe, New South Wales, south-east of Lakes Entrance, eastern Bass Strait, Victoria, south of Gabo Island, Victoria and south-east of Cape Barren Island, Bass Strait, Tasmania. Its depth range is 125–211 metres, but it possibly occurs shallower (Last and Gledhill 2009). Many handfish species have highly restricted ranges and subpopulations are severely fragmented due to their low dispersal capabilities; therefore, despite being known from a low number of records, it is inferred that this species is restricted to this area of southeastern Australia. Based on a minimum bounding polygon drawn around these points, the extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated as 25,394 km2. Since handfish subpopulations are typically restricted to areas less than 100 metres in diameter (Edgar et al. 2015, Edgar et al. 2017), the minimum area of occupancy (AOO) is estimated as the area of five 2 x 2 km grid cells, which is 20 km2, and the maximum is highly unlikely to exceed 500 km2.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no protected areas or species-specific conservation measures. Further research is urgently needed on this species, as little is known on its biology and population (Last and Gledhill 2009, Edgar et al. 2017). A comprehensive survey of the Bass Strait is needed to clarify the status of this and other deep-living handfish species (P. Last pers. comm. 2019).

rationale: This nominal species is known from two localities: a single lake on the southwestern coast of India and a record from 1876 from the backwaters of Madras (Chennai), but it is not known if the habitat is still present there. This species has a very specific habitat, which has been highly degraded from a range of anthropogenic activities. As it only occurs in estuaries of southern India, most of which have been modified and/or polluted, the AOO is likely to be less than 500 km<sup>2</sup>. Given that the AOO is estimated to be less than 500 km<sup>2</sup>, it is known from two locations and is experiencing extensive, continuing habitat degradation, it is listed as Endangered under Criterion B2ab(iii).
habitat: The type locality is an estuary in southwestern India. The largest specimen measured 5.9 cm standard length (Geevarghese and John 1982). This species seems to have a specific habitat type, as it was described from a meso-oligohaline lake near Trivandrum, in fresh and brackish waters.
threats: Species-specific information is limited. However, the type locality (Veli estuary, Kerala, India) is prone to large amounts of pollution (Harikumar and Nasir 2010). Many estuaries, lagoons and near-shore marine and freshwater habitats near Madras and in southern India, where this species has been found, are severely degraded with reports of major decline in species-richness of waterbirds in the Pichavaram mangrove wetlands, southern India as a result (Sandilyan et al. 2010).
population: This species is known from the ten type specimens (Geervarghese and John 1982) and a record from Madras (Day 1878). No additional population information is available.
range: This species is only known from two localities: the Veli estuary, Trivandrum, Kerala, India (Geevarghese and John 1982) and off Madras (Chennai), Tamil Nadu, India (Day 1878, Jaafar 2008). Based on the length of the coastline between its two known localities, the AOO could be as high as 4,072 km<sup>2</sup>; however, as it is known from only two localities and its preferred estuarine habitats occupy a relatively small proportion of India’s coast, the AOO is likely to be less than 500 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures are in place.

rationale: This species is only known from shallow waters off the coast of Eliat, Israel in the Red Sea. Given its shallow depth range and limited distribution, it has an estimated area of occupancy of less than 20 km2; however, since this species is only confirmed from a single specimen and is a cryptic species, a slightly broader range was used that includes a narrow distribution along the coast of the Gulf of Aqaba, making AOO = 1,304 km2 and EOO = 4,130 km2. Given that this species is only known from one location, has experienced habitat degradation from pollution and habitat alteration, and has an EOO of less than 5,000 km2, it is listed as Endangered under criterion B1ab(iii). However, because this is a cryptic species and is active only at night, it may have a wider distribution than currently known which may extend its AOO and EOO. If this is the case, then it should be reassessed and potentially placed into a lower threat category.
habitat: Callogobius amikami is a marine species that inhabits the rocky outcrops of coral reefs (Delventhal et al. 2016). The maximum recorded total length (TL) for this species is 3.9 cm (Randall 1995). It is more active at night.
threats: This species has only been recorded in shallow waters off the coast of Eliat, which has been impacted by pollution and habitat degradation from a number of sources, including tourism and fish-rearing cages along the north beach of Eliat (Al-Rousan et al. 2016, Chaidez et al. 2017, Mohamed 2018).
population: Population data are not available for this species.
range: Callogobius amikami is a western Indian Ocean species known only in the Red Sea from Eilat, Israel (Al-Jufaili et al. 2010, Golani and Bogorodsky 2010, Delventhal et al. 2016). Reports from the East coast of Somalia, the Socotra Archipelago, and Muscat, Oman need further verification, since it is often confused with C. dori (Randall 1995, Zajonz et al. 2000, Manilo and Bogorodsky 2003, Delventhal et al. 2016). It is found at depths ranging from 4 to 10 m (Manilo and Bogorodsky 2003, Delventhal et al. 2016). The AOO for this species is estimated to be 1,304 km2 and EOO = 4,130 km2.
useTrade: Use and trade information is not available for this species.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures for C. amikami; however, its range overlaps with a number of marine protected areas such as the Eilat Coral Beach Nature Reserve, Israel (Karplus and Thompson 2011, IUCN and UNEP-WCMC 2017).

rationale: Drombus dentifer is only known from Lake Chilika in India, which has an area of approximately 1,100 km2. There is no population information, and little information on habitat and ecology available. This species' habitat in Chilika Lake is impacted by a number of threats including siltation, shrinkage, pollution, fish farming, decrease in salinity, loss of biodiversity, and invasive species. Given that the extent of occurrence for this species is less than 5,000 km2, it is known from fewer than 5 locations, and is experiencing a continuing loss of habitat, it is listed as Endangered under Criterion B1ab(iii).
habitat: This species is only known from Chilika Lake, which is a brackish water lagoon (Larson et al. 2013). There is little habitat and ecology information available for this species.
threats: This species' habitat in Chilika Lake is impacted by a number of threats including siltation, shrinkage, pollution, fish farming, decrease in salinity, loss of biodiversity, and invasive species (Nayak et al. 2004, Pattanaik 2007, Sahu et al. 2014).
population: Population information is not available for this species.
range: Drombus dentifer is only known from 8 specimens collected from Chilika Lake, India (Hora 1923). Chilika Lake is a brackish water lagoon, spread over the Puri, Khurda and Ganjam districts of Odisha state on the east coast of India, at the mouth of the Daya River, flowing into the Bay of Bengal, covering an area of over 1,100 km². The record from the Northern Territory, Australia (accessed via the FishNet2 portal, www.fishnet2.net) needs verification (H. Larson pers. comm. 2018).
useTrade: There is no use and trade information available at this time.
conservationActions: There are no known species-specific conservation measures; however, Chilika Lake is on the Ramsar list of important wetlands.

rationale: The Happy Eddie (Haploblepharus edwardsii) is a small (to 64 cm total length) catshark endemic to South Africa in the Southeast Atlantic and Western Indian Oceans, occurring from Langebaan Lagoon, Western Cape, to Algoa Bay, Eastern Cape. This species inhabits rocky reefs, kelp forests, sandy substrates, and the upper continental slope to a depth of 288 m. Little is known of its biology. The Happy Eddie is bycatch in a range of fisheries including beach seine, gillnet, trawl, recreational and commercial line, rock lobster, and demersal shark longline. Trend analyses of research trawl data in South African commercially fished areas and of angler surveys in the De Hoop Marine Protected Area, estimated population reductions of 88–97% over three generation lengths (60 years), with the highest probability of >80% reduction over three generation lengths. The reduction in research trawls is partly driven by a steep decline in catches during the early 1990s when fishing pressure in South Africa was substantially higher. Climate change likely contributed to a range shift away from the research trawl grounds that may account for some of the estimated population reduction but that also likely represents a loss of habitat for the Happy Eddie. Balancing these factors, it is suspected that the Happy Eddie has undergone a population reduction of 50–79% over the past three generation lengths (60 years), and it is assessed as Endangered A2bcd.
habitat: The Happy Eddie is demersal on rocky reefs, in kelp forests, over sandy substrates, and on the upper continental slope to a depth of 288 m, though mostly at depths of 30–90 m (Human 2007, Ebert et al. 2013, Weigmann 2016). The preferred depth range and habitat of this species varies across its distribution; in the west, it occurs from the intertidal to 30 m in kelp forests and rocky reefs (K. Gledhill, unpubl. data, 2018), whereas in the east, it is found predominantly deeper on sandy habitat (Bass et al. 1975, Human 2007). The Happy Eddie reaches a maximum size of 64 cm total length (TL); males and females mature at 37 cm TL (Human 2007, Ebert et al. 2013, Weigmann 2016). Reproduction is oviparous with egg cases laid in pairs, reproductive periodicity is unknown, and size-at-birth of 9.3 cm TL (Bertolini 1993). Age-at-maturity and maximum age are unknown. Catsharks are difficult to age and the most reliable age estimates to date are from the Blacktip Sawtail Catshark (Galeus sauteri) that has an age-at-maturity of 9 years and maximum age of 21 years, resulting in a generation length of 15 years (Liu et al. 2011). The Blacktip Sawtail Catshark is smaller than the Happy Eddie (48 cm vs 64 cm TL) and thus based on scaled-size, the generation length is inferred as 20 years for the Happy Eddie.
threats: The Happy Eddie is bycatch of a range of fisheries, including beach seine, gillnet, trawl, recreational and commercial line, rock lobster, and demersal shark longlines (da Silva et al. 2015). This species has a greater likelihood of capture in line fisheries compared to some other catsharks because it tends to take large hooks. Fisheries operate throughout its range, but trawl fishery effort in South Africa has decreased substantially over the past two decades (S. Fennessy, pers. comm., 20 April 2018). Recreational and rock lobster fishers consider the species a nuisance and persecute them as such, likely causing high mortality (Human 2009). When discarded from other fisheries, post-release mortality is likely low, based on generally very low at-vessel and post-release mortality for catsharks (Ellis et al. 2017). The Happy Eddie has tended to move southward within South Africa over three decades from 1981–2016, with a possible concurrent loss of area occupied (Currie et al. 2019). The range shift is likely at least partially related to climate change (Rouault et al. 2010, Blamey et al. 2015). The hatching rate of egg cases is temperature specific and potentially sensitive to climate change (M. McCord, unpubl. data, 2018).
population:
There are no estimates of population size for the Happy Eddie. Population trend data are available from two sources: (1) annual density estimates from South Africa (Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries (DAFF), unpubl. data, 2018); and (2) number of fish per angler per day from surveys in the De Hoop Marine Protected Area (MPA), South Africa (Department of Environmental Affairs (DEA), unpubl. data, 2018). The trend data from each source were analysed over three generation lengths using a Bayesian state-space framework (Winker and Sherley 2019). This analysis yields an annual rate of change, a median change over three generation lengths, and the probability of the most likely IUCN Red List category percent change over three generations (see the Supplementary Information).

First, the annual density estimates (kg per nm² area swept) were available from demersal research trawl surveys conducted over 26 years (1991–2016) in fished areas of South Africa during autumn and spring along the south coast by the Fisheries Branch of the South African Department of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries (DAFF, unpubl. data, 2018). The trend analysis revealed an annual rate of reduction of 3.4%, consistent with a median reduction of 87.7% over three past generation lengths (60 years), with the highest probability (64.9%) of >80% reduction over three generation lengths. The estimated reduction is driven partly by a steep decline in catch rates during the early 1990s when fishing pressure in South Africa was substantially higher; over the last two decades the population reduction has been less dramatic. Some of the reduction is possibly a result of a geographic shift in abundance away from the trawl grounds due to climate change (Currie et al. 2019). The southward range shift also likely represents a loss of habitat for the Happy Eddie.

Second, the number of fish per angler per day for 1996–2017 (22 years) were available from the De Hoop MPA shore-based research angling surveys conducted by the South African Department of Environmental Affairs (DEA, unpubl. data, 2018). The abundance of the species fluctuated considerably over the 22 years. The trend analysis revealed an annual rate of reduction of 6.6%, consistent with a median reduction of 96.5% over three past generation lengths (60 years), with the highest probability (93.2%) of >80% reduction over three generation lengths. The De Hoop MPA was established in 1985 and is a no-take reserve, and this may not be representative of the population trends in fished areas of South Africa.

Overall, due to an estimated population reduction over most of its range, combined with a substantial reduction in fishing effort in South Africa and a suspected range shift due to climate change that could account for some of the estimated reduction but also likely represents a decline in area of occupancy, it is suspected that this species has undergone a population reduction of 50–79% over the past three generation lengths (60 years).
range: The Happy Eddie is endemic to South Africa in the Southeast Atlantic and Western Indian Oceans where it occurs from Langebaan Lagoon, Western Cape, to Algoa Bay, Eastern Cape (Human 2007, Ebert et al. 2013).
useTrade: The utilization of the Happy Eddie is unknown.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific protections or conservation measures in place for this species at present. Recreational anglers in South Africa are restricted to one shark per species per day (maximum of 10 individuals per day) (da Silva et al. 2015), although enforcement is an ongoing issue. Further research is needed on population size and trends, and life history, and catch rates should be monitored.

rationale:
The Common Smoothhound (Mustelus mustelus) is a medium-sized (to 176 cm total length) shark that occurs in the Mediterranean Sea, east Atlantic Ocean and Western Indian Ocean ranging from Portugal to the east coast of South Africa. It occurs in shallow coastal waters and on the continental shelf and slope at depths of 5–438 m, but is more commonly found in shallow waters at depths of 5–50 m. The species is taken as targeted and incidental catch in demersal trawl, line gear, set net, and trammel net fisheries across its range. It is retained for human consumption and is widely marketed as fresh, dried-salted, or dried and smoked meat while fins enter the international trade.

Little species-specific fisheries catch data are available across most of its range because of frequent misidentifications with other smoothhounds (Mustelus spp.) with overlapping distributions. There is a high level of fisheries resource use and increasing fishing pressure across its range. Both catch and fishery-independent scientific survey data available from the Mediterranean Sea suggest that significant declines have occurred. Trend analyses of relative abundance and stock biomass in Mauritania and South Africa, respectively, reveal population reductions of >80% and >50%, respectively over the past three generation lengths (53 years). Across the rest of its range, this species is still landed in relatively large quantities compared to other shark species but declining catch-per-unit-effort has been reported (e.g., Gabon). Overall, there is limited species-specific reporting, as well as a lack of species-specific time-series data from the remaining range of the species. However, considering general declining catch trends and limited number of specimens recorded in fisheries surveys in several localities, the level of intense and large unmanaged fisheries that operate throughout its range, its limited refuge at depth, its susceptibility to fisheries, and noted declines in other sharks, it is suspected that the Common Smoothhound has undergone a population reduction of 50–79% over the past three generation lengths (53 years) based on abundance data and actual levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Endangered A2bd.
habitat: The Common Smoothhound occurs on sandy and muddy substrates on the continental shelf and slope at depths of 5–438 m, but is more commonly found in shallow waters from 5–50 m (Ebert et al. 2013, Carpenter and De Angelis 2016, Pascual-Alayon et al. 2017). It reaches a maximum size of 176 cm total length (TL), males mature at 70–112 cm TL and females mature at 107–124 cm TL (da Silva 2018, Saïdi et al. 2008, Carpenter and De Angelis 2016). Reproduction is placentotrophic viviparous with litter sizes of 1–25 pups, a gestation period of 7–12 months, and size-at-birth of 24–45 cm TL (da Silva 2018, Saïdi et al. 2008, Carpenter and De Angelis 2016). The Common Smoothhound has an age-at-maturity of 10.75 years and a maximum age of 25 years, resulting in a generation length of 17.8 years (Goosen and Smale 1997, da Silva 2007).
threats:
The Common Smoothhound is targeted and taken as incidental catch in industrial and artisanal fisheries with multiple fishing gears including demersal trawl, line gear, gillnet, set nets, tangle nets, and trammel nets, and is retained for human consumption (Fischer et al. 1987). In the Mediterranean Sea, there is a high level of exploitation on the continental shelf and upper slope to about 800 m depth (Massuti and Moranta 2003, Ferretti et al. 2005, Colloca et al. 2017). This water body has been subject to extensive and intensive fishing across much of the species' known depth and spatial distribution with trawl fisheries operating over a wide bathymetric range (50–800 m) and targeting a variety of species (Lleonart and Maynou 2003, Tsikliras et al. 2015). Semi-industrial fisheries in the Adriatic Sea, off Sicily, Spain and Cyprus are known to take Mustelus spp., and also artisanal fisheries elsewhere (Colloca et al. 2017). Following two centuries of fisheries development, shark and ray fisheries developed in the 1950s, with catches peaking until the 1970s, after which a decreasing trend was reported along with a decline in diversity of species (Cavanagh and Gibson 2007, Davidson et al. 2016). A number of shark and ray species are now considered to be locally extinct due to overexploitation (e.g., Ferretti et al. 2008). 

In the Eastern Central Atlantic, sharks and rays were already being exploited by semi-industrial fisheries in the 1950s (Walker et al. 2005). While these fisheries gradually collapsed, the demand for dried salted shark meat (for export to Ghana) and shark fins in the 1980s drove the development of artisanal targeted shark fishing across much of the region (Diop and Dossa 2011, CCLME 2016, Seto et al. 2017, Moore et al. 2019). Over the years, this has expanded into targeted shark and ray fisheries across many countries and is likely increasing fishing pressure on this species (Walker et al. 2005, Diop and Dossa 2011). Furthermore, this has led to population reductions of many species of sharks and rays including the local extinction of sawfishes (family Pristidae) from West African coastal waters and several species of wedgefishes from their northern range in Mauritania and Senegal (Walker et al. 2005, Fernandez-Carvalho et al. 2014, Kyne et al. 2020). Sharks and rays are still targeted in a number of countries with artisanal fishers using drift gillnets and demersal set gillnets with large mesh sizes (e.g., Mauritania, Nigeria, Ghana, Cameroon; M. Diop, I. Seidu, A. Tamo, and A.B. Williams unpubl. data 2020). 

In general, fishing effort and the number of fishers has intensified in recent decades across most of the range of this species. In West Africa, reports indicate that the diversity and average body size of many important commercial coastal, demersal, and pelagic fishery species have markedly declined with many stocks now considered to be overexploited (Ajayi 1994, Srinivasan et al. 2012, CCLME 2016, Polidoro et al. 2016). Trawl surveys carried out across the Gulf of Guinea from 1977­–2000 showed a decline in fish biomass of demersal resources and deep sea pelagic catches of approximately 50% (Brashares et al. 2004). Further, in Mauritania, the total demersal biomass of inshore stocks is estimated to have declined by 75% since 1982 (Meissa and Gascuel 2015). The direct cause of decline for many of these stocks has been attributed to overcapacity within both the industrial and artisanal fisheries in addition to destructive fishing practices (GCLME 2006, CCLME 2016). Overall, between 1950–2010, the total artisanal fishing effort increased by 10-fold with an estimated 252,000 unregulated artisanal and 3,300 industrial vessels operating in this region by 2010 (mostly distant water fleets from Europe and East Asia operating under ‘access agreements’ that take sharks and rays as bycatch) (Walker et al. 2005, Diop and Dossa 2011, Belhabib et al. 2018).

In the southeast Atlantic, the Common Smoothhood is also targeted or captured as bycatch. Since 2002, artisanal and recreational fishing pressure in a few parts of southern Angola has increased while other areas remain unfished (Beckensteiner et al. 2016). The species is also taken by recreational anglers off Namibia (NATMIRC 2003). However, parts of Namibia are remote and may offer refuge from fishing pressure (Belhabib et al. 2015). In South Africa, declines in linefish species has led to increased exploitation of demersal sharks, such as the Common Smoothhound as both target and bycatch. Fisheries catch data for this species in this area is problematic due to misidentification and high levels of under-reporting. However, this species is one of the top five most valuable commercial species in the demersal shark longline fishery, commercial line fishery, and inshore trawl fishery (da Silva et al. 2019).

Destructive fishing practices including intensive inshore and offshore trawling with increasing incursions into coastal areas, the use of explosives and chemicals in inshore areas, and the use of small-sized beach and purse seine nets in both nearshore and offshore regions, have contributed to depleted fish stocks across the Eastern Central Atlantic region, which covers part of the species' range (Koranteng 1998, GCLME 2006, Gascuel et al. 2007). Specifically, China’s West African fleet has rapidly increased in recent years with an estimated 518 vessels (82% of them trawlers) currently operating in the Eastern Central Atlantic (mostly between Morocco and Gabon) (Gutierrez et al. 2020). This region also has some of the highest levels of Illegal, Unreported, and Unregulated (IUU) fishing in the world and it is estimated that illegal catches exceed more than 40% of the reported legal catch (Pauly and Zeller 2016).

The shallow, inshore soft-substrate habitats used by this species are threatened by habitat loss and environmental degradation (Stobutzki et al. 2006, White and Sommerville 2010, Jabado et al. 2017). Indirect and sublethal sources of mortality include coastal habitat destruction and degradation, conversion of coastal lagoons and mangrove deforestation for agriculture (e.g., rice and salt) and aquaculture (e.g., shrimp, fish culture, and fish production); extensive oil and gas exploration, drilling, and production; the effects of rapid urban expansion from growing coastal populations and unplanned tourism development; pollution (unregulated sewage effluents, agricultural runoff, hydrocarbon, and heavy metals); sedimentation and siltation; and changes to the hydrological cycle from the building of dams leading to dramatic levels of habitat loss evident across the region (GCLME 2006, FAO 2007, Polidoro et al. 2016).
population:
Species-specific population trend data are available from relative abundance in Mauritania and South Africa (da Silva et al. 2019; Institut Mauritanien de Recherches Océanographiques et de Pêches unpubl. data 2020). The trend data were analyzed over three generation lengths (53 years) using a Bayesian state-space framework (Sherley et al. 2020, Winker et al. 2020). This analysis yields an annual rate of change, a median change over three generation lengths, and the probability of the most likely IUCN Red List Category percent change over three generation lengths (see the Supplementary Information). The trend analysis of annual standardized abundance index (individual/year) estimates from trawl surveys (1982–2015) in Mauritania revealed annual rates of reduction of 4.8%, consistent with an estimated median reduction of 92.4% decrease over three generation lengths (53 years), with the highest probability of  >80% reduction over the past three generation lengths (53 years). The trend analysis of stock assessment biomass from demersal trawl surveys conducted along the south coast of South Africa (1990–2016) revealed annual rates of reduction of 1.7%, consistent with an estimated median reduction of 59% over three generation lengths (53 years), with the highest probability of >50% reduction over the past three generation lengths (53 years).

There are a number of other relevant historical accounts and contemporary datasets for landings and catch rates, and although landings data are not a direct measure of abundance, these can be used to calculate population reduction where landings have decreased while fishing effort has remained stable or increased. In nearly all cases presented below, there is no reason to suspect that overall fishing effort has decreased. In fact, as human coastal population continues to grow and as fishing technology and market access improves, fishing effort and power is continuing to increase globally, with high increases in the Mediterranean Sea, Eastern Central Atlantic and Southeast Atlantic regions (Anticamara et al. 2011, Watson et al. 2013, Belhabib et al. 2018).

First, in the Mediterranean Sea, surveys indicate that the Common Smoothhound is more common than the Starry Smoothhound (Mustelus asterias). It was recorded in 111 of 6,336 hauls (2%) conducted during the International Bottom Trawl Survey in the Mediterranean (MEDITS) programme in the western, central, and eastern Mediterranean Sea, from 1994–1999 at depths of 10–800 m, and was mostly captured between 0–50 m depth (Baino et al. 2001). In similar MEDITS surveys in the western Mediterranean (Iberian Peninsula and the Balearic Islands) from 1994–2017, 207 individuals were recorded in the Balearic Islands and another four individuals in the Northern Alboran Sea (Ramírez-Amaro et al. 2020). A significant decrease in abundance of smoothhounds was reported from 1970 onwards in comparable surveys in the Gulf of Lions, southern France (Aldebert 1997). MEDITS catch data was also compared from the Adriatic Sea in 1998 with that the Hvar survey in 1948 and indicated that the occurrence of this species was relatively stable (Jukic-Peladic et al. 2001). In the Hvar trawl surveys, occurrence (frequency log-transformed) was about 1.0 compared to about 0.1 in those of the MEDITS surveys conducted in the same area in 1998. In Gruppo Nazionale Risorse Demersali (GRUND) surveys conducted in Italian waters between 1985–1998, the percentage presence was 21.9%. Most of the population was concentrated in the Adriatic Sea and southern waters of Sicily, and the species was absent from the Ligurian Sea and from Sardinian waters (Relini et al. 2000). Reports from trawl fisheries in the Adriatic Sea between 2006–2008 noted the rarity of this species, with a bycatch rate of 0.0256 individuals per haul within this time period (Fortuna et al. 2011). The annual bycatch estimate was 863 individuals (95% confidence intervals: 818 to 891 individuals). In MEDITS surveys in the Aegean Sea between 1998–2008, catches of the Common Smoothhound were very low but highly variable (zero to 14 individuals) (Tserpes et al. 2013). An experimental trawl fishery in the Aegean Sea (Izmir Bay, Turkey) revealed that this species was one of the least prevalent non-commercial species, representing up to 1.08% of the total catch weight during the winter months, 1.04% in the autumn, 0.42% in the summer months, and 0.43% in the spring (Gurbet et al. 2013). A fishery-independent survey between 2007–2008 in the Gulf of Gabès off Tunisia (North African coast) caught a mean of 2.2 individuals per km of gillnet per day (Echwikhi et al. 2013). The Common Smoothhound was more abundant in this study area compared to the other Mediterranean regions (western, central, and eastern) (Echwikhi et al. 2013). Landings data reported to the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) show that landings of Mustelus spp. (grouped as “smoothhounds nei” in landing statistics and probably including the Common Smoothhound, Starry Smoothhound, and Blackspotted Smoothhound (Mustelus punctulatus), of which the Common Smoothhound is the most common in the region) steadily increased between 1950–1978 to 14,000 t, after which they fluctuated between ~6,500 t and 14,000 t from 1978–1994 (FAO 2008). After 1994, landings dropped significantly, decreasing to 2,980 t in 1997 and did not exceed 2,200 t from 2001–2006 (FAO 2008). Although these landings are not species-specific, combined with the results of fishery-independent trawl surveys, they also suggest that this species has declined in abundance in the Mediterranean Sea. In recent decades, a continuous decrease in smoothhounds across the Mediterranean combined with a contraction in their spatial distribution has been reported (Colloca et al. 2017). Specifically, it was estimated that the Common Smoothhound and Blackspotted Smoothhound have declined by 88% in the western Mediterranean and Adriatic Sea since the 1920s (Colloca et al. 2017). On the other hand, trawl surveys of demersal resources in the south of Sicily, where a reduction in fishing effort has occurred since the mid-1990s, indicate that this decline is likely to be less steep in this region with trends in abundance of demersal elasmobranchs in general increasing (Gancitano et al. 2015).

Second, both catch and effort have continued to rise in the major shark fishing countries of Mauritania, Nigeria, and Ghana, and consequently population reduction cannot be inferred from these increasing trends, but this does indicate rising fishing pressure. There are no other estimates of population reduction available from this region. The greatest fishing effort and largest reported elasmobranch fisheries in the whole of Africa were the West African countries of Nigeria (13,238 t), Senegal (10,757 t), and Ghana (1,902 t) (FAO 2002, Walker et al. 2005). Nevertheless, given the lack of reporting in artisanal fisheries and the large number of nations fishing in African waters, actual landings are likely to be much higher. Overall, across the West Africa region, the average elasmobranch CPUE has decreased by 71% over 1970–2015. The average elasmobranch CPUE in the region was 0.68 t/kW in 1970 and declined to 0.20 t/kW by 2015 (Pauly et al. 2020). Simultaneously, the average elasmobranch catch has increased by more than 2.5 times (250%) from 1970–2015. The average elasmobranch catch in the region was 3,312 t in 1970 and increased to 8,329 t in 2015 (Pauly et al. 2020). This implies a dramatic increase in fishing effort as the elasmobranch catch volume has increased but the CPUE has decreased. Within countries, catches have historically increased but have peaked and begun to decline in recent years. More specifically, in Senegal, reconstructed landings of sharks, rays, and skates showed a decline of at least 30%, and maybe as much as an 80% decline, over 15 years from 2001–2016. Catches gradually rose from 3,644 t in 1950 to 20,180 t in 1972 then declined to 4,211 t in 1981 (80% decline), then rose steeply to a peak of 23,194 t in 2001 followed by a fluctuating decline to 4,734 t in 2016 (Pauly et al. 2020). In Cameroon, reconstructed landings of sharks, rays, and skates have been rising since the 1960s but showed a 96% decline over the years from 2007–2016. Historically, catches quickly rose from 391 t in 1950 to 2,881 t in 1974 then showed a decline to 712 t in 1986 (75% decline). Elasmobranch catch then rose to a peak of 7,516 t in 2007 followed by a steep decline to 303 t in 2016 (Pauly et al. 2020). In Nigeria, reconstructed landings of sharks, rays, and skates have been rising since the 1970s but showed a 19% decline over the years from 2010–2016. Historically, catches quickly rose from 2,419 t in 1950 to 25,144 t in 1980 then rose to a peak of 31,273 t in 2010 followed by a fluctuating decline to 25,396 t in 2016 (Pauly et al. 2020). These declines in landings can be used to infer reductions in their populations, as the fishing effort has remained stable during the period of a decline in landings (Pauly et al. 2020). This steep increase in landings coincides with a steep rise in fishing effort and an overall 44% reduction in elasmobranch CPUE from 0.107 t/kW in 1981–1983 to 0.060 t/kW in 2013–2015.

Third, comparisons of historic abundance with contemporary patterns is consistent with population declines even though the Common Smoothhound still occurs in landings across the Eastern Central Atlantic. In Mauritania, this species is targeted as 'tollo' generally consisting of the Common Smoothhound and the Barbeled Houndshark (Leptocharias smithii) within the Parc National du Banc D'Arguin with fishers using specialized gear. While landings have declined, it is still considered a relatively common species (M. Dia unpubl. data 2020). Between 2004–2011, this species was recorded during extensive landing site surveys across the Sub-Regional Fisheries Commission region in all countries except for Sierra Leone and was considered abundant (Diop and Dossa 2011, M. Diop unpubl. data 2020). In The Gambia, only two individuals of this species were recorded during landing site surveys conducted annually between 2010–2018 although other species of sharks were also infrequently recorded (Moore et al. 2019). In Cape Verde, reports from a demersal fish resource survey carried out between October and November 2000 (R/V Arquipelago) using demersal longlines at depths down to 1,200 m indicate that this species was frequently caught at depths down to 350 m but more commonly between 0–100 m with abundance values between 0.1% and 10% measured as the average percentage of occurrence of each species in all fishing sets per depth strata (Menezes et al. 2004). In Cape Verde, the species is frequently caught in artisanal fisheries across the archipelago but landings quantities are not available because data are aggregated with other species such as the Atlantic Weasel Shark (Paragaleus pectoralis), Barbeled Houndshark, and the Milk Shark (Rhizoprionodon acutus). Across the archipelago, it is targeted for cação (dried shark meat) which has replaced imported cod from Portugal and has resulted in increased targeted shark fisheries (Seymour et al. 2018). This species was also recorded during Baited Remote Underwater Video Surveys undertaken between 2015–2017 with >50 individuals sighted in 220 hours of underwater video footage (MarAlliance 2019; S. Pires unpubl. data 2020). It was recorded in trawl surveys undertaken in Guinea from 1985–2012 but data on quantities are not available (Camara et al. 2016). There has been no recent records of this species in landing site surveys in the Bijagos Archipelago, Guinea-Bissau although it has been recorded in research trawl surveys in 2019 (G.H.L. Leurs unpubl. data 2020). This species was considered abundant in landings from drifting gillnets in Côte d’Ivoire (Abidjan Port) between 1991–2003 (N'Goran et al. 2005). Based on landing site survey results from 2019, this species was still considered relatively common in Côte d'Ivoire (K. Metcalfe unpubl. data 2020). In Nigeria, it is considered relatively common and captured frequently in national trawl research surveys (A.B. Williams unpubl. data 2020). Landing sites surveys in Western Ghana in 2019 and 2020 indicate that only seven individuals of this species were recorded despite other sharks being frequently landed (I. Seidu unpubl. data 2020). In the trawl fisheries observer data from Gabon, this species represented 3% of sharks captured in 2017 and 8.6% in 2018 and while these were mostly discarded alive they were wounded and in a poor state likely increasing post-release mortality. The Common Smoothhound, Atlantic Weasel Shark, and Barbeled Houndshark together represent an important proportion of shark captures reported by onboard observers with 17.1% in 2016, 28.6% in 2017, 50.4% in 2018 and 34.8% in 2019, with variations in catches over the years likely due to differences in the presence of onboard observers and spatial regulations in process (E. Chartrain unpubl. data 2020). This species is the most commonly recorded shark from the artisanal fisheries operating in Mayumba using demersal set gillnets (G. De Bruyne unpubl. data 2020). These artisanal fisheries capture this species seasonally (dry season from March to September) and CPUE has decreased from 10.5 to 4 kg landed per day between 2014–2018, however, fishing effort has increased during the same period (G. De Bruyne unpubl. data 2020). In Cameroon, eight individuals have been recorded over two years of landing site surveys representing 0.4% of all shark and ray records (A. Tamo unpubl. data 2020). In the Republic of the Congo, 727 individuals were recorded during landing site surveys from January to December 2019 representing ~2% total catch (P. Doherty unpubl. data 2020). In Angola, 18 individuals were recorded during opportunistic landing site surveys in 2018 (A.L. Soares unpubl. data 2020). 

Overall, there is limited species-specific reporting, as well as a lack of species-specific time-series data from much of the range of the species. However, considering general declining catch trends and limited number of specimens recorded in fisheries surveys in several localities, the level of intense and large unmanaged fisheries that operate throughout its range, its limited refuge at depth, its susceptibility to fisheries, and noted declines in other sharks, it is suspected that the Common Smoothhound has undergone a population reduction of 50–79% over the past three generation lengths (53 years) based on abundance data and actual levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Endangered A2bd.
range: The Common Smoothhound is found in the east Atlantic Ocean, including the Mediterranean Sea (but is absent from the Black Sea) (Serena 2005, Ebert and Stehmann 2013). It occurs from Portugal to the east coast of South Africa, including Madeira Island, the Canary Islands, the Cape Verde Archipelago, and São Tomé and Príncipe (Wirtz et al. 2007, Ebert and Stehmann 2013, Wirtz et al. 2013). Records of this species in the Northeast Atlantic Ocean (north of Portuguese waters, that is, the United Kingdom, Republic of Ireland, France, and Spain) require confirmation and could be the result of misidentifications with the Starry Smoothhound (Mustelus asterias) (Farrell et al. 2009, McCully Phillips and Ellis 2015).
useTrade: The Common Smoothhound is commercially valuable across its range where it is utilized fresh, smoked, or dried-salted for human consumption (Bauchot 1987, Walker et al. 2005, da Silva 2018). In Italian fish markets, smoothhounds are marketed headless, skinned, and eviscerated and labelled 'palombo'—an umbrella term for a number of shark species and one of which has been identified through DNA barcoding as the Common Smoothhound (Barbuto et al. 2010). Across the Cape Verde Archipelago and Angola, it is widely consumed as dried shark meat (cação) (S. Pires and A.L. Soares unpubl. data 2020). Fins are not considered valuable due to their small size but are still traded internationally (da Silva and Burgener 2007; M. Diop, R.W. Jabado, and A.L. Soares unpubl. data 2020). In South Africa, it is also targeted by commercial fishers when higher value teleosts are unavailable and exported to Australia through the “flake” fillet industry. It is sometimes processed into fishmeal (Walker et al. 2005).
conservationActions:
There are few specific management measures in place for Common Smoothhound throughout the majority of its range. The European Community Council Regulations 850/98 for the ‘conservation of fishery resources through technical measures for the protection of juveniles of marine organisms’ details the minimum mesh sizes than can be used to target fish. Smoothhounds would be classed under ‘all other marine organisms’ and so can only be targeted in fixed nets of more than 220 mm (ICES 2012).

The Common Smoothhound is listed in Appendix III of the Barcelona Convention, affording it regulation of any exploitation taking place in the Mediterranean region (Recommendation GFCM/36/2012/1). All vessels encountering this species must record information on fishing activities, catch data, incidental taking, release and/or discarding events in a logbook or similar document, then all logged information must be reported to national authorities. The Balearic Island Marine Reserves offer minimal protection to smoothhounds, as they are protected within the waters of the reserve.

In Mauritania, a minimum size limit (60 cm total length) for landings of the Common Smoothhound has been established since 2007 (M. Dia unpubl. data 2020). Elsewhere, although countries across its range have legislations concerning fisheries activities (including finning bans, gear restrictions, and no-trawling zones in coastal waters), fisheries taking the Common Smoothhound are generally unmanaged throughout large parts of the species’ range and it is unlikely that pressure will decrease in the near future. 

In the Eastern Central Atlantic, a number of countries have either adopted a Regional Plan of Action for the Conservation of Sharks (Sub-Regional Fisheries Commission countries from Mauritania to Sierra Leone, including Cape Verde) or are currently working on developing a National Plan of Action (e.g., Liberia) to conserve sharks and rays and manage their fisheries for sustainability under the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) International Plan of Action for the Conservation and Management of Sharks (IPOA). However, progress towards the implementation of these actions have stalled since 2011 due to lack of funding and support (M. Diop unpubl. data 2020).

Also, a Regional Marine Protected Areas Network in West Africa (RAMPAO) was set up in 2007 across six countries (Mauritania to Sierra Leone) to conserve representative samples of critical habitats and protect threatened species but many of these protected areas lack capacity, funding, infrastructure and governance for effective enforcement and conservation (Polidoro et al. 2016). Therefore, it is unlikely that they provide a refuge for this species. In fact, shark and ray fishing has been prohibited in the Parc National du Banc d’Arguin in Mauritania since 2003 but sharks and rays are still frequently landed as bycatch (M. Diop unpubl. data 2020). Other countries such as Gabon, the Republic of the Congo, and Côte d'Ivoire are in the process of expanding their marine protected areas coverage, however, financial and technical support will also be required to ensure they can be enforced and that they promote connectivity and protect key life history stages (K. Metcalfe unpubl. data 2020). 

There are a number of protected areas in South Africa across the range of this species that may offer some protection. Additionally, gill net fisheries are prohibited from retaining sharks and rays while beach seine fisheries are only allowed to retain sharks in False Bay (da Silva 2018). There is currently a bag limit of 1 per person per day among non-commercial anglers, with no bag limits for commercial fisheries (Cliff and da Silva 2020). A size limit of 70–130 cm is currently being implemented for this species in the demersal longline and the commercial linefishery. This will protect the juveniles and the larger, more fecund adult females (Cliff and da Silva 2020).  

To conserve the population and to permit recovery, a suite of measures will be required which may include species protection, spatial management, bycatch mitigation, and harvest and trade management measures (including international trade measures). Effective enforcement of measures will require ongoing training and capacity-building (including in the area of species identification). Catch monitoring is needed to help understand population trends and inform management.

rationale:
The Sharpfin Houndshark (Triakis acutipinna) is an extremely rare small shark (to at least 102 cm total length). It is known only from Manabí province, Ecuador in the Southeast Pacific with an estimated extent of occurrence of 4,900–7,163 km². Its habitat and life history are virtually unknown and based on captures it is known to occur at depths of 50–200 m. There are limited records and specimens of this species.

Small-scale fisheries which catch sharks operate across coastal Ecuador and the Sharpfin Houndshark is reportedly caught very rarely in coastal artisanal demersal gillnet fisheries and the industrial hake demersal longline fishery that operates to a depth of 200 m. Fishers interviewed in 2020 report catches as recent as ‘2010–2015’ in the artisanal gillnet fisheries. When caught, it is apparently discarded with only occasional local consumption of the meat. Its occurrence in Machalilla National Park (Isla de la Plata) could have significant conservation benefits for the species. However, given its rarity and restricted range, the Sharpfin Houndshark requires full legal protection and associated awareness and education.

Its extent of occurrence is potentially smaller than 5,000 km², it is known from a single location (Manabí province) affected by pressure from fisheries, and a continuing decline is inferred in the number of mature individuals based on the level of fishing effort across its range. The population size for this species is considered to be <2,500 individuals, based on very few records of it within a restricted area (with no evidence for genetically or geographically distinct subpopulations). The Sharpfin Houndshark is therefore assessed as Endangered B1ab(v); C2a(ii).
habitat: The Sharpfin Houndshark is currently only known to occur on the continental shelf at depths of 50–200 m (Weigmann 2016). The habitat of the species is virtually unknown. It reaches a reported maximum size of 102 cm total length (TL), a male was mature by 90 cm TL and female size-at-maturity is unknown (Kato 1968, Cevallos-Garcias et al. submitted). Reproduction is viviparous but nothing else is known of its biology.
threats: Small-scale fisheries that catch shark operate across coastal Ecuador. The Sharpfin Houndshark is reportedly caught very rarely in coastal artisanal demersal gillnet fisheries (Martínez-Ortiz and García-Domínguez 2013, Cevallos-Garcias et al. submitted). A recently interviewed fisher indicated that the species has been taken as bycatch in the industrial hake fishery which uses demersal longlines at around 200 m depth (Cevallos-Garcias et al. submitted).
population:
The population size of the Sharpfin Houndshark was considered to be <2,500 mature individuals by Compagno et al. (2009) on account of there being very few records from a restricted geographic area. Indeed, the species is known only from the adult female holotype, an adult male record, reports that it is very rarely landed from coastal gillnet fisheries around Puerto López and El Matal (Martínez-Ortiz and García-Domínguez 2013), and recent interviews with fishers indicating that it has been caught around a small number of coastal communities in Manabí province (Cevallos-Garcias et al. submitted). 

This species is distinct and separable from other houndsharks in the Eastern Pacific, however triakids ('tollo') are commonly recorded at family level in fisheries statistics, making it difficult to ascertain catches and trends in particular species (Cevallos-Garcias et al. submitted). Of a small number of fishers (n=12) recently interviewed in coastal communities of Manabí province, half recognised the species and dates of last capture were provided for three communities: 1990s for Las Piñas, 2000–2005 for Liguiqui, and 2010–2015 for Santa Rosa (Cevallos-Garcias et al. submitted).
range: The Sharpfin Houndshark is known only from Manabí province, Ecuador in the Southeast Pacific Ocean (Ebert et al. 2013). The type locality is Isla de La Plata. Despite its listing in some Peruvian checklists, the species has not been recorded there (see Cevallos-Garcias et al. submitted). The extent of occurrence is estimated as 4,900–7,163 km².
useTrade: Houndsharks ('tollo') are heavily utilised in the Eastern Pacific for their meat and fins.
