The meat of sawfish is sometimes utilised by Indigenous communities but the extent to which Indigenous Australians harvest and utilise Dwarf Sawfish is unknown; it is likely localised and at a low rate. There are also anecdotal reports of Indigenous people purchasing sawfish rostra off commercial fishers, painting and then selling them (Stevens et al. 2005).

Outside of Australia, in the historical Indo-West Pacific distribution of Dwarf Sawfish, exploitation of elasmobranchs is high (e.g. India, Indonesia) and sawfish have been utilised and traded for meat, fins, oil and rostrums. See CITES (2007) for a comprehensive overview of trade in sawfishes.
conservationActions:
Within Australia, Dwarf Sawfish has the following conservation and protected status listings: Australian Commonwealth waters, Vulnerable (Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999); Queensland, Protected (Fisheries Act 1994); Northern Territory (NT), Vulnerable (Territory Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 2000); Western Australia (WA), Totally Protected (Fish Resources Management Act 1994). The take of the species is therefore prohibited within Australian Commonwealth, state and territory waters. Dwarf Sawfish is listed on Appendix I of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES), prohibiting any international trade in the species (Dwarf Sawfish were collected for the aquarium trade prior to this listing and exported; DSEWPaC 2011).

In addition to the above legislated regulations, the Commonwealth, Queensland, NT and WA all have fisheries management plans in place for interactions with protected species, including Dwarf Sawfish. These include mandatory reporting of interactions with these species, release of live animals, observer coverage of most of the fisheries (although this is very low in state and territory fisheries which are likely to interact with Dwarf Sawfish) and education programmes for fishers on identification and ways to minimise interactions with this species. The Queensland Government has published a guide to the safe release of sawfish for commercial fishers (DEEDI 2010) and the NT shark fishers have a Code of Practice for the release of live sawfish from gillnets (Salini et al. 2007).

Several spatial closures in riverine, estuarine and coastal waters in the NT Barramundi Fishery, offer Dwarf Sawfish some refuge from commercial gillnet fishing activities in the NT. Similarly, spatial closures in important sawfish habitat areas of Port Musgrave and the Wenlock River in the Queensland Gulf of Carpentaria offer some protection (DEEDI 2009). Closed areas within the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park and the closure of rivers in Princess Charlotte Bay to gillnetting would afford protection to Dwarf Sawfish if they occur on the northeastern Queensland coast. Seasonal spawning closures for the take of Barramundi (Lates calcarifer) throughout much of the range (mostly during the summer wet season) add a level of protection to the species, however, information on Dwarf Sawfish long-term movement patterns and habitat use are required in order to assess the benefits of closed areas and seasons not specifically designed for sawfish.

In the prawn trawl fisheries (Northern Prawn Fishery and Queensland East Coast Trawl Fishery), the use of turtle exclusion devices (TEDs) and bycatch reduction devices (BRDs) is mandatory, though the benefit of these devices on sawfish is poorly quantified. In a Northern Prawn Fishery study, they have been shown to reduce the catch of Narrow Sawfish (Anoxypristis cuspidata), however, they and other sawfish species are still being caught as their rostra become tangled in the body of the net (Brewer et al. 2006).

Outside of Australia, awareness needs to be raised, and regulations put in place to protect all sawfishes and promote population recovery. While sawfishes (Largetooth P. pristis, Narrow and Green Sawfish P. zijsron) are theoretically protected in India (Indian Wildlife (Protection) Act), threats continue with little beneficial management, although increasing awareness of sawfishes in India is encouraging.

rationale: Clupeonella engrauliformis is a marine, schooling species endemic to the Caspian Sea, specifically from the middle and southern regions. Given that this species is known to reach maturity at around 2 years old and has a maximum longevity of 8 years, its generation length was estimated to be between 4–5 years. Prior to the 2000s, species of Clupeonella (or Kilka, i.e., Clupeonella engrauliformis, C. grimmi, and C. caspia) were considered the most abundant fishes in the Caspian Sea and contributed to the most commercially important fisheries; this species in particular, made up 70–80 % of total Kilka landings. More recently (2000–present) this species has suffered from fishery collapse and severe population declines, similar to C. grimmi. In addition to overfishing, the population faces a series of pervasive threats, as sea level rise and invasive species, which has been shown to alter the relative abundance of the three species of Kilka in the Caspian Sea. Where data are available, sharp declines have been depicted in the total biomass, spawning stock biomass, annual landings and CPUE of this species throughout its range. For example, trends in current CPUE from Iran were extrapolated to the present using an exponential regression based on past CPUE data (1995–2011). Based on this estimation, current CPUE is suspected to have declined by approximately 98.2–99.3 % within three generation lengths (12–15 years). Declines in annual landings of this species from Iranian waters have also been calculated using current catch data. This species decreased from 45,600 tonnes (~80% of total Kilka landings) in 1996 to about 600 tonnes (~3% of total Kilka landings) in 2017. Over the most recent three-generation length time window of 12–15 years (from 2003– or 2006–2017), catches are represented by a decline of 68–92%. However, there is some evidence suggesting a shift in the spatial distribution of fishing vessels in the Caspian Sea that may have resulted in a decline in fishing effort for this species (i.e., fleets are now fishing closer to shore and there has been a decline in fishing vessels targeting this species); it is plausible that some of the decline in landings of this species in Iran could be attributable to declines in effort. Therefore, it is conservatively suspected that population declines for this species in Iran have exceeded 50% over the past three generation lengths. Despite the lack of available quantitative data outside of Iran, there is no reason to suspect that the situation is any better elsewhere in the Caspian Sea. It is therefore suspected that the anchovy Kilka has experienced a global population decline at least exceeding 50% over the past three generation lengths, which qualifies this species for Endangered under criterion A2bde. Immediate coordinated international effort is recommended in order to implement swift and necessary management of this species within the Caspian Sea.
habitat: Clupeonella engrauliformis is a marine, schooling species endemic to the Caspian Sea. This species mainly occupies open sea areas but occasionally approaches the shore. It forms large concentrated schools where the water depth exceeds 30 m and is typically found in the upper water layers but may descend to 120 m (Janbaz et al. 2012, Coad 2017). This species can tolerate salinities ranging from 8–14 ‰, but is mostly found in areas with higher salinities (i.e., 10–12 ‰: Coad 2017). This species overwinters in the southern Caspian sea and extends north into the central and northern Caspian in the Spring to feed. Sexual maturity is attained around age 2 (Coad 2017) and breeding takes place from April to November but mostly in July (Whitehead 1985). The sex ratio varies with season; females dominate from January to June and males were more abundant from September to November (Coad 2017). This species is known to have a maximum longevity of up to 8 years (Coad 2017) and grows to a maximum standard length of 15.5 cm, though usually only found between 11.5 and 12.5 cm (Whitehead 1985). Given the maximum known longevity (8 years) and the age at maturity (2 years) of this species, the generation length was estimated to be 4–5 years.
threats: This species, similar to the other species of Clupeonella, has suffered severe declines in recent years and faces several distinct threats, including impacts from invasive species, fishing pressure and habitat changes (i.e., increased sea level). The accidental introduction of the comb jelly Mnemiopsis leidyi from the Azov-Black Sea Basin in 1999 is a major threat to this species as they compete for the same food and M. leidyi also consumes the eggs of this species (Kideys 2001, Shiganova et al. 2004, Mamedov 2006, Fazli et al. 2017). This species was the first Kilka to suffer from the introduction, which was the main commercial species for all Caspian countries (Shiganova et al. 2004). Mamedov (2006) reported that the arrival of M. leidyi resulted in a decreased biomass of zooplankton, the main food resource of this species of Clupeonella, which dropped by a factor of 4 - 10 between 2000 and 2003. It has been suggested that the reason for the 2005 stock collapse is primarily due to the invasion and spread of this ctenophore species (Mnemiopsis leidyi) but that over-fishing and other factors also contributed to the crash (Fazli et al. 2007, Daskalov and Mamedov 2007, Aliasghari et al. 2017). Sea level rise and increased freshwater output from the Volga River has also been attributed to depleted abundances for this species (Fazli et al. 2007, 2017).
population:
Status of Kilka in the Caspian Sea

The majority of fisheries landings in the Caspian Sea are attributable to Kilka, the most abundant fishes in the region (Fazli et al. 2009) which includes Clupeonella caspia, C. engrauliformis and C. grimmi. Historically, the majority of Kilka landings were represented by C. engrauliformis, with less than 20% in contribution by C. caspia and C. grimmi (Fazli et al. 2009, Janbaz et al. 2012, Falahatkar 2015, Coad 2017). Annual harvest of total Kilka catch has shown some fluctuations over time, but overall show a declining trend with evidence to support overexploitation from a majority of its range, including Iran (Fazli and Taghavi 2013) and Azerbaijan (Daskalov and Mamedov 2007).

Globally, lumped landings of species of Clupeonella are reported to the FAO in appreciable quantities (averaging roughly 256,000 tonnes per year); however, we have been unable to determine the precise extent this species is included in reported landings. Annual catch of three clupeoid species including Clupeonella engrauliformis reached a maximum of 423,000 metric tons in 1970, which accounted for roughly 70% of the total fish catch in the Caspian Sea. Overexploitation and the expansion of the invasive ctenophore, Mnemiopsis leidyi, in the early 2000’s resulted in major declines in total biomass and catch of Kilka, as well as a change in the relative abundance of the three species (Daskalov and Mamedov 2007, Fazli et al. 2007, Aliasghari et al. 2017).

For example, total catch in 1999 peaked at 271,400 tonnes and fishing mortality reached 1.8 y-1 indicating overexploitation (Daskalov and Mamedov 2007).

Additionally, more recent studies from Iran indicate that C. caspia is now considered to be the most common Kilka in the Caspian Sea,  accounting for 87% of catches, whereas this species (previously the most abundant) recently represented roughly 8–9% and C. grimmi represented 1.6% (Karimzadeh et al. 2010, Parafkandeh Haghighi and Kaymaram 2012).

Furthermore, biomass of all species of Clupeonella declined by a factor of three in Russia, Iran and Azerbaijan between 2000 and 2001, with larger declines seen in 2002 (Shiganova et al. 2004). By 2002, M. leidyi reached critical biomass levels in important commercial areas jeopardizing fishing industries in the Caspian Sea, including C. engrauliformis, which was the main commercial fishery for all Caspian countries (Shiganova et al. 2004). Clupeonella abundance in Iranian waters declined from roughly 10–15% to 0–2% and fisheries collapsed by approximately 50% in 2–3 years following the introduction (Daskalov and Mamedov 2007, Coad 2017).

Azerbaijan

In Azerbaijan, total Kilka catches declined from 18,500 to 5,100 tonnes (2000 – 2004) representing a 72% decrease in 5 years (Mamedov 2006). Recruitment failure in 2001 has been attributed to the invasion and spread of the ctenophore Mnemiopsis leidyi (Daskalov and Mamedov 2007) and resulted in an increase in the average age of the stock and a large decline in total abundance (Mamedov 2006).

Iran

The vast majority of available data regarding the status of Kilka in the Caspian Sea refer to Iranian waters, which likely represents less than 50% of all Kilka in the Caspian Sea. However, there is no reason to believe that it is not representative of the entire region. Since 1996, total landings of Kilka in Iran have declined from 57,000 to 27,602 tonnes in 2017, representing an approximate 60.3% decrease (Iranian Fisheries Organization unpublished data).

Additionally, changes of biological characteristics of all species of kilka, especially C. engrauliformis, were reported in areas impacted by M. leidyi (Parafkandeh Haghighi and Kaymaram 2012) including a sharp decrease in weight, length and condition of individuals (Shiganova et al. 2004).

Specific information regarding the status of the anchovy Kilka, C.engrauliformis

Azerbaijan

A study using an integrated catch-at-age analysis based on commercial catch of this species indicated a sustainable fishery from 1991 to 2000 with relatively good recruitment and a high spawning-stock biomass (Daskalov and Mamedov 2007). However, poor recruitment was noted in 2001 from competition and predation of M. leidyi, and has reportedly remained at a low level since then (Daskalov and Mamedov 2007).

Iran

Fazli et al. (2012) indicated that the population status of this species in Iranian waters is in critical condition. Overexploitation and the introduction of M. leidyi in 1999 resulted in major reported declines in biomass, catch and CPUE of C. engrauliformis in Iranian waters. For example, the total biomass and spawning stock biomass showed a declining trend (Fazli et al. 2012); biomass declined from about 186,000 tonnes in 1996 to less than 12,000 tonnes in 2004 (Fazli et al. 2007) roughly representing a 94% decrease in 9 years. Fazli et al. (2009) indicated that overfishing (especially between 2005 and 2008) is the main reason for the most recent collapse of this species’ fisheries.

CPUE data are not available for the entire range of the current three generations (12–15 years, based on age at maturity = 2 and maximum longevity = 8); however CPUE information is available until 2010 (Fazli and Taghavi Jelodar 2013) and current annual landings data are available (Iranian Fisheries Organization 2017). Catches of this species increased from 1995 to a peak in 1999 at 67,000 tonnes (Iranian Fisheries Organization 2017); during this time CPUE (in tonnes per vessel per night) remained relatively constant (2.92–3.52: Fazli et al. 2012). After the introduction of M. leidyi (1999), catch and CPUE declined while effort increased until 2001 (Fazli and Taghavi Jelodar 2013). Acceptable biological catch (ABC) was estimated at 2,190 metric tonnes in 2004; however, in 2005 the catch was more than twice the estimated ABC (~4,300 tonnes) indicating overexploitation (Fazli et al. 2009, Iranian Fisheries Organization 2017). In 2008 the catch declined to 450 tonnes; the proportion of catches of this species dropped below 1% relative to other species taken in 2009 (Fazli et al. 2012). Catches continued to sharply decline to about 83 tonnes in 2011 with a CPUE of 0.01 (Fazli et al. 2012, Iranian Fisheries Organization 2017). Given the lack of current CPUE data (most recent estimate from 2011), the available data was extrapolated to the present using an exponential regression. Based on this estimation, it is suspected that declines exceed 95% over three generation lengths, which would qualify C. engrauliformis for Critically Endangered under criterion A2 in Iran. 

The only current data available within the most recent 10–15 years are annual landings data from Iran. Anchovy Kilka decreased from 45,600 tonnes (~80% of total Kilka landings) in 1996 to about 600 tonnes (~3% of total Kilka landings) in 2017 (IFSRI unpublished data). Since the lowest catch in 2011, catches have increased slightly in recent years, but remained below 200 tonnes until 2017 where the catch exceeded just over 600 tonnes (IFSRI unpublished data). Over the most recent three generation length time window of 12–15 years (from 2003– or 2006–2017), catches are represented by a decline of 68–92%. However, there is some anecdotal evidence suggesting a shift in the spatial distribution of fishing vessels in the Caspian Sea that may have resulted in a decline in fishing effort for this species. For example, more recently a larger portion of fishing activities has taken place in shallower water zones with depths less than 50 m, where this species is less available and C. caspia is more available to fisheries (Parafkandeh Haghighi and Kaymaram 2012, Fazli and Taghavi Jelodar 2013). Additionally, the number of vessels reported to target Kilka has recently declined from ~200 boats in 2002 to ~70 boats in 2013 (Falahatkar 2015); it is plausible that some of the decline in landings of this species in Iran could be attributable to declines in effort. Therefore, it is conservatively suspected that population declines for this species in Iran have exceeded 50% over the past three generation lengths. Although quantitative data are primarily available from Iran, there is no reason to suspect that the situation is any better elsewhere in the Caspian Sea. We therefore suspect that the anchovy Kilka has experienced a global population decline exceeding 50% over the past three generation lengths, which qualifies for Endangered under criterion A2.
range: Clupeonella engrauliformis is distributed throughout the Caspian Sea, specifically the middle and southern regions (Whitehead 1985, Fazli et al. 2009). Records of this species from the Anzali Lagoon and Gorgon Bay (Armantrout 1980, Coad 2017) require verification. This species descends to maximum depths of 78 m (Whitehead 1985).
useTrade:
Clupeonella engrauliformis is fished at a large-scale commercial level throughout its range. This species is taken at night time and is caught using lift nets and fish pumps with underwater electric lights (Fazli et al. 2009, Aliasghari et al. 2017). 

Azerbaijan is traditionally the most important area for commercial capture of Kilka species in the Caspian Sea (Mamedov 2006). In Iran, this species is commercially targeted; catches of all Kilka species are mainly concentrated along the Babolsar and Anzali coasts (Fazli et al. 2007, Parafkandeh Haghighi and Kaymaram 2012). The exploitation rate for this species varied between 0.34 and 0.815 (1995–2004: Coad 2017); the most recent exploitation rate was calculated as 0.51 per year in 2007 (Janbaz et al. 2012). In Iranian waters of the Capian Sea, a relatively recent stock assessments estimate maximum sustainable yield (MSY) at 44,652 metric tonnes and effort at 19.609 vessels per night (Fazli et al. 2009). Individuals ranging from 2 to 4 years old dominate fish landings in Iran (Coad 2017). In Iran, this species is commercially targeted and used in the local fishmeal industry. It is also consumed smoked, salted, canned in sauce and oil, and well as marinated, according to a traditional recipe and seasoned with fruits, herbs and vegetables (Alavi-Yegaheh et al. 2017).
conservationActions: No known species-specific conservation measures are in place; however a relatively recent study indicated that the population status of this species is in critical condition (Fazli et al. 2009). In a report prepared for the Caspian Environment Programme in 2001, suggestions of fishing limitations, lab studies and monitoring were made as measures to combat the Mnemiopsis problem. Aliasghari et al. (2017) recommends the increased attention, effort and monitoring of population levels, fishing pressure and influence of M. leidyi on this species. Further recommendations have been made for increased coordinated international effort needed to implement immediate management of Kilka stocks in the Caspian Sea (Fazli et al. 2009, Fazli and Taghavi Jelodar 2013). It has also been suggested that all catches of the three species of Clupeonella must be restricted during spawning periods (Fazli and Taghavi Jelodar 2013).

rationale:
Clupeonella grimmi is a marine, brackish, migratory and schooling species, endemic to the mid- and southern Caspian Sea and is generally not found close to shore. Given that this species is known to reach maturity at 2.5 years and has an maximum longevity of 7–8 years, a generation length for this species was estimated to be between 3.5–4 years.

Previously (prior to the 2000s), species of Clupeonella (or Kilka, i.e., Clupeonella engrauliformis, C. grimmi, and C. caspia) were considered the most abundant fishes in the Caspian Sea and contributed to the most commercially important fisheries; this species in particular, made up ~18% of total Kilka landings. More recently (2000–present) this species has suffered from fishery collapse and severe population declines, similar to C. engrauliformis. Additionally, the population faces a series of pervasive threats from over-fishing, sea level rise and invasive species (e.g., Mnemiopsis leidyi), which has been shown to alter the relative abundance of the three species of Kilka in the Caspian Sea.

Where data are available, sharp declines have been depicted in the total biomass, spawning stock biomass, annual landings and catch per unit effort (CPUE) of this species throughout its range. For example, trends in current CPUE from Iran were extrapolated to the present using an exponential regression based on past CPUE data (1995–2011). Based on this estimation, current CPUE is suspected to have declined by approximately 89–92 % within three generation lengths (10–12 years). Declines in annual landings of this species from Iranian waters have also been calculated using current catch data. This species decreased from 10,400 tonnes (~18% of total Kilka landings) in 1996 to about 226 tonnes (~ < 1% of total Kilka landings) in 2017. Over the most recent three-generation length time window of 10–12 years (from 2006– or 2008–2017), catches are represented by a decline of 21–78 %. It is important to note that declines calculated over 12 years include unusually high CPUE and reported catches (2006), therefore, the estimated decline over the most recent 10 years is thought to be a better representation of decline. However, there is some evidence suggesting a shift in the spatial distribution of fishing vessels in the Caspian Sea that may have resulted in a decline in fishing effort for this species (i.e., fleets are now fishing closer to shore and there has been a decline in fishing vessels targeting this species); it is plausible that some of the decline in landings of this species in Iran could be attributable to declines in effort. Therefore, it is conservatively suspected that population declines for this species in Iran have exceeded 50% over the past three generation lengths.

Despite the lack of available quantitative data outside of Iran, there is no reason to suspect that the situation is any better elsewhere in the Caspian Sea. We therefore suspect that the anchovy Kilka has experienced a global population decline at least exceeding 50% over the past three generation lengths, which qualifies this species for Endangered under criterion A2bde. Immediate coordinated international effort is recommended in order to implement swift and necessary management of this species within the Caspian Sea.
habitat: Clupeonella grimmi is a schooling species, endemic to the Caspian Sea. This is an open water species known to inhabit deeper areas of the central and southern Caspian Sea (Fazli et al. 2009). This species rarely uses inshore areas and primarily occupies low - light areas in depths over 50–70 m, down to 450 m, with large schools down to approximately 130 m (Aliasghari et al. 2017). Larvae remain offshore at depths exceeding 70 m (Fazli et al. 2009). It does not enter freshwater or areas of low salinity (Aliasghari et al. 2017). In winter this species is found mainly in the southern regions and moves to the mid regions in the spring (Whitehead 1985). Mean age of females and males is 4.09 and 3.61 years, respectively with a maximum known life span of 7–8 years (Fazli et al. 2009, Aliasghari et al. 2011, Parafkandeh Haghighi and Kaymaram 2012). This species reaches maturity at approximately 2.5 years and 8.82 cm FL (Fazli et al. 2009). Given that this species has a maximum know life span of 7–8 years and reaches maturity at 2.5 years, declines should be calculated based on a 3.5–4 year generation length; 10–12 years is sufficient to represent 3 generation lengths for this species. Reproduction occurs throughout the year but peaks in February–March (Fazli et al. 2009). This species feeds mainly on copepods but also on pelagic mysids and small fishes. This species grows to a maximum standard length of 14.5 cm but usually only to 10.5–11 cm (Whitehead 1985).
threats: This species, similar to the other species of Clupeonella, has suffered severe declines in recent years and faces several distinct threats, including impacts from invasive species, fishing pressure and habitat changes (i.e., increased sea level). The accidental introduction of the comb jelly Mnemiopsis leidyi from the Azov-Black Sea Basin in 1999 is a major threat to this species as they compete for the same food and M. leidyi also consumes the eggs of this species (Kideys 2001, Shiganova et al. 2004, Mamedov 2006, Fazli et al. 2017). Mamedov (2006) reported that the arrival of M. leidyi resulted in a decreased biomass of zooplankton, the main food resource of this species of Clupeonella, which dropped by a factor of 4–10 between 2000 and 2003. Additionally, this species is currently considered to be overexploited in Iranian waters (Aliasghari et al. 2017). Depleted abundances for this species have also been attributed to sea level rise and increased freshwater output from the Volga River (Fazli et al. 2007, 2017).
population:
Status of Kilka in the Caspian Sea

The majority of fisheries landings in the Caspian Sea are attributable to Kilka, the most abundant fishes in the region (Fazli et al. 2009) which includes Clupeonella caspia, C. engrauliformis and C. grimmi. Historically, the majority of Kilka landings were represented by C. engrauliformis, with less than 20% in contribution by C. caspia and C. grimmi (Fazli et al. 2009, Janbaz et al. 2012, Falahatkar 2015, Coad 2017). Annual harvest of total Kilka catch has shown some fluctuations over time, but overall show a declining trend with evidence to support overexploitation from a majority of its range, including Iran (Fazli and Taghavi Jelodar 2013) and Azerbaijan (Daskalov and Mamedov 2007).

Globally, lumped landings of species of Clupeonella are reported to the FAO in appreciable quantities (averaging roughly 256,000 tonnes per year); however, we have been unable to determine the extent this species is included in reported landings. Annual catch of three clupeoid species including Clupeonella grimmi reached a maximum of 423,000 metric tons in 1970, which accounted for roughly 70% of the total fish catch in the Caspian Sea. Overexploitation and the expansion of the invasive ctenophore, Mnemiopsis leidyi, in the early 2000s resulted in major declines in total biomass and catch of Kilka, as well as a change in the relative abundance of the three species (Daskalov and Mamedov 2007, Fazli et al. 2007, Aliasghari et al. 2017).

For example, total catch in 1999 peaked at 271,400 tonnes and fishing mortality reached 1.8 y-1 indicating overexploitation (Daskalov and Mamedov 2007).

Additionally, more recent studies from Iran indicate that C. caspia is now considered to be the most common Kilka in the Caspian Sea, accounting for 87% of catches, whereas C. engrauliformis recently represented roughly 8–9% and this species represented 1.6% (Karimzadeh et al. 2010, Parafkandeh Haghighi and Kaymaram 2012).

Furthermore, biomass of all species of Clupeonella declined by a factor a three in Russia, Iran and Azerbaijan between 2000 and 2001, with larger declines seen in 2002 (Shiganova et al. 2004). By 2002, M. leidyi reached critical biomass levels in important commercial areas jeopardizing fishing industries in the Caspian Sea, including Kilka, which was the main commercial fishery for all Caspian countries (Shiganova et al. 2004). Clupeonella abundance in Iranian waters declined from roughly 10–15% to 0–2% and fisheries collapsed by approximately 50% in 2–3 years following the introduction (Daskalov and Mamedov 2007, Coad 2017).

Azerbaijan

In Azerbaijan, total Kilka catches declined from 18,500–5,100 tonnes (2000–2004) representing a 72% decrease in 5 years (Mamedov 2006). Recruitment failure in 2001 has been attributed to the invasion and spread of the ctenophore Mnemiopsis leidyi (Daskalov and Mamedov 2007) and resulted in an increase in the average age of the stock and a large decline in total abundance (Mamedov 2006).

Iran

The vast majority of available data regarding the status of Kilka in the Caspian Sea refer to Iranian waters, which likely represents less than 50% of all Kilka in the Caspian Sea. However, there is no reason to believe that it is not representative of the entire region. Since 1996, total landings of Kilka in Iran have declined from 57,000 to 27,602 tonnes, representing an approximate 60.3% decrease (Iranian Fisheries Organization unpublished data).

Additionally, changes to biological characteristics of all species of Kilka, especially C. engrauliformis, were reported in areas impacted by M. leidyi (Parafkandeg Haghighi and Kaymaram 2012) including a sharp decrease in weight, length and condition of individuals (Shiganova et al. 2004).

Specific information regarding the status of the bigeye Kilka, C. grimmi

Azerbaijan

Big-eye Kilka are caught sporadically in the central Caspian Sea and generally represent around 0.5–1.5% of the total Kilka catch. Stocks of this species in Azerbaijan waters have purportedly declined in recent years (Mamedov 2006). For example, in 2004, this species constituted just 0.2–2% of total Kilka catch, which is well below their relative contribution in the 1970s when this species was the second most important Kilka and represented roughly 20% of total Kilka catch (Mamedov 2006).

Iran

Species-specific population data are primarily available from Iran, where C. grimmi has suffered severe population declines in recent years. Overexploitation and the introduction of M. leidyi in 1999 resulted in major reported declines in biomass, catch and CPUE of C. grimmi in Iranian waters. For example, estimated biomass increased from 36,900 metric tonnes in 1995 to 53,500 metric tonnes in 1998, but then declined to less than 5,900 tonnes in 2001 (Fazli et al. 2009), representing an 89 % decline in biomass between 1998 and 2001. Reports indicate that overfishing and the introduction of M. leidyi resulted in the population collapse of this species, and the similar C. engrauliformis in 2002 (Fazli et al. 2009, Fazli and Teghavi Jelodar 2013).

CPUE data are not available for the entire range of the current three generations (10–12 years based on a known age at maturity at 2.5 years and a maximum longevity between 7–8 years); however, CPUE information is available until 2009 (Fazli 2011) and current annual landings data are available (IFRSI unpublished data). Catches of this species reached a peak of about 18,500 tonnes in 1998 (IFRSI unpublished data); during this time CPUE was at its highest reported value for this species at 0.87 metric tonnes per vessel per night (mt/VN: Fazli 2011). After the introduction of M. leidyi in 1999, CPUE fell to just above 0 by 2001 (Fazli 2011) and catches reached the lowest on record in 2002 (26 tonnes: IFRSI unpublished data). Since the lowest CPUE in 2001 and lowest catch in 2002, total catch and CPUE have remained at low levels until 2011 (the most recent years available for CPUE data) aside from an increase in catches (1,048 tonnes) and CPUE (0.08) in 2006 only. For example, the CPUE has remained below 0.1 since the decline in 2001 (Fazli 2011); similarly catches have rarely exceeded 300 tonnes (IFRSI unpublished data). Given the lack of current CPUE data (most recent estimate from 2011), the available data was extrapolated to the present using an exponential regression. Based on this estimate, it is suspected that CPUE has declined by 89–92 % over three generation lengths (10–12 years), which would qualify C. grimmi for Critically Endangered under criterion A2 in Iran.

The only current data available within the most recent 10–12 years are annual landings data from Iran. Bigeye Kilka decreased from about 10,400 tonnes (~18% of total Kilka landings) in 1996 to about 226 tonnes (~ < 1% of total Kilka landings) in 2017 (IFRSI unpublished data). Since the lowest catches in 2002, catches have increased slightly but generally remain below ~300 tonnes with the exception of 2005 – 2007 where catches were about 543, 1,048 and 385 tonnes, respectively (IFRSI unpublished data). Using the total time series for which catches are available, total catch of this species from Iranian waters has declined by an estimated 97.8% between the years 1996–2017. Over the most recent three generation length time window of 10–12 years (from 2006– or 2008–2017), catches are represented by a decline of 21–78%. However, declines calculated over a 12 year period include the year 2006 where catches exceed the average of the most recent 15 years by an order of magnitude (IFRSI unpublished data). Therefore, the estimated decline over 12 years is suspected to be a conservative estimate, while the estimated decline over to most recent 10 years is thought to be more of a true representation of the population decline of this species.

Conversely, there is some anecdotal evidence suggesting a shift in the spatial distribution of fishing vessels in the Caspian Sea that may have resulted in a decline in fishing effort for this species. For example, more recently a larger portion of fishing activities has taken place in shallower water zones with depths less than 50 m, where this species is less available and C. caspia is more available to fisheries (Parafkandeh Haghighi and Kaymaram 2012, Fazli and Taghavi Jelodar 2013). Therefore, it is conservatively suspected that population declines for this species in Iran have exceeded 50% over the past three generation lengths. Although quantitative data are primarily available from Iran, there is no reason to suspect that the situation is any better elsewhere in the Caspian Sea. We therefore suspect that the anchovy Kilka has experienced a global population decline exceeding 50% over the past three generation lengths, which qualifies for Endangered under criterion A2.
range: Clupeonella grimmi is endemic to the Caspian Sea, distributed mostly throughout the mid and southern regions (Whitehead 1985, Esmaeili 2014). Adults of this species occupy depths over 50 - 70 m, down to 450 m, with large schools forming down to approximately 130 m (Aliasghari et al. 2017).
useTrade:
This species supports major commercial fisheries throughout many regions of the Caspian Sea. This species is caught at nighttime using underwater electric lights and fish pumps (Fazli et al. 2009, Aliasghari et al. 2017). 

Azerbaijan is traditionally the most important area for commercial capture of Kilka species in the Caspian Sea (Mamedov 2006). This species is mostly targeted in the southwestern part of the Caspian sea around the Borisov shoal at depths of  30–56 m (1.5–3%) and over the Kornilov - Pavlov shoal at depths of 46–97 m (1.5–3.5%: Mamedov 2006).

In Iran, this species is commercially targeted; catches of all Kilka species are mainly concentrated along the Babolsar and Anzali coasts (Fazli et al. 2007, Parafkandeh Haghighi and Kaymaram 2012). The most recent estimate of exploitation rate for this species is 0.26 in the south Caspian Sea in 2008 (Karimzadeh et al. 2010).

Currently this species is considered to be overexploited in Iranian waters (a large proportion of its range: Aliasghari et al. 2017) despite representing the lowest proportion of total Kilka catch (1% in 2017: Iranian Fisheries Organization unpublished data). In Iranian waters, individuals in the 3–4 year class dominate catches (Aliasghari et al. 2017).

In general, this species is used in local fishmeal industries of Iran. It is also consumed smoked, salted, canned in sauce and oil, and well as marinated, according to a traditional recipe and seasoned with fruits, herbs and vegetables (Alavi-Yegaheh et al. 2017).
conservationActions: No known species-specific conservation measures are in place; however a relatively recent study indicated that the population status of this species is in critical condition (Fazli et al. 2009). In a report prepared for the Caspian Environment Programme in 2001, suggestions of fishing limitations, lab studies and monitoring were made as measures to combat the Mnemiopsis problem. Aliasghari et al. (2017) recommends the increased attention, effort and monitoring of population levels, fishing pressure and influence of M. leidyi on this species. Further recommendations have been made for increased coordinated international effort needed to implement immediate management of Kilka stocks in the Caspian Sea (Fazli et al. 2009, Fazli and Taghavi Jelodar 2013). It has also been suggested that all catches of the three species of Clupeonella must be restricted during spawning periods (Fazli and Taghavi Jelodar 2013).

rationale: This is a marine and estuarine, coastal species that is distributed in the western Pacific, from northern Viet Nam, along the coast of mainland China, to the western Korean Peninsula, including the East China, Yellow and Bohai seas. This species is abundant in Viet Nam and was previously abundant in China. However, in general, it  is threatened by overfishing,  pollution and habitat  degradation caused by large-scale hydrological projects that have disrupted its spawning migrations and decreased survival in several areas. As such, its population  has experienced declines in parts of its range. Where data are available, declines probably exceed  75% over the past ten years (estimated to be more than three generation  lengths for this species) given that it has been nearly, if not  completely extirpated from the Geum River in South Korea and has  experienced at least a 99% decline in the Yangtze estuary. Although  these data reflect only a limited proportion of this species total  range, it is not likely to be in substantially better condition  throughout the remainder of its range given that the area is largely  characterized by heavy exploitation, industrial development and urban  expansion. Based on the documented declines in harvest, it is  conservatively suspected that the population has declined by levels at  least approaching 50%, if not more, in the past 10 years. Therefore,  this species is listed as Endangered under criterion A2bd. Improved  fisheries management and habitat protection are recommended to improve the  status of this anadromous species.
habitat: This species inhabits marine coastal waters and estuaries (Whitehead et al. 1988). Its maximum standard length is 20 cm (Whitehead et al. 1988). In the Yangtze River, it migrates in the spring from marine to estuarine waters to spawn (Yang et al. 2006). In the Yangtze River estuary, it spawns year-round with a peak between March - August and each individual spawns only once (He et al. 2011). He et al. (2008) examined the otoliths of individuals captured in the Yangtze River and found the maximum age to be five years. It is thought that the sex ratio in the Yangtze River population is biased towards females and that males have a slower growth rate (He et al. 2008). He et al. (2011) indicated that the reproductive traits of this population are likely influenced by heavy exploitation. Given the life history parameters of its congener, C. nasus, it is inferred that the generation length of this species is about 3 years.
threats: In the Yangtze River, this species is experiencing threats from over-fishing (especially of juveniles), juvenile occurrence as bycatch, pollution and habitat degradation (Liu et al. 2004, Zhang et al. 2005, Yang et al. 2006, Chen et al. 2009). The Yangtze estuary is greatly impacted by the largest hydropower dam in the world, the Three Gorges Dam, and the largest estuarine hydraulic project in China, the North Passage Deep Water Channel Regulation Engineering. The construction of the dam far upstream in 2003 and dredging and dumping related to the estuarine hydraulic project in 2011 changed materials delivered into the estuary, including the availability of plankton, which is the main food source for this species (Chen et al. 2015). Additionally, this species was previously (1970s) present in the Geum River estuary in South Korea, but has been potentially extirpated from this river after the construction of an estuary barrage in the 1990s despite the inclusion of fish passageways (Yoon et al. 2017).
population:
Currently this species is abundant in Viet Nam (H. Hata pers. comm. 2017). However, in South Korea, this species was collected in the Geum River estuary in the early 1970s, but has not longer been found after the construction of a estuary barrage in the 1990s despite the inclusion of fish passageways (Yoon et al. 2017). As reported in Zhang and Hua 1991, He et al. (2011) reported that this species was the most abundant in late 1990s in China. However, compared with historical data, this species has declined sharply due to overharvesting and water pollution, especially in the Yangtze River (Liu et al. 2004). In the 1970s, this species was heavily exploited in the lower reaches of the Yangtze River and its estuary in China. Annual catches averaged 2000 tons in the 1980s, and represented almost half the total fisheries catch in the area (Zhang and Hua 1991). In the 1990s, fisheries of Jiangsu Province and Shanghai City averaged 2500 tons per year (Ni et al. 1999). This exceeded the estimated maximum sustainable yield, which was 1417 tons (Liu et al. 2004).  More recently, annual catches of this species from the Yangtze estuary have declined (99% decrease) from approximately 1000 to 8.2 tonnes in the years 2003 to 2012 (Chen et al. 2015), a time period thought to exceed three generations for this species as inferred from the similar species Coilia nasus. Fish younger than age two dominate the commercial harvest, many of which have not spawned, or have spawned only once (He et al. 2008). Liang and Pauly (2017) estimated that subpopulations of this species in China have a high total mortality.

Population data area available from scattered localities throughout this species distribution. Where data are available, declines likely exceed 75% over the past ten years (more than three generation lengths for this species) given that it has been nearly, if not completely extirpated from the Geum River in South Korea and has experienced at least a 99% decline in the Yangtze estuary. Although these data reflect only a limited proportion of this species total range, it is not likely to be in substantially better condition throughout the remainder of its range given that the area is largely characterized by heavy exploitation, industrial development and urban expansion (Daoji and Daler 2004, Zhao et al. 2006, Cheung 2015). Therefore, it is conservatively suspected that the decline has at least exceeded 50% over the past ten years.
range: This species occurs in the western Pacific from northern Viet Nam along the coast of mainland China to the western Korean Peninsula (H. Hata pers. comm. 2017), including the East China, Yellow, and Bohai seas. Specimens collected from Phuket Island in Thailand are doubtful (H. Hata pers. comm. 2017). This species can be found at a maximum depth of 10 m.
useTrade: Previously, this species supported fisheries in the Yangtze River contributing considerable amounts annually (Liang and Pauly 2017). Currently, it still supports an important fishery (Yang et al. 2006), but only a few tonnes are contributed (Liang and Pauly 2017).
conservationActions: No known species-specific conservation measures are in place. Chen et al. (2009) recommended protection of larval and juvenile individuals and their habitats in the surf wave zone along the banks of the Yangtze estuary in order to help rebuild adult stocks. He et al. (2008) also recommended the reduction of fishing effort in the Yangtze Estuary during the early spawning season as to increase the proportion of older females remaining in the population.

rationale: Coilia nasus is an andromous, coastal species that is relatively widely distributed in the western Pacific from Caton, China, north throughout the Yellow and Bohai seas, and off the Korean Peninsula. There is also a small subpopulation within Ariake Bay, Japan. Given the life history characteristics of this species, it is inferred that the generation length is about 3 years. Previously (prior to 2000's), this species was abundant and commercially important in Chinese Rivers (i.e., the Yangtze and Yellow rivers); however, it has been heavily exploited in both China and Japan. In addition, large-scale hydrological projects have caused habitat degradation, disrupted its spawning migration and decreased its survivability in several areas. Where data are available, declines likely exceed 75% over the past ten years (more than three generation lengths for this species) given that it has been listed as Endangered on the Japanese Red List represented by a 50 - 70 % decline, and has been nearly extirpated from both the Yellow and the Yangtze rivers. Although these data reflect only a small proportion of this species total range, it is not likely to be in substantially better condition throughout the remainder of its range given that this area is largely characterized by heavy exploitation, industrial development and urban expansion. Based on the documented declines in harvest, as well as declines in average size of the catch and truncated age-structure, it is conservatively suspected that the population has declined by at least 50 % in the past 10 years. Therefore, this species is listed as Endangered under criterion A2bd. Improved fisheries management and habitat protection are needed to improve the status of this anadromous species.
habitat: This anadromous species inhabits coastal marine, estuarine and riverine waters (Whitehead et al. 1988). It spends its first year in freshwater and then enters brackish/marine waters as far as 300 km from the coast (Jiang et al. 2012). In Japan, it spawns in freshwater from May-August by running up the Chikugo River and eggs hatch near the river mouth (Takita 1967). Its maximum standard length is 41 cm and reaches sexual maturity at the age of 1–2 years with a longevity of 4-5 years (Yuen et al. 1978). Given these life history parameters, it is inferred that the generation length is about 3 years for this species.
threats: This species is heavily exploited in both China and Japan, with near extirpation observed in the Yangtze River (Zhang et al. 2005) and a potential extirpation in the Yellow River (Liu et al. 2016). In addition, large-scale hydrological projects have caused habitat degradation, disrupted its spawning migration and decreased its survivability in the Yangtze and Yellow Rivers (Chen et al. 2015, Jiang et al. 2016, Liu et al. 2016). The Yangtze estuary is greatly impacted by the largest hydropower dam in the world, the Three Gorges Dam, and the largest estuarine hydraulic project in China, the North Passage Deep Water Channel Regulation Engineering. The construction of the dam far upstream in 2003 along with dredging and dumping related to the estuarine hydraulic project in 2011, changed materials delivered into the estuary, including the availability of plankton, which is the main food source for this species (Chen et al. 2015). Furthermore, the most important spawning ground in the Yellow River is now mostly disconnected from the river channel due to hydrological manipulation (Liu et al. 2016).
population:
The Chinese and Japanese populations do not mix, and are genetically separated, but there is high gene flow between northwestern Chinese populations including the Yellow River, Nantong, Ningbo and Wenzhou (Yang et al. 2012). In the Yangtze River, there are both anadromous and landlocked populations (e.g., Taihu Lake: Cheng et al. 2005).

Previously, this species was abundant and represented an important commercial fishery in the Yellow River (Cai et al. 1980); however, this species is now so rare that fishers now catch only a few individuals per year and a 2008 survey failed to record this species (Liu et al. 2016). Declines in the Yellow River are due to exploitation and habitat degradation and modification by large-scale hydrological projects. In particular, frequent long-duration cease-to-flow events in the 1990s restricted the upstream spawning migrations of Coilia nasus and isolated mature adults from their preferred spawning grounds.

Zhang et al. (2005) reported the MSY as 2,062 tons in the lower reaches of the Yangtze River and that its subpopulation has been nearly extirpated from the middle reaches. The study also found that the body size of this fish has decreased over time and the age structure of the subpopulation was truncated due to overexploitation. In the Yangtze River, the average harvest per boat during the fishing season decreased from 285 tons (2002) to only 1.2 tons (2010: Liu et al. 2012). From 1998-2012, total catch declined from 208 tons to 7 tons, which represents a 97% decline over a period of 14 years. The lowest recorded catch of C. mystus occurred in 2011 and 2012 with 10 and 7 tons (Chen et al. 2015). As a result of this decline in the river, marketed individuals are now mostly sourced from marine waters (Zhong et al. 2007).

Population decline data are available from scattered localities throughout this species distribution. Where data are available, declines likely exceed 75% over the past ten years (more than three generation lengths for this species), given that it has been listed as Endangered on the Japanese Red List (represented by a decline of 50 - 70 %), and has been nearly extirpated from both the Yellow and the Yangtze rivers. Although these data reflect only a small proportion of this species total range, it is not likely to be in substantially better condition throughout the remainder of its range given that this area is largely characterised by heavy exploitation, industrial development and urban expansion (Daoji and Daler 2004, Zhao et al. 2006, Cheung 2015). Therefore, it is conservatively suspected that the global population decline has at least exceeded 50 % over the past 10 years.
range: This species occurs in the western Pacific from Canton, China, north along the mainland coast to the Yellow and Bohai seas. It has been reported up to 1,000 km up the Yangtze River in China. In Japan, this species is known only from Ariake Bay. Coilia nasus is easily confused with the co-occurring C. mystus (Whitehead et al. 1988). Depth information for this species is not known; however, based on data from other related species, it is estimated to be within 0 - 50 m.
useTrade: This species is heavily exploited in Japan during its spawning season in the Chikugo River and near its mouth in the Ariake Sound (Whitehead et al. 1988). It also supports an important and valuable fishery in the Yangtze and Yellow Rivers, China (Cai et al. 1980, Whitehead et al. 1988). Given this species large size, it is a more esteemed food fish than other species of Coilia (Whitehead et al. 1988). The price of this species taken from the Yangtze River was more than US$ 1,000 per kilogram in 2011 (Yang et al. 2012).
conservationActions: No species-specific conservation measures are in place. Improvements in fishery management are needed. It is listed as Endangered in the Japanese Red List of Threatened Fishes (Ministry of the Environment 2012).

rationale:
The Pacific Nurse Shark (Ginglymostoma unami) is a medium-sized (to 280 cm total length) shark that occurs in the Eastern Central and Southeast Pacific from the Gulf of California, Mexico, to Peru. It inhabits rocky and coral reefs, channels between mangrove keys, and sand flats on continental and insular shelves from the surface to 13 m depth.

This shark is captured in artisanal gillnet and longline fisheries, which are intense and largely unmanaged throughout its range. Formerly, it was common in the Gulf of California in the 1980s, but has become rare there. For example, extensive surveys of multiple landings sites in 1998–1999 did not encounter this species. In Guatemala, the species was more common in fisheries in the past; there are some records from the 1990s and 2000s, but there have been none recently. In Costa Rica, this shark remains common, particularly in protected areas. In Colombia, there are few historic records of this species, and can be considered scarce. Artisanal fishing pressure is intense over much of its range and it lacks management; a population reduction is suspected. In addition, mangrove habitats, which often serve as nursery areas for nurse sharks, have been degraded with the development of shrimp aquaculture in many areas of the Eastern Central Pacific.

Overall, given the intense fishing pressure through most of its range, its likely limited biological productivity, relative rarity in recent decades, and the degradation of coastal mangrove habitats, balanced with occurrence in some protected areas, it is suspected that the Pacific Nurse Shark has undergone a population reduction of 50–79% over the past three generations (90 years), and it is assessed as Endangered A2cd.
habitat: The Pacific Nurse Shark inhabits rocky and coral reefs, channels between mangrove keys, and sand flats on continental and insular shelves from the surface to 13 m depth (although it probably occurs deeper than this) (Ebert et al. 2013, Weigman 2016). It reaches a maximum size of 280 cm total length (TL) (Weigmann 2016). Life history parameters are poorly-known, but can be inferred to be similar to the Atlantic Nurse Shark (Ginglymostoma cirratum): reproduction is lecithotrophic viviparous, gestation period of 5–6 months, biennial reproductive cycle, litter size up to 50 pups (mean of 34), male age-at-maturity of 10–15 years, female age-at-maturity of 15–20 years (Carrier 1991, Carrier and Luer 1990, Castro 2000, Compagno 2001). Generation length is estimated to be 30 years.
threats: This shark is captured in artisanal and commercial gillnet and longline fisheries, which are intense and unmanaged across its range. This shark has been suggested to have a medium to high susceptibility to fishing (Furlong-Estrada et al. 2014, Saldaña-Ruiz et al. 2017), and its large size and slow life history suggest it is sensitive to fishing pressure. Fisheries ramped up considerably in the Gulf of California in the 1980s and 1990s, with an increase in the number of fishers, vessels, and nets in the water; depletion of large pelagic sharks and other species occurred, and caused fishers to turn to coastal species (Sala et al. 2004). Off Mazatlan, Mexico, unmanaged gillnet and longline fisheries targeting sharks arose prior to the 1960s (Kato 1965). In Nayarit, Mexico, this shark is caught in low numbers in artisanal gillnets and longlines targeting sharks (Pérez-Jiménez et al. 2005). In Costa Rica, this species is caught rarely in artisanal fisheries but appears to remain relatively common in dive records and in protected areas (M. Espinoza unpubl. data 2019). Across much of its Central and South American range, artisanal fisheries are ongoing and are inadequately managed. Mangrove habitats, which often serve as nursery areas for nurse sharks, have been degraded with the development of shrimp aquaculture in many areas of the Eastern Central Pacific (López-Angarita et al. 2016).
population: Formerly (in the 1980s), this shark was common in the Gulf of California, but it has generally been encountered at low frequency in the artisanal fishery (Saldaña-Ruiz et al. 2017). Catches have however, become scarcer; for example, extensive surveys of multiple landings sites in 1998–1999 did not encounter this species (Bizzarro et al. 2009). In Guatemala, it was more common in fisheries in the past, as there are some records from the 1990s and 2000s (Ruiz-Alvarado and Mijangos-Lopez 1999, Ixquiac et al. 2009), but there have been none recently (C. Avalos unpubl. data 2019). In Costa Rica, this shark remains common, particularly in protected areas (M. Ezpinoza unpubl. data 2019). In Colombia, there are few historic records of this species, and can be considered scarce. Artisanal fishing pressure is intense over much of its range and it lacks management. Overall, given the intense fishing pressure through most of its range, the species' apparent limited biological productivity, and its relative rarity in recent decades in some areas, it is suspected that the Pacific Nurse Shark has undergone a population reduction of 50–79% over the past three generations (90 years).
range: The Pacific Nurse Shark occurs in the Eastern Central and Southeast Pacific from western Baja California and the Gulf of California, Mexico to Peru (Ebert et al. 2013 [as the Eastern Pacific range of G. cirratum], Morales-Flores et al. 2015).
useTrade: This shark is retained and the meat is consumed fresh or salted and dried locally, fins are traded internationally, and skins are used for leather. In Pacific Colombia, this species has a lower commercial value than other shark species (Mejía-Falla et al. 2017).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific protections or conservation actions in place for this shark. In the Mexican Pacific, there is a closed season for targeted elasmobranch fishing  from May 1st to July 31st, but enforcement is inadequate (O.  Sosa-Nishizaki unpubl. data 2019). A temporal ban of shrimp trawl fisheries is established in Colombia (January to March) but enforcement is also inadequate (Mejía-Falla and Navia 2017). Additionally, targeted industrial fishing of sharks and rays is prohibited in Colombia, with set bycatch limits (up to 35% of bycatch in the national territory; Resolution 1743 of 2017); however, surveillance and compliance requires strengthening. To conserve the population and permit recovery, a suite of measures will be required which will need to include species protection, spatial management, bycatch mitigation, and harvest management, all of which will be dependent on effective enforcement. Further research is needed on life  history and population size and trends. Species-specific monitoring of  catch is needed in artisanal gillnet and longline fisheries.

rationale: This shallow reef species is known only from the 53 specimens collected from southern Taiwan in 1968 and 1978. It occurs in very specific, shallow water habitat in southern Taiwan, which may be impacted coastal development and cyclones. This species has not been collected for more than 40 years, despite more active collections in the Ryukus and other areas. This indicates that this species has a very restricted range. It has an AOO of 316 km<sup>2 </sup>and EOO = 1,800 km<sup>2 </sup>and has only been collected from 7 sites. These sites are very close together in Kenting National Park, which is threatened by severe cyclones and if this species occurs outside of the park, it is also threatened by coastal development. Given its AOO of less than 500 km<sup>2</sup>, that it is known from fewer than 5 locations, and that its extent and quality of habitat is threatened, it is listed as Endangered under B1ab(iii)+2ab(iii). However, if the known distribution of this species is expanded in the future (greater than 500 km<sup>2</sup>), then it should be reassessed and possibly placed into a lower threat category.
habitat: This species inhabits shallow rocky and coral reefs, and may prefer surge channels cut well back into the shore. Its maximum standard length is 2.2 cm (Greenfield and Jewett 2014).
threats: This species' habitat in southern Taiwan may be impacted coastal development and cyclones; however, it appears all collections may have occurred in Kenting National Park.
population: This species is only known from 53 type specimens collected in 1968 and 1978 (Greenfield and Jewett 2014); as such, little is known on its population.
range: This species has only been collected from southern Taiwan (Kenting National Park) at the following 7 sites: Pingtung Co., just south of Chin-Chiao-Wan (21.9208 N, 120.8292 E), Ch’uan-fan-shih (21.9300 N, 120.8133 E and 21.9451 N, 120.7845 E), Sha-toa (21.9758 N, 120.7157 E and 120.9167 N, 120.8333 E), Mao-pi T’ou (21.9222 N, 120.7361 E) and K’en ting (21.9392 N, 120.8049 E). It has been collected between 0-13 m depth (Greenfield and Jewett 2014). The AOO for this species is estimated to be 316 km<sup>2</sup> and EOO is estimated to be 1,800 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for E. aquila. It appears that all collections are from Kenting National Park in southern Taiwan.

rationale: Amblyeleotris neglecta is a recently described shrimp-goby known from relatively few specimens and photograph records from the Gulf of Aqaba, northern Red Sea. Given its shallow depth range and limited distribution, AOO for this species is estimated to be 1,304 km2 with an EOO of 4,130 km2, it is only known from one location, and has experienced habitat degradation from pollution and alteration, it is listed as Endangered under criterion B1ab(iii). However, if the known distribution of this species is expanded in the future, then it should be reassessed and potentially placed into a lower threat category.
habitat: This species has only been reported living as commensals in the burrows of shrimps of the genus Alpheus at depths of 15-33 m (Jaafar and Randall 2009). The largest type specimen was about 5.4 cm total length (Jaafar and Randall 2009). It occurs over coarse sand and gravel, in areas of seagrass and small, sparse coralheads (Jaffar and Randall 2009).
threats: This species has only been recorded from a single location in the vicinity of a desalination plant, which is a source of pollution and habitat alteration. Although the desalination plant has recently been decommissioned, the shallow waters off the coast of Eliat have been impacted by pollution and habitat degradation from a number of other sources, including tourism and fish-rearing cages along the north beach of Eliat (Al-Rousan et al.2016, Chaidez et al. 2017, Mohamed 2018).
population: It is known from the three type specimens and one photograph from the Gulf of Aqaba (Jaafar and Randall 2009). No further population data are available.
range: This newly described shrimp-goby is known only from the Gulf of Aqaba, northern Red Sea (Jaafar and Randall 2009, Freinschlag and Patzner 2012). It may be more widely distributed than is currently known. It has been recorded at depths from 15-33.5 m (Jaffar and Randall 2009). The AOO for this species is estimated to be 1,304 km<sup>2</sup> with an EOO of 4,130 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: This species is not thought to be utilized.
conservationActions: No species-specific conservation measures are in place.

rationale: This species is known from two islands in the Raja Ampat Islands of Indonesia and can be common. Part of its range occurs in the Raja Ampat Marine Protected Area; however, only 1 location (Batanta Island) is within the protected area, while the other location (Pef Island off of Gam Island) is found outside the marine protected area. As this species lives around live branching corals, its habitat outside the protected area is under threat from local impacts (pollution, siltation, transportation, coastal development and degradation from fisheries impacts), while both locations are impacted by regional oceanographic changes associated with climate change. The calculated AOO for this species is 432 km<sup>2</sup> and EOO = 2,615 km<sup>2</sup>. Given that the AOO is less than 500 km<sup>2 </sup>and that the EOO is less than 5,000 km<sup>2</sup>, that it is known from fewer than 5 locations, and that it is experiencing a decline in the extent and quality of its habitats, this species is listed as Endangered under B1ab(iii)+2ab(iii). However, if the known distribution of this species is expanded in the future, then it should be reassessed and placed into a lower threat category.
habitat: This species occurs in small groups near or among branching corals on sheltered reef slopes. Its maximum total length is 3 cm (Allen and Erdmann 2012).
threats: This species' coral reef habitat is under threat from local impacts (pollution, siltation, transportation, coastal development and degradation from fisheries impacts) as well as regional oceanographic changes associated with climate change.
population: There is no population information available. This species can be common in sheltered waters with rich coral growth (Donnelly et al. 2003).
range: This species is known from Pef and Batanta islands in the Raja Ampat Islands, West Papua, Indonesia. Its depth range is 0-12 m (Greenfield and Jewett 2011, Allen and Erdmann 2012). The AOO for this species is estimated to be 432 km<sup>2</sup> and EOO is estimated be 2,615 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures.

rationale:
Anguilla dieffenbachii is a catadromous, semelparous species with multiple life stages, and is assumed to be panmictic. These life history traits, coupled with the limited information available to infer abundance trends, pose particular challenges in applying the IUCN Red List Categories and Criteria (Jacoby et al. 2015). Ideally, the IUCN Red List criteria would be applied to mature eels at their spawning grounds, and in the absence of such data, silver eels starting their spawning migration as these represent the maximum estimate of spawning stock biomass, but such data sets are rarely available. Analysis conducted on fisheries and monitoring data for glass eels, yellow eels and silver eels were reviewed in the present assessment, but the relationships between recruitment, yellow eel populations, silver eel escapement, and spawner stock biomass are poorly understood. As such, the IUCN Red List criteria must be applied to an amalgamation of multiple life stages, which provides the current best estimate of the population status.

Anguilla dieffenbachii is endemic to New Zealand, and found on both North and South Islands, as well as Chatham and Stewart offshore Islands. Anguilla dieffenbachii is slow growing, and can be long-lived to a large size, dependent on environmental factors, meaning there is a reduced likelihood of reaching sexual maturity, longer exposure to threats, and increased vulnerability to certain threats (e.g. ease of capture).

Catch Per Unit Effort (CPUE) data are available for A. dieffenbachii from both the North Island and South Island, where catch is of yellow eels—there is no targeted silver eel fishery, with exception of silver male A. australis from Te Waihora (Beentjes and Dunn 2013, Beentjes and McKenzie 2017). On both islands, CPUE initially declined since data gathering began in 1990–91, before increases or no trend were seen in the North Island after 2002 and increases in the South Island after introduction of the Quota Management System (QMS) in 2000. The introduction of Total Allowable Catch (TAC) and Total Allowable Commercial Catch (TACC) were believed to contribute to the CPUE increases seen in the North Island, as well as other contributors, such as low market prices, reduction in number of fishers and processing factories, increased escapement tube sizes, and voluntary non-targeting. Models have shown only a few females survive to spawn even at relatively low rates of fishing pressure, with reductions in spawning per recruit of 83% and 96.5% from unfished levels, at an annual exploitation rate of 5% and 10%, respectively (Hoyle and Jellyman 2002). As such, A. dieffenbachii are particularly vulnerable to over-exploitation.

A number of data sources have suggested a historic decline in A. dieffenbachii recruitment has occurred. In three coastal streams across New Zealand; Pigeon Bay, Horokiwi Stream, and Te Maari Stream, the average rate of decline in glass eel recruitment was calculated, with a conservative estimate suggesting a decline of 77% between 1980 and 2000 (Jellyman et al. 2000). Although this was based only on three streams, the positioning of them across both North and South Islands (Middle and Southern North Island, Middle South Island), suggests it would be reasonable to infer the results may represent the status across the country. For the Arahura River, models indicated a 5% per year decline over several decades (Jellyman et al. 2000). In the Waikato River, sampling of glass eels in 2004 and 2005 was compared with historical catches (1970–1974) of glass eels from the same area. The proportion of A. dieffenbachii in sampling from 2004 was 3% compared to 12% in the 1970s (Jellyman 1979, Jellyman et al. 2009). Pre-1995 recruitment data has however been reported to be unreliable (Fisheries New Zealand 2018), and the most recent data on recruitment, between 1995 and 2015, shows large fluctuations with no consistent trend, suggesting the historic decline has ceased (Jellyman 2012, Martin and Bowman 2016). Surveys conducted between 1996 and 2010 to determine size distribution of eels in New Zealand found that the proportion of elvers in smaller length classes (50–99 mm) was much lower than that of a healthy size distribution for this species (Jellyman 2012, PCE 2013). The relationship between life-stages is poorly understood, but it is generally agreed that it is likely that low recruitment will ultimately translate, though not linearly, to reduced future escapement. The effects of which, due to the longevity of the species, may yet to be seen (Jellyman 2009).

There are less data estimating the trend for yellow eel and silver eel life stages. Records collected from the New Zealand Freshwater Fish Database (NZFFD) (in Crow et al. 2016) identified a decline in an index of relative abundance from 1977 to 2015 for A. dieffenbachii. It has also been estimated that silver eel escapement (t) has declined by 80% from levels in the 1920s to that in 2008 (Graynoth et al. 2008b). Studies have suggested that a substantial proportion of A. dieffenbachii is located in reserves or rarely fished areas (Graynoth et al. 2008b, Beentjes et al. 2016) but this may not have always been the case, and the protection achieved by national reserves is not absolute, due to the eventual migration to the sea (McDowall 1990). Habitat loss, resulting from wetland drainage may have also resulted in A. dieffenbachii population reductions. Since human settlement in the 1840s, to the mid-1970s, total wetland habitat has declined by 85%, from 670,000 ha to 100,000 ha (Taylor and Smith 1997, Beentjes et al. 2005, PCE 2013; Jellyman 2007, 2012, 2016). A number of sources have also estimated that anthropogenic barriers (e.g. hydro-dams) have reduced access to large areas of riverine habitat, that would otherwise be capable of supporting significant numbers of eels (Beentjes et al. 2005, Boubée et al. 2008, Graynoth et al. 2008b, Jellyman and Harding 2012). Under the New Zealand Threat Classification Series, A. dieffenbachii has been assessed as ‘At Risk – Declining’ a category that is both conservation dependent and based on limited data (Dunn et al. 2018). It is however stated that: "The panel also notes that public discourse on the longfin eel portrays the species as being severely threatened despite data that indicate otherwise" (Dunn et al. 2018). It is reported that abundance of A. dieffenbachii is stable or increasing in commercial fisheries, although there is still concern over continuing habitat degradation (Dunn et al. 2018).

Based on available information, A. dieffenbachii has been listed as Endangered (EN) (A2bd). Available data suggest recruitment underwent a sharp decline from historic levels, however; there is indication that this decline has ceased, perhaps as a result of management actions. Escapement has been estimated to have declined substantially from the levels in the 1920s compared to that in 2008. Further, there has been a significant reduction in available habitat over three generation lengths (102 years). Due to the vulnerability of the species and its long generation length, discussions were had as to whether this species falls within the Critically Endangered (CR) category, but this was felt not to be warranted, at present. It is strongly advised that management actions relating to anthropogenic threats continue and monitoring and data collection is strengthened to better determine population status. As with all anguillids, co-ordination of the management across this species’ range will also be pivotal for conservation.

Assessment of this species was carried out during a workshop held at the Zoological Society of London from the 5th–9th November 2018.
habitat:
There are a number of phases in an eel’s life that have specific terminology; the leaf-shaped marine larval stage is referred to as leptocephalus; these become glass eels as they reach continental waters, before developing into pigmented elvers and then the growth phase: the yellow eel. The final stage is the marine-migratory silver eel which is characterised by silvery counter-shading and large eyes.

Anguilla dieffenbachii is the largest freshwater fish found in New Zealand, and arguably the largest species of the genus Anguilla (Arai et al. 2004, Graynoth and Niven 2004, Jellyman and Unwin 2017). This species is slow-growing, averaging 20–30 mm per year, and reaches a maximum size of 2 m weighing up to 50 kg, although this was more common historically (Chisnall 2000; Jellyman 2007, 2012; Jellyman and Unwin 2017). More recently, few are found at lengths exceeding 1200 mm and weights of >25 kg (Chisnall 2000, Jellyman 2012). The growth rate of A. dieffenbachii has been found to vary across habitats, with the fastest occurring in rivers with low population density and high food availability (Chisnall 2000). The fastest growth was recorded in the Waikato River hydro reserve (160 mm/year) whilst slower growth has been recorded in indigenous forest streams and high-country lakes (12 and 11 mm/year, respectively) (Chisnall 2000). In another high-country lake, Lake Rotoiti, the slowest mean growth rate was recorded at 9 mm/year (Jellyman 1995).

Anguilla dieffenbachii has been described as an ecological generalist, due to its opportunistic feeding, and ability to inhabit a wide range of environments from estuaries to upper reaches of river systems, although this species does show preference to certain habitats (Glova et al. 1998, Jellyman 2012). It has previously been known to tolerate poor water quality, including low levels of dissolved oxygen and higher temperatures, although is more commonly found in stony-bottomed rivers with clear water (Arai et al. 2004, Jellyman 2012, PCE 2013). Smaller A. dieffenbachii, <300 mm, showed habitat preferences to downstream reaches with high abundance of algae and invertebrates, with coarse sediment. For larger individuals, >300 mm, substrate was an important characteristic, as well as cover e.g. debris, plant, bank, surface, but algae and invertebrate abundance were not (Jellyman et al. 2003). There is some overlap between the habitat of A. dieffenbachii and A. australis, although A. australis is found predominantly in lowland areas (Arai et al. 2004, Sagar et al. 2005, Jellyman 2012). Juveniles of both species prefer shallow water, although A. australis shows preference for slow flowing water with a fine substrate, whilst A. dieffenbachii prefers faster flow with coarse substrate (Jellyman 2007, 2012). Large A. dieffenbachii prefer deep water (> 1 m) with slower water velocity (< 0.2 m/s) and cover in the form of banks or tree roots (Graynoth and Niven 2004). Anguilla dieffenbachii is a nocturnal feeder, with a diet that includes a wide range of aquatic invertebrates and has also been observed to feed on small fish, including juvenile brown trout (Cadwallader 1975, Jellyman 1996 in Sagar et al. 2005, Doole 2005). Anguilla dieffenbachii and A. australis show dietary overlap, so differences in habitat preference is the mechanism thought to reduce interspecific competition between the species (Sagar et al. 2005). Anguilla reinhardtii also shows overlap with A. australis and A. dieffenbachii in both life history, although more so with A. dieffenbachii in ecology (Chisnall 2000). The faster growth rate of A. reinhardtii may mean it is competitive with A. dieffenbachii as a top predator (Chisnall 2000).

Anguilla dieffenbachii is catadromous, feeding and growing in continental waters before embarking on a seaward migration to spawn (Doole 2005, Graynoth et al. 2008a, Jellyman et al. 2009, Stuart et al. 2018). Studies using otolith microchemistry have found A. dieffenbachii to exhibit behavioural plasticity in regard to life history, with an ability to adapt to various habitats and salinities (Arai et al. 2003, 2004). Anguilla dieffenbachii is long-lived; ages at migration differ between males and females, with males averaging 25 years, and females >40 (Jellyman 2012, PCE 2013). A review by Jellyman (2007), estimated mean age of silver A. dieffenbachii females in various regions across the North and South Islands. Average age across the regions was 43.5, although more data were available for the South Island where growth is slower (Jellyman 2007). Eels of substantial ages at spawning migration have been recorded; in a glacial-formed South Island lake containing cool water, the mean age of maturing female A. dieffenbachii was 93 years, and the oldest feeding yellow A. dieffenbachii was over 100 years old (Jellyman 1995). Assessment of available data on generation length highlighted that factors such as longitude and latitude, sex and habitat quality can affect this metric. Thirty-four years was agreed upon after analysis.

Environmental variables have been shown to influence migration. Increases in rainfall and flow have been suggested as key factors. Emigration of female A. dieffenbachii from Lake Manapouri generally took place during large outflows (Jellyman and Unwin 2017). Although, it has been also been suggested that flow and lake level only have a weak correlation with eels caught during migration (Stuart et al. 2018). Boubée et al. (2001) found 60% of the migrant eels arriving at Lake Aniwhenua was attributed to rainfall exceeding a cumulative total of 40 mm over three days. This study also found migrations generally began as water temperatures declined in autumn, and ended when the temperature dropped below 11°C.
