Such rainfall and flow triggers could be used as predictors to commence mitigation activities that would allow mature eels to proceed uninjured past barriers such as hydro-electric dams (Boubée et al. 2001). Migration to sea occurs within a two to three-month period for A. dieffenbachii, with male migration occurring sooner (March-April) than females (April-June) (Todd 1981 in Jellyman and Unwin 2017).

Anguilla dieffenbachii exhibits diel vertical migration movement during its spawning migration. A study of three individuals displayed frequent dives to >600 m (max. 980 m), with two individuals ascending to 150–200 m, and the other returning to depths between 1 and 10 m (Jellyman and Tsukamoto 2005). This pattern of migration was assumed to be in response to thermoregulation—eels were found to often spend time in 5–6°C water—and to avoid predation (Jellyman and Tsukamoto 2005).

Anguilla dieffenbachii is assumed to exhibit panmixia, with the genetic structure indicating derivation from a single spawning population (Smith et al. 2001; Jellyman 2007, 2012). Exact location of spawning is yet unknown, although research conducted using pop-up tags deployed on migrating females has suggested migration to tropical waters occurs, with subsequent spawning in an area lying east of New Caledonia, possibly in the south Fiji basin (Jellyman and Tsukamoto 2005, 2010). This species is believed to be semelparous, spawning only once in its lifetime before dying (Doole 2005, Fisheries New Zealand 2018). Leaf-shaped are passively transported via currents back to New Zealand, a process that is thought to occur over eight to ten months (Graynoth et al. 2008a, Fisheries New Zealand 2018). On reaching estuaries and river mouths between August and November, larvae have metamorphosed into glass eels (Fisheries New Zealand 2018). The mean size of glass eels of A. dieffenbachii when they recruit to the New Zealand coast is 66.8 mm (Arai et al. 2004). Environmental variables have been shown to effect glass eel/elver migrations. In the Tukituki River, Hawke Bay, glass eels displayed a preference for water temperatures between 12–20°C for migration, with an optimum of 16.5°C (August and Hicks 2008). Temperatures lower than 12°C and above 22°C were found to depress glass eel catches (August and Hicks 2008). Elver migration into Lake Pounui was affected by seasonal rainfall, with the largest migrations occurring during the greatest seasonal rainfall, and the smallest migrations occurring at the lowest seasonal rainfall (Jellyman and Ryan 1983).

Note: Within the IUCN Habitat Classification Scheme table, most listed habitats are considered important for eels. The Marine Oceanic habitats were listed as ‘Major Importance’ due to there likely being a discrete spawning area.
threats:
Anguilla dieffenbachii, as with all anguillid eels, is susceptible to a number of, primarily anthropogenic, threats. These threats include but are not limited to; barriers to migration, climate change, habitat degradation, invasive species, parasitism, pollution, predation and unsustainable exploitation. The significance of any single threat, or the synergy it may have with other threats is still poorly understood (Jacoby et al. 2015). It is therefore important to highlight, that management measures focusing on a single threat, in isolation of other identified pressures, are less likely to have a significant positive effect on eel abundance. All anguillids are catadromous and semelparous, migrating from continental waters to the ocean to breed, and spawning only once before death. These traits arguably increase the impact of threats, through the terminal nature of reproduction and exposing them to pressures in both freshwater and marine environments. For A. dieffenbachii, other aspects of life history make this species particularly vulnerable. Anguilla dieffenbachii is endemic, meaning the population is reliant solely from escapement occurring from New Zealand (Jellyman 2012, Hoyle 2016). The species is long-lived, and slow-growing to a large size, with a reduced likelihood of reaching sexual maturity, longer exposure to threats, and making the species more vulnerable to certain threats e.g. ease of capture (Jellyman 2012, PCE 2013, Jellyman and Unwin 2017). Ultimately, like other temperate anguillids, the adaptive capacity of this species is seemingly being outpaced by the cumulative effect of the threats posed upon it (Drouineau et al. 2018).

Large scale commercial yellow and silver eel fisheries began in New Zealand in the 1960s (PCE 2013, Hoyle 2016, Fisheries New Zealand 2018). Glass eels were experimentally caught in the 1970s, although this did not last past the 1980s as once large glass eel recruitment events are now infrequent (Jellyman 2012, Tagried Kurwie pers. comm. 2018). Most recent landings proportions from the 2015–16 fishing year showed A. dieffenbachii to make up around 19% of New Zealand’s total commercial eel catch (Fisheries New Zealand 2018). Historically, A. dieffenbachii has made up a larger proportion of catch (46% in 1992-93) however this has reduced as a result of declining abundance, quotas, market demand and closed areas (Fisheries New Zealand 2018). It has been suggested that the reduction in abundance of larger eels is partly attributed to the effects of commercial fishing (Jellyman 2012, PCE 2013). Hoyle and Jellyman (2002) stated that fisheries for adult eels can severely affect the escapement for this species, and that management should be conservative. A study by Chisnall (1994) investigated the effects of fishing pressure in the Ahirau stream, an unexploited pastoral stream in Waikato, containing both A. australis and A. dieffenbachii. In the unexploited stream, prior to the removal of marketable sized eels, the dominant biomass was large A. dieffenbachii, which were found largely within pools. Anguilla australis mainly inhabited shallower, faster flowing areas and were found in greater numbers, although in much smaller sizes, possibly due to territorial behaviour by A. dieffenbachii excluding A. australis from pools (Chisnall 1994). After the initial removal of eels, it was found that A. australis had a greater abundance and penetrated further upstream, and very few A. dieffenbachii were caught, including few elvers, showing little recovery and possibly poor recruitment (Chisnall 1994). It was concluded that commercial fishing pressure represents more of a threat to A. dieffenbachii than to A. australis, due to their ease of capture (Chisnall 1994). Anguilla dieffenbachii may have previously dominated eel populations within the Waikato prior to exploitation, which has seemingly reduced the density and biomass of this species (Chisnall 1994). However, in the sites where A. dieffenbachii were recruited, interspecific competition favoured A. dieffenbachii, and the density and biomass of A. australis was reduced (Chisnall 1994).

Catch of glass eels in New Zealand is illegal, and so catch reports are of yellow and, to a lesser extent, silver eels. Although not a legislative requirement, there are no targeted fisheries for silver eels in New Zealand (Jellyman 2007). This is due to capture being difficult at high flow periods when most migrate and voluntary bans among fishers to support the sustainability of the stock (Jellyman 2007). As well as this, minimum and maximum weight limits of 220 g (since 1992) and 4 kg (since 1995 for South Island and 2007 for North Island), respectively, are in place to prevent catch of migrating silver eels (Jellyman 2012, Fisheries New Zealand 2018). In the early 1990s, there were 23 licensed eel processing factories operating, in 2012 there were only four or five remaining (Jellyman 2012). Present day fishing methods mostly involve the use of fyke nets, which are baited when targeting A. dieffenbachii (Jellyman 2012). The concern over the long-term sustainability of A. dieffenbachii harvest, has resulted in an increase in reserve areas, reductions in TACC and changes to minimum size (Jellyman 2012, PCE 2013). Māori have frequently expressed concern that commercial fishing has compromised their own ability to harvest sufficient quantities of large eels for ceremonial purposes and in recognition of the reduced availability of A. dieffenbachii in some areas, Māori are voluntarily not fishing their Annual Catch Entitlement (ACE) for this species (Jellyman 2012).

Development of hydropower within the habitat of A. dieffenbachii has been shown to have detrimental effects on the population. As this species is known to travel further inland, dams and weirs have impeded both upstream and downstream migrations, reducing the amount of available habitat (Beentjes et al. 2005, Boubée et al. 2008, Graynoth et al. 2008b, Jellyman 2012). In present times, migrant females are more commonly found to occur in small streams or reserves, whilst they were historically derived from large rivers and lakes (Graynoth et al. 2008b). An extreme example comes from Lake Manapouri, home to the largest unexploited population of A. dieffenbachii (Boubée et al. 2008, Graynoth et al. 2008b, Jellyman and Unwin 2018). Lake Manapouri is the largest hydroelectric scheme in New Zealand, contributing substantially to overall hydro-electric generation (Jellyman and Unwin 2018, Stuart et al. 2018). Water levels in the lake are controlled by a weir, the Manapouri Lake Control structure (MLC) (Jellyman and Unwin 2018, Stuart et al. 2018). When silver eels attempting to emigrate from the lake encounter outflows, entry to the power station can result in 100% mortality (Stuart et al. 2018). This source of mortality, given that many eels reside in lakes with hydropower development, could be significant, and reduce spawner escapement from New Zealand (Fisheries New Zealand 2018).

Habitat degradation is another threat to A. dieffenbachii in New Zealand. Wetland drainage has resulted in a huge loss of habitat in New Zealand (Jellyman 2016). Since European settlement in the 1840s, to the mid-1970s, wetlands have been reduced from around 670,000 ha to 100,000 ha, a decline of 85% (Taylor and Smith 1997, Beentjes et al. 2005, PCE 2013; Jellyman 2007, 2012, 2016). The wetland areas that remain have been subject to other stressors, such as pollution, animal grazing and introduced plants (Taylor and Smith 1997). Although this remains a more serious threat to A. australis, habitat overlap with A. dieffenbachii means it is likely to have had some negative effect. Felling of trees for timber has also occurred, along with burning of forests for quick conversion to pasture farming (Beentjes et al. 2005, PCE 2013, Fisheries New Zealand 2018). By the 1980s, around 70% of the native forest had been lost (PCE 2013). Topsoil run-off as a result of forest clearing resulted in large scale erosion and sedimentation of rivers, detrimental effects of which are still being seen in the present day (PCE 2013). For A. dieffenbachii, who shows preference for shade and cover under banks and tree roots, the removal of a sufficient riparian zone results in loss of refuge areas and therefore habitat (Graynoth and Niven 2004, Beentjes et al. 2005, PCE 2013). Furthermore, the reduction in riparian vegetation also has generic detrimental effects to the ecosystem, including; reducing the buffer zone between the terrestrial and aquatic interface, reduced capability to filter nutrients from run-off, reduction in bank stabilisation causing soil erosion, and reduced entry of allochthonous material as a source of organic matter and therefore energy (Beentjes et al. 2005, PCE 2013, Gonzáles et al. 2017). This, ultimately, compromises the overall health of the river system (Beentjes et al. 2005).

The effects of farming irrigation has also been suggested to be detrimental to eels in New Zealand. Poor water quality resulting from greater concentrations of nutrients and sediment in the water has been linked to excessive plant growth and smothering of the stream bed, reducing habitat and food for eels (PCE 2013). The use of drainage for pastoral purposes means there is a requirement for drain cleaning (Jellyman 2012, Fisheries New Zealand 2018). Methods include both mechanical clearing and herbicides, and personal accounts have reported that mechanical excavation leads to eels being scooped out of the water onto banks, causing direct mortality if they cannot make it back to the watercourse (Beentjes et al. 2005, Fisheries New Zealand 2018). Although, drainage for pastoral purposes in more common in low-lying lands, and so may be a more serious threat to A. australis (Jellyman 2012). Flood pumping stations control water levels in low lying lands within catchments (Vaipuhi Consulting 2017). Impellors spin within the pump, which can cause direct mortality to eels as they attempt passage (Duirs 2017, Vaipuhi Consulting 2017, Williams et al. 2017). Mortality of large eels greater than 600 mm in length has been found to be 100%, whereas smaller eels of a size less than 600 mm, is significantly lower at 12% (Vaipuhi Consulting 2017). Impacts of flood pumps may be greater for A. australis, as they are more prevalent in low land areas. There is, however, likely to be some threat to A. dieffenbachii as a result of habitat overlap.

Invasive species may be another threat to A. dieffenbachii. Wu et al. (2013) described some of the effects of invasive fish on freshwater ecosystems in New Zealand. It was noted that they alter turbidity, cause shifts in invertebrate composition, reduce native macrophyte abundance, increase concentrations of nutrients, and compete with native species. Cyprinid fishes, such as common carp (Cyprinus carpio) and goldfish (Carassius auratus), were described to be known for altering the freshwater ecosystem through mobilising fine sediments, causing clear shallow lakes to become turbid. The introduction of invasive species such as those mentioned may contribute to the loss of suitable available habitat for A. dieffenbachii, particularly due to its habitat preferences (Graynoth and Niven 2004). Other introduced species, such as trout, perch, rudd, catfish, koi carp, tench and gambusia may also impact eels through competition for food and resources, as well as degrading habitat and reducing biodiversity (Rowe 2004 in Williams et al. 2017). Competition with other eels may also pose a threat to A. dieffenbachii. The Australian long-finned eel, A. reinhardtii, utilises similar habitat and has overlapping diet with A. dieffenbachii, and is highly competitive within its native range with a faster growth rate (Chisnall 2000). If A. reinhardtii becomes more common in upper reaches of catchments, where there is limited habitat for A. dieffenbachii, it is likely to compete as top predator (Chisnall 2000). This said, A. reinhardtii is rare in New Zealand, and so currently this threat is likely to be minimal (Williams et al. 2017).

Changes in ocean-atmospheric conditions have been implicated in the decline in recruitment seen in all temperate anguillid species (Miller et al. 2009). For some species, this involves El Niño Southern Oscillation (ENSO) events, which have potentially been affecting spawning and recruitment of A. australis and A. dieffenbachii (Miller et al. 2009). Alterations in surface layer characteristics (productivity/community structure) may also have occurred due to ocean warming, affecting both larval feeding and transport (Miller et al. 2009). In the Tukituki River, Hawke Bay, New Zealand, glass eels (both A. australis and A. dieffenbachii) migrating upstream were found to display preference for water temperatures between 12–20°C, with an optimum of 16.5°C (August and Hicks 2008). Temperatures lower than 12°C and above 22°C were found to depress glass eel catches (August and Hicks 2008). It was therefore implied that warmer waters occurring as a result of the changing climate may be detrimental to glass eel recruitment in the native range of these species (August and Hicks 2008). In the North Island Waikato River, glass eel recruitment (both A. australis and A. dieffenbachii) was also studied over a period of two years (2004–5) (Jellyman et al. 2009). Comparison of catch results from this study with previous catch data (30 years apart), found glass eel migration periods to occur earlier in the present study, by several weeks (Jellyman et al. 2009). It was also found that reduced CPUE and duration of runs in the recent sampling, indicating a reduction in recruitment may also have occurred (Jellyman et al. 2009). One possible explanation given was that deviations were a result of climate change, as although no consistent national trend exists, fresh water temperatures in New Zealand have increased by ~1.6°C from 1989–2005 (Scarsbrook 2006 in Jellyman et al. 2009). Glass eels sampled by Jellyman et al. (2009) were caught between temperatures of 12.6°C and 13.1°C, substantially below the 16.5°C optimum suggested by August and Hicks (2008). There was also evidence that glass eels may compensate for increased temperature through earlier seasonal migration (Jellyman et al. 2009). Therefore, if they were to wait for river temperatures >12°C before beginning upstream migration, the time window would become limited (Jellyman et al. 2009). For these studies, catches in both the Tukituki and Waikato were both predominantly A. australis, 91–93% and >97%, respectively (August and Hicks 2008, Jellyman et al. 2009).

Eels are seen as suitable indicators of persistent organic pollutant (POP) contamination in freshwater ecosystems, due to their high lipid content, longevity and omnivorous feeding (Holmqvist et al. 2006). New Zealand is highly industrialised, with many potential sources of POPs, although levels of Polychlorinated biphenyls (PCB) in A. dieffenbachii are the lowest found in anguillid eels worldwide (Holmqvist et al. 2006).
population:
A range of sources indicate a population decline for Anguilla dieffenbachii, mainly as a result of fishing pressure, barriers to migration, and habitat degradation. The first European settlers to New Zealand found, like Māori, eels to be a largely available, abundant, easily exploitable food source (McDowall 1990). British settlers introduced trout to New Zealand waters, eventually resulting in the abstraction of eels to protect the introduced trout (McDowall 1990). Commercial fishing for eels began again both during and after the second world war, up to a peak of 2,364 t in 1975. Over time, there has been a shift from eels being an originally abundant nuisance species in New Zealand (from the perspective of European settlers), to an exploited species of high export value (McDowall 1990). In the present day, there is growing public knowledge that eels—in particular A. dieffenbachii—are an important part of New Zealand biodiversity (Jellyman 2014).

The Fisheries New Zealand ‘Fisheries Assessment Plenary’ was published in May 2018. This document is a summary of fisheries, biological, environmental, stock assessment, and stock status information for commercial fish species in New Zealand. The first available catch data (landings, tonnes (t)) of yellow, and to a lesser extent, silver eels is from 1965, although up to 1989–90 this encompassed landings of both shortfin (A. australis) and longfin (A. dieffenbachii), with the latter making up ~25% of commercial eel catch (PCE 2013). Although not a legislative requirement, there are no targeted fisheries for silver eels - with the exception of silver male A. australis from Te Waihora) in New Zealand (Jellyman 2007). This is due to capture being difficult at high flow periods when most migrate, and voluntary bans among fishers to support the sustainability of the stock (Jellyman 2007). Australasian longfin (A. reinhardtii), after identification in 1996 (Jellyman et al. 1996), has been confirmed in North Island landings, although the percentage is unknown and thought to contribute very little, so is included and managed within ‘shortfin’ (A. australis) stocks. Catch data prior to 1988 was also collected by calendar year not fishing season, which straddle years. Fisheries New Zealand (2018) reported general trends in fisheries landings (t) since the late 1980s within their Fisheries Assessment Plenary. From 1989–90 to 2007–08, the proportion of A. dieffenbachii in overall eel landings declined from 42% to 29%. After which, a sharp decline was seen in the next fishing season, with the proportion of A. dieffenbachii being only 18% in 2008–09. This figure increased again to 30% in 2013–14 but has since declined to a proportion of 19% in the most recently reported record from 2015–16. Over the time scale of this data, A. dieffenbachii landings have undergone a decline of ~80% from 1989–90 to 2015–16. However, due to the effects of market demand, quotas, voluntary non-targeting, and fishery closures (Williams et al. 2017), it would not be accurate to infer declines solely from the landings data presented within the Fisheries Assessment Plenary.

Catch Per Unit Effort (CPUE) data are available by Eel Statistical Area (ESA) (a list of which can be found in Fisheries New Zealand 2018). For North Island ESAs, robust CPUE data was analysed from Northland (ESA AA), Auckland (ESA AB), Hauraki (ESA AC), and Waikato (ESA AD), from 1990–91 to 2014–15 (Beentjes and McKenzie 2017). Indices for A. dieffenbachii were found to be more variable, with wider confidence intervals than that of ‘shortfins’. Catch per unit effort of A. dieffenbachii in the North Island ESAs initially declined from 1990, followed by increases or no trend occurring from 2002—apart from Northland, where CPUE declined throughout the series (Beentjes and McKenzie 2017). Catch per unit effort is now indicating a halt or reversal in the declines, although reductions in Total Allowable Commercial Catch (TACC) in 2007–08 and voluntary reductions in Annual Catch Entitlement (ACE) by iwi—the political unit of the Māori representing customary and commercial interests—prior to this, may have contributed to this (Beentjes and McKenzie 2017). Estimates of CPUE are described as being conservative following 2007 due to non-reporting of legal sized eels returned to the water, a consequence of fishers not having enough ACE to cover the catch, but also voluntarily forgoing opportunities to fulfil their ACE (Williams et al. 2017). The increased size of fyke net escape tubes—a mechanism to allow eels under the size restriction to escape—from 25 mm to 31 mm in 2013–14 to exclude eels <300 g will also have contributed to these conservative estimates (Beentjes and McKenzie 2017).

Analysis of CPUE has also been conducted for South Island ESAs from 1990–91 to 2012–13 (Beentjes and Dunn 2013). In data poor areas (Nelson (ESA AN), Marlborough, South Marlborough (ESA AP-AQ), North and South Canterbury (ESA AR, AT), and Waitaki (ESA AU)) there was no strong consistent trend observed over the series, with the exception of Marlborough and South Marlborough where CPUE was found to decline (Beentjes and Dunn 2013). For data rich areas (Westland (ESA AX), Otago (ESA AV), Southland (ESA AW) and Te Waihora (AS1)) pre-Quota Management System (QMS) CPUE showed clear declines, apart from in Westland where CPUE increased. Post-QMS, CPUE showed increasing trends in Westland and Otago, and to a lesser extent in Southland (Beentjes and Dunn 2013).

Although CPUE is a better indicator of population status data are only available from areas that are fished and so may be unrepresentative of the overall population (Hoyle 2016). Graynoth et al. (2008b) estimated 49% of the freshwater (rivers and lakes) biomass of A. dieffenbachii was located in reserves or rarely fished areas. Another study found 35% of New Zealand A. dieffenbachii river habitat to be fished, with commercial fishing occurring in 27.2% of river and lake habitat accessible to A. dieffenbachii (Beentjes et al. 2016). Catch per unit effort may therefore not be the most useful metric to solely determine the overall population trend, particularly when it is difficult to determine how much unfished areas contribute to recovery for eels (Hoyle 2016). Chisnall and Kalish (1993) found 68% of marked and recaptured A. dieffenbachii exhibited little movement within the Ahirau Stream (North Island, New Zealand). Eels were found to remain between one and three years within the same pools or runs, possibly suggesting the contribution of unexploited areas to those that are fished may be minimal (Hoyle 2016). Models developed by Hoyle and Jellyman (2002) indicated few females survived to spawn even at relatively low rates of fishing pressure, with reductions in spawning per recruit of 83% and 96.5% from unfished levels, at an annual exploitation rate of 5% and 10%, respectively. As such, A. dieffenbachii are particularly vulnerable to over-exploitation. Dunn et al. (2009) investigated the feasibility of developing a population dynamics model for South Island A. dieffenbachii using fisheries data. Estimates suggested pre-exploitation spawning stock biomass to range between 120 and 180 t, with current spawning stock biomass to be depleted, at either 5% or between 20–25% of pre-exploitation levels dependent on the type of model used (Dunn et al. 2009).

Jellyman et al. (2000) examined the age composition of A. dieffenbachii in freshwater, to assess annual variations in year class abundance and determine whether there had been a decline in recruitment. Samples were taken using electrofishing from three coastal streams (Pigeon Bay, Canterbury; Horokiwi Stream, Wellington; Te Maari Stream, Raglan) over three years. Abundance of size/age groups within the entire catchment were estimated and used to determine age composition and mortality rates. Annual recruitment was found to be highly variable and was unlikely to have declined at a steady rate. The average rate of decline since 1980 for all three waters (Pigeon Bay, Canterbury; Horokiwi Stream, Wellington; Te Maari Stream, Raglan) was found to be 10% per year, although a conservative 7% per year was used in subsequent graphs and models. This conservative estimate suggested recruitment to have declined by 77% between 1980 and 2000, based these waterbodies. Although this was based only on three streams, the positioning of them across both North and South Islands (Middle and Southern North Island, Middle South Island), suggests it would be reasonable to infer the results may represent the status across the country. A second data set, from the Arahura River (West Coast, South Island) was used, where electrofishing surveys were conducted in 1998. Models indicated a 5% per year decline over several decades. These declines in recruitment could seriously affect yellow eel populations and silver eel escapement that, due to the longevity of the species, could be seen for decades to come (Jellyman 2009).

As part of a Public Good Science Fund (PGSF) research programme on eels, the National Institute of Water and Atmospheric Research (NIWA) conduced regular sampling for glass eels (Jellyman 2012). The data series ran from 1995–2006, and analysis was conducted on glass eel catches sampled at two weekly intervals during September and October (Jellyman 2012). The analysis found A. dieffenbachii to be less abundant than A. australis, although found no evidence of a decline in recruitment of A. dieffenbachii over the period (Jellyman, 2012). This suggests the declines indicated in Jellyman et al. (2000) had ceased. However, the time period assessed in this paper, in comparison to the generation length of the species (34 years) is very short. It was concluded that it would be premature to assume A. dieffenbachii recruitment is stable, and that other studies (Jellyman et al. 2009) have found evidence of recruitment declines (Jellyman 2012).

The Waikato River is known to have the largest glass eel recruitment of all the rivers in New Zealand (Jellyman et al. 2009, 2012). From 1970–74, trials to determine the commercial potential of exporting glass eels were conducted where fishing was carried out for four seasons (Jellyman 1979). More recently, during research to determine environmental triggers of recruitment in the Waikato during 2004 and 2005, comparisons were able to be made with the data from the 1970s (Jellyman et al. 2009). It was found that the proportion of A. dieffenbachii had declined from 12% (n=10,525 glass eels) in the 1970s to 3% (n = 437) in 2004 (Jellyman 1979, Jellyman et al. 2009). The migration period was found to be several weeks earlier during the studies conducted in 2004 and 2005 when compared to previous, and CPUE, duration of runs, and average catch per run were significantly reduced (Jellyman et al. 2009). However, conclusions based on two years data must be provisional, as interannual variation in recruitment can be 10-fold (Francis and Jellyman 1999 in Jellyman et al. 2009).

It has been reported that recruitment data collected prior to 1995 is unreliable (Fisheries New Zealand 2018). Since 1995, the Ministry for Primary Industries (MPI) has been monitoring recruitment through elver trap and transfer operations at hydro dams. Martin and Bowman (2016), estimated recruitment trends between 1995 and 2015, using the data collected from six locations: Wairua Falls Power Station, Karapiro Dam, Matahina Dam, Patea Dam, Waitaki Dam and Arnold Dam. In Karapiro and Matahina, for both A. dieffenbachii and A. australis, catch indices peaked between 2007 and 2009, underwent a sharp decline in 2011–12, before increasing in 2014–15. In the South Island, there were large gaps in data, making it difficult to discern trends. Arnold Dam showed declines in recruitment from around 2008–09, although this increased in 2014–15. Overall, catch indices have fluctuated markedly through seasons and between sites, with no consistent trend across the time series, suggesting no overall trend in recruitment (Martin and Bowman 2016). It should be noted however, that recruitment to some large rivers is is seemingly inadequate for their size (Don Jellyman pers. comm. 2019). In the North Island, on the Waikato River, the catchment area above Karapiro Dam is 4,226 km². Previously (2007–2008) this has supported 701,000 elvers, but has a recent five-year average of 134,000, compared to the long-term average of ~230,000 (1992–93 to 2014–15) (Martin and Bowman 2016). In the South Island, three out of four of the largest rivers, the Waiau, Waitaki, and Clutha, have annual recruitment of up to ~100,000 elvers annually, with only a few hundred in some years (catchment area above the dams is, 5,785 km², 7,801 km², and 12,000 km², respectively) (Martin and Bowman 2016).

Surveys of A. dieffenbachii and A. australis were conducted between 1996 and 2010 by NIWA, as described in the report by the Parliamentary Commissioner for the Environment (2013). NIWA undertook 30 surveys in 19 streams and rivers, with eels being counted, measured and subsequently divided into 50-millimetre length classes. Over 10,000 A. dieffenbachii were measured, and it was found that the proportion of elvers (50–99 mm) was much lower than what would have been expected given a healthy size distribution for this species (where there would be a larger proportion of small eels being present compared to larger eels) (Jellyman 2012). This reduced proportion of elvers was determined to depict a reduction in the resilience of the population, as low numbers of eels in smaller age classes will result in knock on effects to later life stages (Jellyman 2012).

Records from 1977–2015 collected from the New Zealand Freshwater Fish Database (NZFFD) were analysed by Crow et al. (2016) using a generalised linear model, to estimate the probability of capture as an index of relative abundance for each year. Two approaches were run for this analysis, one using probability of capture values only, and one that was weighted, through placing higher emphasis on observations for which there is greater confidence. Within the weighted analysis, the relative abundance of A. dieffenbachii declined over the complete time series, and so the unweighted analysis trend could not be inferred with confidence. The data within NZFFD records are collected country-wide, possibly suggesting country-wide trends, however, records were mostly from electrofishing, which may over-represent life stages in stream habitats accessible to this method (Haro et al. 2015, Crow et al. 2016). When looking at spawning escapement of A. dieffenbachii, Graynoth et al. (2008b) estimated escapement to be 277 t per year. This indicated a decline of around 80% in escapement since the 1920s (1,360 t), before the start of hydro-dam construction and commercial eel fishing.

In three of the largest rivers in New Zealand (Waitaki, Waikato, and Clutha) hydro-dam development has prevented access to 68,000 km of riverine habitat, and while not all will be suitable for eels, represents a large impact on habitat availability (Jellyman and Harding 2012). Graynoth et al. (2008b) used models to estimate the biomass of eels that could be supported within river habitat in New Zealand, if hydro-dams were not blocking passage. It was estimated, that hydro-dams in both the North and South Islands have impeded upstream access to water that has a carrying capacity of 6,260 t of longfin eels (Graynoth et al. 2008b). However, another study proposed a more conservative estimate and that major dams have reduced access to habitat with a carrying capacity of 460 t of eels in the North Island, and 1,200 t in the South Island (Boubée et al. 2008). Beentjes et al. (2016) found hydro and reservoir dams to impede access to 44% of natural lake habitat suitable for A. dieffenbachii (Beentjes et al. 2016). Although estimates vary and multiple metrics are used, these papers indicate that anthropogenic barriers have a substantial effect on eel migration (Beentjes et al. 2005).

Anguilla dieffenbachii has been assessed as ‘At Risk – Declining’ under the New Zealand Threat Classification Series, with qualifiers ‘CD’ (conservation dependent — “The taxon is likely to move to a higher threat category if current management ceases”) and ‘DP’  (data poor — “Confidence in the listing is low due to there being only poor data available for assessment”) (Dunn et al. 2018, Townsend et al. 2008). It is reported that abundance of A. dieffenbachii is stable or increasing in commercial fisheries, although there is still concern over continuing habitat degradation (Dunn et al. 2018). It is also stated within the report: "The panel also notes that public discourse on the longfin eel portrays the species as being severely threatened despite data that indicate otherwise." (Dunn et al. 2018). The New Zealand Threat Classification Series defines population as “The total number of individuals that are resident or that breed in New Zealand” referring solely to mature individuals (Townsend et al. 2008). The difficulty with assessing an Anguillid species using this terminology, as with the IUCN classification, is that we do not have a direct metric for ‘mature individuals’, as eels are not considered mature until they reach oceanic breeding grounds to spawn. Therefore, it is necessary to assess them using the nearest closest metric. Within the New Zealand Threat Classification Series assessment, there is no indication as to what metric was used or reasoning as to why that metric was decided to be an appropriate alternative.
range: Anguilla dieffenbachii is a temperate species, endemic to New Zealand (Jellyman and Unwin 2017). It is found in both the North and South Islands as well as the Chatham and Stewart offshore Islands (McDowall 1990, Jellyman 2007, Jellyman and Unwin 2017). Anguilla dieffenbachii can travel up to 300 km inland and is distributed from sea level up to elevations of 1,150 meters, allowing individuals to inhabit high country lakes and rivers (McDowall 2000, Jellyman 2007). The spawning grounds of this species are currently unknown, although research using pop-up satellite archival tags on migrating females have suggested a tropical spawning ground, lying east of New Caledonia, possibly in the south Fiji basin (Jellyman and Tsukamoto 2005, 2010). Anguilla dieffenbachii is assumed to be panmictic, with genetic structure indicating derivation from a single spawning population (Smith et al. 2001; Jellyman 2007, 2012).
useTrade:
The various life stages, ranging from juvenile to adult, of all anguillid species are harvested and traded on a global scale for farming and consumption, with current demand predominantly driven by East Asian markets, in particular Japan and mainland China. A concerning pattern of exploitation is already apparent – when one Anguilla species or population becomes over-exploited, industry moves to the next in order to fulfil demand (Gollock et al. 2018).

According to FAO data, annual global Anguilla production has steadily increased since the 1950s, mainly due to the expansion of farming in East Asia. In 2016, eel farming accounted for 98% of total eel production (over 290,000 t), with mainland China responsible for nearly 86% (FAO 2018). Eel farming is reliant on wild-caught juvenile eels (glass eels/elvers) as “seed” as breeding in captivity is not yet commercially viable. Although the preferred species for farming in East Asia is A. japonica, which is native to the region, declines in availability and ongoing demand has led to increase in harvest and trade in juveniles of other Anguilla spp. in recent years (Shiraishi and Crook 2015, Gollock et al. 2018). Anguilla dieffenbachii juvenile eels have not been affected by these shifts in demand, however, as catch or export of glass eels from New Zealand is not permitted (apart from small quantities for research purposes), and there is no information suggesting this species is currently used (or there is interest in using it in the future) in eel farms in East Asia. Only yellow and silver A. dieffenbachii eels are harvested and traded globally (see below for more information).

Live eels and meat are traded globally for consumption and to a much smaller extent Anguilla skins and leather products are also in international trade. Global Customs trade data for live, fresh, frozen and prepared/preserved eel (non-species-specific) are available for the last 40 years. According to FAO and UN Comtrade, global annual exports of Anguilla averaged around 20,000 t in the late 1970s, after which annual exports showed a steady increase to a maximum of over 130,000 t in 2001. Since then annual exports have been declining, to just over 80,000 t in 2008–2011, increasing again slightly to ~90,000 t in 2013–2015. The export value of these commodities has steadily increased over the past 40 years, reaching USD ~1.6 billion in 2012. Over the last decade, of the four commodity types, live and prepared/preserved eel accounted for nearly 80% of total exports by weight, and China has been the main eel exporter (52% and 71% of global exports by weight and value respectively during 2006–2015) and Japan the main importer (for 54% and 72%). As noted above, a high percentage of eels in international trade are derived from eels having been grown out in farms. Trade in A. dieffenbachii on the other hand is wholly wild-caught eels, as there is no known farming of this species.

In New Zealand, eels (known in Te Reo as “tuna”) feature extensively in Māori mythology and large eels are considered spiritual guardians of waterways. To this day, eels are important to Māori for cultural reasons. In some cases they are considered a delicacy and are served at various functions. Prior to European settlement, Māori already had extensive knowledge of the ecology of eels and developed effective fisheries through combinations of traps, spearing, bait fishing and large weirs (McDowall 1990, 2011; Jellyman, 2012). The extent of current or past non-commercial take in New Zealand is unknown, however current allowances for customary and recreational take of longfin eels (A. dieffenbachii) as of 2018 were set at: 32.6% of TAC (46 t) in the North Island, and 21.7% of TAC (24.68 t) in South Island, for customary take. For recreational take, allowances were 22.7% of TAC (32 t) in the North island, and 6.4% of TAC (7.24 t) in the South Island. 

Large scale commercial yellow and silver eel fisheries of domestic species began in New Zealand in the 1960s with the arrival of Dutch immigrants to New Zealand, who had both the knowledge of eel fisheries and the ability to make and use fyke nets (McDowall 1990). Anguilla dieffenbachii is particularly vulnerable to capture using baited fyke nets, with larger eels being more likely to be caught than smaller eels (Jellyman and Graynoth 2005). The fishery grew rapidly until annual catches of 2,000 t were recorded in the early 1970s. Annual landings were relatively stable from 1983 to 2001 (~1,000–1,500 t), after which they dropped as eel stocks were progressively introduced into the Quota Management System (QMS), TACCs were reduced and international demand declined (Fisheries New Zealand 2018). Over the last decade, total commercial annual catch has ranged between about 450–750 t. Anguilla dieffenbachii catch has accounted for around 20–30% of this: ranging between 90 and 240 t a year (Fisheries New Zealand 2018).

The majority of New Zealand eel catch (>70%) is exported (New Zealand Ministry for Primary Industries 2018). Anguilla dieffenbachii is not usually exported live due to difficulties in ensuring survival; according to industry sources the main processed product is frozen chunks (of about 5 cm length, New Zealand Ministry for Primary Industries 2018). According to New Zealand Customs data (which does not differentiate between species), New Zealand exported 3,636 t of frozen eels and 2,818 t of live eels during 2008–2017. Annual frozen eel exports ranged between 152 and 380 t during 2008–2017 except for 2010 when these exceeded 1,189 t with sudden increases in frozen eel exports to South Korea (926 t). Except in 2010, the main destinations of frozen eels were Belgium, the UK and Germany. Live eel exports reached a peak of 517 t in 2011, after which they declined gradually to 133 t in 2016. The main destinations of live eels were South Korea until 2013, mainland China (2014–2016) and Canada in 2017. Jellyman (2012) reported that there has been a substantial increase in the price that New Zealand eels are fetching on overseas markets, although details are scarce.
conservationActions:
In New Zealand an annual meeting of the Eel Working Group occurs as part of the management process for eel fisheries. This involves Ministry of Fisheries fishery managers, iwi—the political unit of Māori representing customary and commercial interests—commercial fishers, processors, Seafood Industry Council, the Department of Conservation and research providers (Jellyman 2012). The meetings involve discussions surrounding research priorities, reviewing research outcomes as well as reviewing the annual report on eels (Ministry of Fisheries assessment plenary) (Jellyman 2012).

The New Zealand fishing season for all eel stocks extends from 1st October to 30th September, apart from Te Waihora/Lake Ellesmere, where since 2002 the season is 1st February to 31st January (Fisheries New Zealand 2018). A Quota Management System (QMS) was introduced to New Zealand in 1986, to control the amount of fish taken from each stock (Ministry for Primary Industries, 2019a). On 1st October 2000, the South Island eel fishery was introduced to the QMS, combining ‘shortfins’ (A. australis with some A. reinhardtii) and ‘longfins’ (A. dieffenbachii) within six stocks. The Chatham Island fishery followed, introducing the QMS on 1st October 2003, with one stock for ‘shortfins’ and one for ‘longfins’. The North Island fishery was introduced on the 1st October 2004, with eight fish stocks, four for each ‘shortfins’ and ‘longfins’ (Fisheries New Zealand 2018). On 1st October 2017 the South Island stocks were finally separated into ‘longfins’ and ‘shortfins’, to allow species specific management (Fisheries New Zealand 2018).

The QMS involves establishing Total Allowable Catch (TAC) (In 2018: 113.95 t South Island, 141 t North Island) for each fish stock, which is split into: Total Allowable Commercial Catch (TACC) (In 2018: 72% of TAC (82 t) South Island, 39% of TAC (55 t) North Island), customary catch, recreational catch, and other sources of fishing related mortality (Jellyman 2007, 2012). New Zealand’s indigenous people, Māori, have been allocated 20% of commercial quota, with additional catch allocation for customary take (Jellyman 2007, Williams et al. 2017). Quota shares generate a certain amount of Annual Catch Entitlement (ACE), which does not necessarily have to be fished by owners themselves and can be sold to other licensed fishers that may or may not own quota. The proportion of the TAC given as customary allowance is different for both North and South Islands and can vary in different years as a result of adjustments made after reviews. The current customary allowance for the North Island is 32.6% of the TAC (46 t) after cuts to the TAC/TACC were made on 1st October 2018, although this varies within each Quota Management Area (QMA) (Ministry for Primary Industries 2019c). In the South Island the customary allowance is 21.7% of TAC (24.68 t), with the proportion again varying by QMA (values for TAC, TACC, cust. allowance, and rec. allowance for each North and South Island QMA can be found: Ministry for Primary Industries 2019d) (Ministry for Primary Industries 2019d).

Minimum and maximum commercial size limits (220 g from 1992 and 4 kg from 1995 for South Island and 2007 for North Island) are in place for anguillid eels throughout New Zealand (Jellyman 2012). In 2005, Mohaka, Motu and most of the Whanganui River catchments were closed to commercial fishing (Fisheries New Zealand 2018). In the Waikato-Tainui rohe region in 2014, bylaws were introduced to limit minimum harvest sizes to 300 g for ‘shortfins’ and 400 g for ‘longfins’, with an upper limit of 2 kg for both (Fisheries New Zealand 2018), to prevent the take of migratory females. There was also the addition of seasonal closures in some reaches as a result of the introduced bylaws (Fisheries New Zealand 2018). Across New Zealand, there is a recreational daily bag limit of six eels, introduced in October 1994 (Fisheries New Zealand 2018). A fisher agreement also exists, whereby commercial fishers have voluntarily agreed to not land A. dieffenbachii in Lake Ellesmere (Te Waihora), or any ‘longfin’ migratory female (or eel over 4 kg) (Williams et al. 2017, Ministry for Primary Industries, 2019b). Commercial fishing in New Zealand is also banned in National Parks and Scenic Reserves, and often on the Crown Estate (managed by the Department of Conservation).

In April 2018, the National Institute of Water and Atmospheric Research and Department of Conservation developed the “New Zealand fish passage guidelines: for structures up to 4m” in partnership with the New Zealand Fish Passage Advisory Group (Doc.govt.nz 2018, Franklin et al. 2018). The document outlines recommended practice for the design of instream infrastructure to provide for general fish passage and sets foundations for improved fish passage management, although it makes some reference to eels specifically (Doc.govt.nz 2018, Franklin et al. 2018). Other management developments have included enhancement of upstream waters with juvenile eels (although where this takes place upstream of hydro dams, escapement still remains an issue), setting aside additional reserve areas to increase escapement of silver eels, and increased management involvement of Māori (Jellyman 2007).

Since 1982/3 assistance of upstream elver passage over hydro-dams has occurred in New Zealand, and ‘trap and transfer’ methods are used to help improve the state of eel populations above these structures (Boubée et al. 2008). Lake Manapouri in the Waiau River catchment operates the largest hydropower station in New Zealand (Jellyman and Unwin 2018). To provide safe downstream passage for silver eels, Meridian Energy Ltd.—the power company responsible for the Manapouri Lake Control structure—are required to operate a ‘trap and transfer’ and monitoring programme, whereby silver eels are caught in the lake and transferred downstream of the obstruction to allow access to the sea (Jellyman and Unwin 2018, Stuart et al. 2018). Methods allowing for downstream movement include netting eels in headraces, and opening spillway gates at critical times, such as at the Patea Dam in Taranaki, where spillway gates are opened for an hour after sunset following heavy rain when mature eels are likely to migrate (PCE 2013). Māori have also practised various forms of management, named “rāhui”, which has included imposing fishing bans on waterways for ceremonial or conservation reasons and seeding areas with small eels (Jellyman 2012).

As well as this, iwi have voluntarily refrained from catching their Annual Catch Entitlement (ACE) for A. dieffenbachii, or made it available for use by others, a practise that has occurred for several years (Joshua Baller - Te Wai Māori Trust, pers. comm. 2019). Graynoth et al. (2008b) estimated that, at time of publication, 7% of A. dieffenbachii biomass occurred in water closed to commercial fishing, allowing safe migration of females. Water protected in the upper reaches held 17% of biomass (although fishing could still occur downstream) and a further 25% was located in rarely fished small streams. Overall, Graynoth et al. (2008b) estimated that 49% of the biomass was located in reserves or rarely fished areas. A study by Beentjes et al. (2016) found only 27.2% of river and lake habitat accessible to A. dieffenbachii to be commercially fished. The proportions varied depended on island, with 32.5% in the South Island, and 22.5% in the North Island. It has, however, been argued that the protection achieved by national reserves is not absolute, due to the eventual migration to the marine environment, where the species becomes again accessible to exploitation (McDowall 1990).

rationale: This nearshore species inhabits sandy bottom habitats and is restricted to a small area off Angoche, Mozambique. Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated as 1,380 km<sup>2</sup> and the area of occupancy (AOO) is 720 km<sup>2</sup>. It is taken in nearshore fisheries where the level of exploitation is very high, but the impact on this species is not currently quantified. Anecdotal evidence from monitoring the catch of these fisheries indicates that catch has declined over time due to overfishing. In addition, the nearshore habitat quality of this area may be impacted by a mining industry that is fixed directly on the shore. Overfishing is considered a major threat, and justifies this species occurring in only a single location as defined by the Red List methodology. Therefore, this species is listed as Endangered B1ab (iii,v). Development of fisheries management and data collection is highly recommended, as well as dedicated biological studies on this species and environmental research on water quality in the area.
habitat: This is a demersal species that inhabits sandy beaches and nearshore sandy bottoms. The maximum standard length is 10.2 cm (Uiblein and Lisher 2013, Uiblein and White 2015). Nothing is known on its life history (F. Uiblein pers. comm. 2019).
threats: Fishing is a major threat to this species. A secondary threat from mining development in Sangage is likely to be a source of pollution impacting the nearshore habitats that this species is restricted to (C. Maunde pers. comm. 2019).
population: This species is not particularly abundant, and is possibly relatively rare, especially compared to the more common Upeneus guttatus (F. Uiblein and M. Lisher pers. comm. 2019). It is known from relatively few confirmed specimens due to possible confusion with other goatfish species (Uiblein and Lisher 2013). The level of fishing effort for nearshore fishes such as this is very high throughout the area that this species is restricted to (C. Maunde and F. Uiblein pers. comm. 2019). Due to the lack of species-specific fisheries data in Mozambique, its population status is poorly understood, but anecdotal observations of catch declines in the intensive nearshore fisheries of Angoche are known. Some catch data have been collected for these fisheries since 1998, but this species has been misidentified within these data (C. Maunde pers. comm. 2019).
range: This species is considered endemic to northern Mozambique in the western Indian Ocean off Angoche (Uiblein and Lisher 2013, Uiblein and White 2015). This area has other restricted range species, and this is probably influenced by the unique upwelling conditions (Malauene et al. 2014). Its depth range is 1-40 metres (Uiblein and Lisher 2013). The species is considered to exist in a single location, with the major threat identified as overfishing. Its area of occupancy (AOO) is estimated as the area of 180 grid cells of 2 x 2 km size, which totals 720 km2. Based on a minimum bounding polygon, the extent of occurrence (EOO) is estimated as 1,380 km2. There is uncertainty in the current understanding of the boundaries of its occurrence in the Angoche area, but the AOO is expected to be larger than 500 km2 and less than 2,000 km2 with the EOO greater than 1,000 km2 and less than 5,000 km2.
useTrade: This species is taken in nearshore fisheries in Angoche (C. Maunde and F. Uiblein pers. comm. 2019).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures. The area around Angoche, which has a relatively high biodiversity, requires further research to fully understand the fish species composition and abundance (F. Uiblein pers. comm. 2019).

rationale:
The Zebra Shark (Stegostoma tigrinum) is a broadly distributed continental and insular shelf species of the Indo-West Pacific. It is usually found within a narrow band of shallow coral reef habitat and soft bottom that is heavily fished throughout all of its range except Australia. It is taken in inshore fisheries (demersal trawls, floating and fixed bottom gillnets and baited hooks) and regularly seen in fish markets in Indonesia, Thailand, Philippines, Pakistan, India, Taiwan, and elsewhere. There are limited data on population declines in these areas, with the exception of the Gulf of Thailand, but the species is susceptible to capture in a wide range of fisheries, has a narrow habitat range with potential limited dispersal, shows strong site fidelity and forms aggregations which facilitate the rapid removal of individuals.

Population genetic analysis supports two subpopulations of the Zebra Shark: Indian Ocean-Southeast Asian and Eastern Indonesian-Oceania. The greatest levels of exploitation and ongoing threats for this species occurs in Southeast Asia, particularly Thailand through to Indonesia. Given little or no genetic exchange from unexploited areas it is suspected that this subpopulation has declined by at least 50% over the last three generations (51 years) and these threats are suspected to continue at these levels into the future. Therefore the Indian Ocean-Southeast Asian subpopulation is considered Endangered. The Eastern Indonesian-Oceania subpopulation is composed of regions with minimal exploitation to this species as well as regions of greater fishing pressure and habitat threats. In particular, the Zebra Shark in Australian waters is considered Least Concern due to minimal impacts from fishing, non-consumptive exploitation and habitat loss. However, population genetic and tracking studies suggest there is likely to be exchange between Australian waters and the Arafura Sea in Eastern Indonesian waters where extensive trawl fishing occurs and has been increasing in intensity over the last 30 years. Based on the ongoing fishing and habitat threats posed by these trawl fisheries in the Arafura Sea and the potential impacts on Zebra Sharks migrating from adjacent regions, reductions of at least 20% of its population size within three generations (51 years) are suspected and the Eastern Indonesian-Oceania subpopulation is assessed as Near Threatened.

By combining the subpopulation assessments according to relative area (the Indian Ocean-Southeast Asian subpopulation has approximately 70% of the available habitat; the Eastern Indonesian-Oceania subpopulation has approximately 30% of the available coastal habitat), and given the ongoing threats from fishing and habitat loss across much of its range and suspected reductions of over 50% of its population size within three generations, this species is assessed globally as Endangered.
habitat:
The Zebra Shark occurs in tropical and subtropical, shallow inshore and offshore waters, often found on and around coral and rocky reefs and on sandy plateaus near coral, at depths down to at least 62 m. They are often observed resting on the bottom as well as swimming near the surface as both juveniles and adults.

The Zebra Shark demonstrates seasonal movement patterns in subtropical locations towards the latitudinal extent of their distribution (Dudgeon et al. 2013). Regular seasonal movements of over 1,000 km and a larger movement of over 2,000 km along the Queensland coast in Australian waters have been recorded using acoustic tracking methods (C. Dudgeon, unpublished data). Aggregations along coastal sites in southern Queensland and northern New South Wales occur during the warmer months of each year (Dudgeon et al. 2008, Dudgeon et al. 2013). The species demonstrates strong site fidelity to particular reefs in Australia (Dudgeon et al. 2013) and Thailand (Spot the Leopard Shark Thailand, unpublished data), which may make them more susceptible to targeted fishing.

The Zebra Shark is an oviparous species. Size at birth ranges between 20 and 36 cm total length (TL). Reproductive periodicity in the wild is unknown. Captive aquaria animals have demonstrated annual egg laying periods of up to 3 months with 40–80 eggs laid per year (Robinson et al. 2011) with up to 25% of eggs resulting in hatchlings (Squire Jnr, pers. comm., 22 Jul 2014). Age of maturity of captive female sharks is approximately 6-8 years of age based on the commencement of egg laying (Thomas, pers. comm., 18 Feb 2015; Robinson, pers. comm., 11 Jan 2015) and 7 years of age for males (Watson, pers. comm., 18 Feb 2015). Adults reach a maximum size of 246 cm TL with no sexual dimorphism evident (Dudgeon et al. 2008) and live over 28 years in aquaria (Thomas, pers. comm., 17 Feb 2015). Generation length estimates based on 6 years first age at maturity and 28 years maximum longevity for female sharks is 17 years.
threats:
The Zebra Shark is susceptible to capture in a wide range of inshore fisheries and although there is no direct evidence of population decline in the Indo-West Pacific, market surveys suggest this species is much less common than it used to be (L.J.V Compagno and W.T. White, pers. comms., 2003, Pillans and Simpfendorfer 2003). Surveys from 2004-2012 in Thailand indicate that the Zebra Shark is regularly landed at fish markets on the Andaman Sea but was not recorded from the Gulf of Thailand (Krajandara 2014). However, photographs show Zebra Shark available for auction at the Samut-Sakorn fish market near Bangkok in Thailand in 2012 (Arthur Jones Dionio, pers. comm). The geographic origin of these animals is unknown as Thai fleets also operate in foreign waters (Chen 1996). The Zebra Shark is reported from fisheries operating out of Taiwan (Chen et al. 1997), Myanmar (SEAFDEC 2004), Bangladesh (Hoq et al. 2014), India (Theisavigamani and Subbiah 2014), the Persian Gulf, the Oman Sea (Valinassab et al. 2006, Henderson et al. 2007), and Zanzibar (Shehe and Jiddawi 1997). Fish market surveys in Indonesia during April 2001-March 2006 recorded 77 Zebra Sharks with almost all coming from trawl fishery bycatch in Jakarta (Dharmadi et al. 2015).

Anecdotal reports suggest that a substantial decrease in Zebra Shark sightings in the Berau Archipelago, East Kalimantan was from fishers using a free diving harpooning catch method targeting Zebra Shark (Erdmann, pers. comm., 23 March 2015). Genetic analyses (DNA barcoding) of shark fins collected during market surveys conducted across Indonesia from mid 2012 to mid 2014 found the vast majority of landed species were pelagic sharks with common reef and carpet sharks (including Zebra Sharks) extremely rare. Given the extensive shallow coastal habitat around Indonesia that would support the reef and carpet shark species, the authors conclude that this is a strong indication of the collapse of reef shark populations in Indonesia, most likely due to overfishing (Semibiring et al. 2015). Documented large declines in shark and ray catches associated with corresponding increases in fishing effort in the Java Sea (Blaber et al. 2009) are likely to have a large impact on the Zebra Shark in Indonesian waters and may be representative of fishing impacts across the region.

Legal and illegal fishing pressure has increased substantially in the Arafura Sea over the last 30 years (Resosudarmo et al. 2009). Trawling was banned in 1980 in all waters of the Indonesian 200 mile Exclusive Economic Zone west of longitude 130 E. This resulted in concentrated trawling pressure in the eastern part of the Timor Sea and the Arafura Sea. Approximately 90% of the large industrial scale vessels are foreign-owned and aim to collect maximum possible biomass including elasmobranchs (Fegen 2003). Zebra Sharks are likely to comprise part of this catch given their presence as bycatch in trawl surveys from neighbouring regions (Okera and Gunn 1986, Ramm 1997, Roelofs and Stapley 2003). Thai vessels comprise the largest demersal trawl fleet (Fegen 2003) and the numbers of Thai vessels operating in the Arafura Sea have increased from reports of 150 vessels (Chen 1996) to approximately 700 vessels (Blaber et al. 2005). Fegen (2003) reports that the Indonesian government issued 1,500 trawl licenses between 1998 and 2001. Thai vessels offload their catch onto freezer ships (Blaber et al. 2005) which are then transported for sale in Thai fish markets including Samut-sakorn province, Samut-prakarn province and Songkla province (Chen 1996).

The Zebra Shark is found in inshore, shallow coastal areas including mudflat, mangrove and seagrass beds as juveniles and then move further offshore to coral and rocky reef areas as adults. Threats to these key habitats occur in Southeast Asia with substantial coastal development including prawn farming in coastal areas as well as up to 80% of corals bleaching in the Andaman Sea and Gulf of Thailand during periods of elevated water temperatures in 2010 (Yeemin et al. 2010).

Threats within Australia are likely to be minimal. There are no target fisheries and small numbers are captured as bycatch in the Queensland East Coast Inshore Finfish Fishery (Harry et al. 2011), the Northern Prawn Fishery (Zhou and Griffiths 2008), the Pilbara Trawl fishery (Western Australia Department of Fisheries 2010) and in nets deployed by the Queensland Shark Control program (Sumpton et al. 2011). However, they demonstrate a high level of survival and records for these fisheries indicate a 79.5-100% post release survival rate. Recent acoustic tracking studies demonstrate that Zebra Sharks undertake large seasonal migrations on the eastern Australia coastline with regular movements of over 1,000 km annually and larger distances of over 2,000 km recorded in six months (C. Dudgeon unpublished data). Therefore it is possible for Zebra Sharks to move from Australia into nearby regions with fishing pressure such as the Indonesian Arafura Sea and Timor Seas.

A prawn trawl fishery consisting of about nine vessels operates in the Gulf of Papua in southern Papua New Guinea where Zebra Shark are caught in low numbers and mostly as juveniles (L. Baje, National Fisheries Authority, pers. comm., 2015).
population:
The Zebra Shark comprises two distinct subpopulations based on the population genetic analysis of 13 microsatellite loci and mitochondrial ND4 sequences: Indian Ocean-Southeast Asian subpopulation and Eastern Indonesian-Oceania subpopulation (Dudgeon et al. 2009).

Indian Ocean-Southeast Asian subpopulation
Population size information for the Indian Ocean-Southeast Asian subpopulation is limited. Zebra sharks are reported from fish markets across the region (Pillans and Simpfendorfer 2003). An ongoing photo-identification program in Thailand has identified approximately 250 individual Zebra Sharks in the Krabi Province in the Andaman Sea with most records from 2012–2015 (Spot the Leopard Shark Thailand, unpublished data). In contrast, only two sightings of Zebra Sharks have been reported from the Gulf of Thailand over this time. Vidthayanon (1997) and Compagno (2001) report the species as having declined in the Gulf of Thailand. Recent fish market surveys support substantial population declines in the Gulf of Thailand as the Zebra Shark was not sighted at landing sites in this region (Krajangdara 2014). Surveys of SCUBA dive schools operating in the Gulf of Thailand have recorded a significant reduction in sightings between the 1990s and 2000s from an average of one shark sighted per dive to <0.25 sharks sighted per dive (Ward-Paige and Lotze 2011).

The Zebra Shark is likely to be locally extinct from several locations throughout Indonesia. In particular, extensive SCUBA surveys for fish diversity assessments at sites across the Indonesian Archipelago have recorded none (Bali, Anambas Archipelago, Timor-Leste, Triton Bay and Cenderasih Bay in West Papua) or very few Zebra Sharks (Southwest Sulawesi; North Sulawesi; Raja Ampat) (Erdmann, pers. comm., 23 March 2015). The Zebra Shark was observed regularly (3-7 animals per dive) on dive sites at Berau Archipelago off East Kalimantan during surveys in 1997 but none were observed on subsequent surveys in 2002 and 2004 (Erdmann, pers. comm., 23 March 2015).

Eastern Indonesian-Oceania subpopulation
The Zebra Shark is found in large aggregations (20-50 animals) over sand near reef systems in parts of its Australian range (Pillans and Simpfendorfer 2003, Dudgeon et al. 2008). Abundance estimates based on mark-recapture analysis of photo-identification surveys of mature individuals are available for an unexploited aggregation in southern Queensland, Australia: 458 (95% CI = 298-618) (Dudgeon et al. 2008). Genetic effective population size estimates based on microsatellite data closely approximate these census sizes (377, 95% CI = 274–584) (Dudgeon and Ovenden 2015) suggesting the aggregation is composed of breeding adults. This population extends along the Queensland coast with genetic evidence of some segregation from northern Australia.

Population estimates for areas outside of Australia are unknown. Anecdotal reports from Conservation International staff at Raja Ampat in Eastern Indonesia suggest that the Zebra Shark used to be common on the large sandy regions around the reefs but are now rare.
range: The Zebra Shark is found in inshore waters of the continental and insular shelves of the Western Pacific and Indian Oceans (Compagno 2001).
useTrade: Zebra Sharks are landed whole and used for their fins, skin (dried), meat and cartilage (White et al. 2006). Zebra Sharks are kept in aquaria around the world. They breed well in aquaria and eggs and adults are also taken from the wild for aquaria stock. They are valuable within the recreational SCUBA diving industry, particularly in eastern Australia waters (C. Dudgeon. pers. obs.), near Phuket in Thailand (Anderson 2002), and elsewhere.
conservationActions:
Within Australia, the Zebra Shark occurs within several marine protected areas including the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park and Moreton Bay Marine Park in Queensland.

The Gulf of Papua trawl fishery in southern Papua New Guinea is managed under national laws and regulations, and there are some seasonal closures in place; although bycatch reduction devices are not currently in place, there are plans to implement in the near future (L. Baje, National Fisheries Authority, pers. comm. 2015).

The Zebra Shark is protected under the Malaysian Fisheries Act, therefore catches are opportunistic and landings not reported (Last et al. 2010).

rationale: The Longfin Gulper Shark (Centrophorus longipinnis) is a small (to 93 cm total length) deep-water shark that is patchily distributed across the Northwest and Western Central Pacific, and the Eastern Indian Oceans from Taiwan to Papua New Guinea. It is demersal on the continental slope at depths of 330–460 m, though its depth range is poorly known and it could occur deeper. It has very low biological productivity with only one pup produced per litter. The species is taken as bycatch, and possibly targeted, by demersal trawl and longline fisheries, and is likely retained for the meat, fins, liver oil, and for fish meal. There are no species-specific population trends although landings data of all sharks combined from the Taiwan Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) can be used to infer a reduction of 62% in the Longfin Gulper Shark over the past three generation lengths (83 years). The catch-per-unit effort of Centrophorus species in Lombok, Indonesia dramatically declined by 88% over two years from 2016–2018 with an inferred 99% decline in catches over three generation lengths (83 years). It currently has refuge from fishing pressure in Papua New Guinea. Centrophorus species stocks have collapsed within 20 years where they have been targeted in Maldives and Australia which is evidence that Centrophorus species are unable to sustain intense target or bycatch fishing pressure due to their limited biological productivity. It is suspected that the Longfin Gulper Shark has undergone a population reduction of 50–79% over the past three generation lengths (83 years) due to levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Endangered A2d.
habitat: The Longfin Gulper Shark is demersal on the continental slope at depths of 330–460 m (White et al. 2018). The depth range information is limited and only recorded from Papua New Guinea, and it possibly occurs deeper (White et al. 2017, D. Ebert unpubl. data 2019). The species reaches a maximum size of 93 cm total length (TL), males mature at 68 cm TL and females mature by 87 cm TL (White and Dharmadi 2010, White et al. 2017, White et al. 2018). Reproduction is aplacental viviparous with litter sizes of one pup (based on only two observed pregnant females) and size-at-birth of ~35 cm TL (White et al. 2018). Reproductive periodicity is unknown but could be 2–3 years based on other Centrophorus spp. (Kyne and Simpfendorfer 2007). Age parameters are unknown but can be inferred from a closely related species, the Gulper Shark (Centrophorus granulosus) that has a female age-at-maturity of 16.5 years and a maximum age of 39 years, resulting in a generation length of 27.8 years (Guallart 1998).
threats:
The Longfin Gulper Shark is taken as bycatch by deep-water trawl and likely deep-water longline, and retained for the meat, fins, liver oil, and for fish meal. The species is a bycatch of deep-water trawl fisheries that operate off the northeast and southwest coasts of Taiwan at depths of 300–700 m; these fisheries target multiple species of shrimp with all the incidental catch retained (Ebert et al. 2013; reported as Centrophorus cf. lusitanicus (Lowfin Gulper Shark), D. Ebert unpubl. data 2019). The fishery on the east coast, particularly operations out of Da-xi, has moved into deeper waters over the past 30 years (from 1998 to 2019) due to depletion of shallow water shrimp species. The fishery has moved from fishing depths of 100–300 m to depths of 300–700 m (D. Ebert unpubl. data 2019). Prior to 30 years ago (about one generation length) this species would not have been fished in Taiwan as it was beyond the depth of the fishing gear. During the monsoon season, conditions preclude deep-water trawling and some trawlers operate in the shallower depths of 100–300 m (H. Ho pers. comm. 28/08/2019); this would provide a reprieve from fishing pressure for the Longfin Gulper Shark. Deep-water longlines in Taiwan operate at depths of 100–300 m (H. Ho and H. Hsu pers. comm. 28/08/2019) and thus are unlikely to capture this species as its upper depth limit is beyond the reach of the longline gear.

In Taiwan, by the 1950s, coastal fisheries were considered overfished, and fisheries expanded into offshore waters within the Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ), and distant waters. The fisheries catch within the Taiwan EEZ continued to rise from the 1950s until 1980, after which it steadily declined (Kuo and Booth 2011). The number of powered vessels operating significantly increased from the 1950s (3,215 vessels) to the late 1980s (peaked in 1989s at 15,900), and then slowly decreased to 11,200 vessels in 2017 (Huang and Chuang 2010, Liao et al. 2019, H. Hsu Taiwan National Fisheries Statistics unpubl. data 2019). The artisanal fishing effort has steadily and markedly declined for non-powered sampans (8,283–239 from 1956 to 2004), but remains steady for fishing rafts (14,273–12,984 from 1956 to 2004) (H. Hsu, Taiwan National Fisheries Statistics unpubl. data 2019). In Taiwan, the demand for seafood has always been high at 31.2 kg per capita in 2013 (Helgil 2019). Fish too small for human consumption are in demand for processing into fish meal feed for the aquaculture industry that produces double the quantity of seafood taken from wild capture fisheries in Taiwan waters (NDC 2016).

In Indonesia, this species is likely taken on deep-water demersal longlines that operate at depths of 150–600 m (White et al. 2006). Fishing pressure in Indonesia is intense with the largest chondrichthyan fishery globally, and substantial catches of target and bycatch chondrichthyans (White et al. 2006). Indonesia has been among the top shark fishing nation for over 20 years (Oakes and Sant 2019). The deep-water demersal longlines fishing effort has remained relatively constant over the past 15 years, except for West Java where the fishery ceased operating in ~2010 (Fahmi unpubl. data 2020). In the Philippines, the species' upper-depth limit is beyond the reach of the trawl fisheries that operate to a maximum depth of 200 m (D. Tanay unpubl. data 2020). It may have previously been encountered in the Philippines by bottom set multiple hook-and-line gear that targeted dogfish sharks for their liver oil; the fishery was intensive from the 1960s–1980s and still operates but at an artisanal scale and not in the western Sulu Sea area (Gaudiano and Alava 2003, Flores 2004, D. Tanay unpubl. data 2020, J. Utzurrum unpubl. data 2020). In Papua New Guinea, the species is not encountered by commercial fishers (White et al. 2017), as it occurs at depths not yet fished (NFA 2020).
population:
The Longfin Gulper Shark is caught relatively frequently but in low numbers in Taiwan (Ebert et al. 2013; reported as Centrophorus cf. lusitanicus (Lowfin Gulper Shark), D. Ebert unpubl. data 2019). Elsewhere, it has only been reported from landing sites with no information on catch rates (White et al. 2017). There is no species-specific data from Taiwan, landings data are available on all combined shark species from coastal and offshore fisheries within the Taiwan Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ). Although landings data are not a direct measure of abundance, these can be used to infer population reduction where landings have decreased while fishing effort has remained stable or increased. Across Taiwan, both industrial and artisanal fishing effort have increased substantially since the 1950s, despite attempts by the Taiwan government to restrict effort in response to depletion of fisheries resources. Since the 1990s, industrial effort has declined, however there remains considerable industrial and artisanal fishing effort. The landings data showed a 52% decline of all combined shark species over 63 years from 1953 to 2015. The annual landings rose from ~8,300 t annually in the 1950s to a peak of 32,400 t in 1975, then declined steadily to 4,023 t in 2015 (Liao et al. 2019, H. Hsu, Taiwan National Fisheries Statistics unpubl. data 2019). These long-term declines in abundance of sharks can be inferred to represent reductions in their populations, as the declines have occurred since the peak catches of the mid–1970s, prior to any noticeable reduction in the 1990s of industrial fisheries effort. This represents a 62% decline when scaled to the past three generation lengths (83 years) for the Longfin Gulper Shark, and although not species-specific, is informative for inferring the possible levels of reduction of this species in Taiwan.

In Lombok, Indonesia the catch-per-unit effort (CPUE) for Centrophorus spp. declined markedly by 88% from 2016 to 2018 and then remained at the 2018 level in 2019 (Fahmi unpubl. data 2020). In Indonesia, data from a targeted demersal longline fishery for gulper sharks landed in Tenau, East Nusa Tenggara documented a decline in catch-per-unit effort (CPUE) from 145 kg/trip to 78 kg/trip between 2011–2014 (Samusamu and Dharmadi 2017). Total catch of dogfishes, a mixed category for more than 10 species, reported to the Indonesian National Shark Data Collection program decreased from 16,536 t in 2005 to 4,820 t in 2016 (DGCF 2017). This equates to >99% reduction in population over three generation lengths (83 years) of the Longfin Gulper Shark. Centrophorus spp. populations are reported to have collapsed when fished intensively for as little as two decades, as seen in the Maldives and Australia (Graham et al. 2001, Jabado et al. 2017). These collapses indicate that the biologically unproductive Centrophorus spp. are unable to sustain intense target or bycatch fishing pressure.

Fishing pressure (‘actual levels of exploitation’) is high across the range of this species, inferred population declines in Taiwan are 62% across the past three generation lengths of the Longfin Gulper Shark (83 years), with an 88% recent decline in CPUE for all Centrophorus spp. in Lombok, Indonesia over two years, and 99% inferred decline in catches of the Longfin Gulper Shark over three generation lengths (83 years). This species likely has little resilience to fishing pressure. It has refuge in some parts of its range as it occurs beyond the depth of fishing gear. Overall, based on actual levels of exploitation, it is suspected that the Longfin Gulper Shark has undergone a population reduction of 50–79% over the past three generation lengths (83 years).
range: The Longfin Gulper Shark is patchily distributed across the Northwest and Western Central Pacific, and the Eastern Indian Oceans. It is known from Taiwan, eastern Indonesia, and Papua New Guinea (Huon Gulf) and likely, but not morphologically verified, from off Puerto Princesa City, eastern Philippines (White et al. 2017). The specimen from Philippines was slightly different genetically from other Centrophorus longipinnis but similar to an Indonesian specimen that was examined and found to be morphologically identical to the other C. longipinnis specimens (White et al. 2017).
useTrade: In Indonesia, Centrophorus spp. are landed with the livers removed and used for meat; the liver oil is processed locally and exported (Fahmi unpubl. data 2020). Elsewhere, based on other Centrophorus spp., the Longfin Gulper Shark is likely used for its meat, fins (low value), and liver oil (high value) (White et al. 2006, Fields et al. 2018). Individuals too small for human consumption are likely used for fish meal (D. Ebert unpubl. data 2019).
