A genetic study by Arai et al. (2017) found A. anguilla was dominant in the uppermost sample site of the Tone river system. Interspecific competition of this species with A. japonica may pose a threat, due to similarities in functional morphology and similar niche preference. This threat will diminish as the number of European Eels in Japanese waters has substantially decreased over time (Okamura et al. 2008) and the species is very unlikely to successfully escape and spawn outside of its natural range. The exotic A. rostrata has also been found in Taiwan, after being imported at the glass eel stage for farming, and subsequently escaping from aquaculture ponds (Han et al. 2002, Tzeng et al. 2009). This could present a risk of interspecific hybridisation, although successful spawning is unlikely due to species specific migration routes (Han et al. 2002, Tzeng et al. 2009).

Environmental fluctuations, such as changes in ocean circulation, and El Niño, have been proposed to influence larval transport and survival, and as a consequence, the recruitment of glass eels to coastal and freshwater habitats (Kimura et al. 2001, Bonhommeau et al. 2008, Miller et al. 2009, Tzeng et al. 2012, Chang et al. 2016, Lin et al. 2017a, Chang et al. 2018, Hsiung et al. 2018, Hsiung and Kimura 2019). However, there remains considerable uncertainty, surrounding the role of changing oceanographic conditions on all anguillid eel population dynamics and further research is required in order to understand the influence of both natural climatic fluctuations and anthropogenic effects.

Anguilla japonica is the native host of the nematode (Anguillicola crassus) that parasitises the swim bladder and has been proposed to affect survivorship and migration behaviour of non-native species. Japanese Eels, however, appear to show more evidence of acquired immunity and significantly reduced pathological effects than the European Eel (Knopf 2006) possibly because of longer historical exposure to this parasite (Münderle et al. 2006).

As with other anguillid eels, the upstream and downstream migration of the Japanese Eel has been impacted due to the presence of barriers in waterways. In Japan, construction of dams has reduced eel catches in some areas (Tatsukawa 2003). On 135 sampling sites in five rivers in Japan, individual density of Japanese Eel was negatively correlated with cumulative height of dams and weirs located in the lower reach of each sampling site (Ministry of the Environment 2016). Other studies investigated young yellow eels in a small river and reported density is negatively correlated with the number of weirs (Kume et al. 2019, 2020). Shuai et al. (2020) reported that dams could have blocked eel’s migration routes and affected their spatial dispersal.

Other threats include the loss of river habitat due to agricultural, urban and industrial development. Chen et al. (2014) used Landsat imagery to determine the amount of Japanese Eel habitat loss caused by human activity in 16 rivers across East-Asia (Japan, South Korea, Taiwan, China). The study revealed a reduction in effective habitat area of 76.8% from the 1970s to 2010s, with the highest reductions in China (81.5%) and Taiwan (49.3%). In Japan, part of the reduction in river habitat has included the extensive revetment of the shorelines of rivers and lakes for flood control purposes (Yoshimura et al. 2005, Itakura et al. 2015a). In a study comparing areas of natural shoreline to those with revetment, there was found to be lower abundance, poorer body condition, emptier stomachs, and reduced prey diversity within stomach contents, in eels sampled in areas of revetment (Itakura et al. 2015b). 

Development has also increased industrial effluent, and agricultural and urban runoff, all of which are known to negatively impact eel numbers through displacement, reduced reproductive success and direct mortality, particularly during the spawning migration (Tzeng et al. 2006, Drouineau et al. 2018). One example is organochlorines, primarily used in pesticides, which have shown to be persistent in aquatic environments even after their ban (Arai 2014). These chemicals are lipid soluble, and therefore accumulation was greater in silver stage A. japonica and eels that had resided for longer in freshwater (Arai 2014). In Lake Shinji, high concentrations of neonicotinoid insecticide effluent from rice paddies has been indirectly linked to the decline in average fishing yields of eel between 1981–1992 and 1993–2004, after its introduction in 1993 (Yamamuro et al. 2019). This may have been caused by a reduction in aquatic invertebrates, a prey source for A. japonica (Yamamuro et al. 2019). 

Predation of A. japonica naturally occurs in both continental and oceanic life stages. Miyake et al. (2018) studied the influence of predation on glass eel recruitment in the Tone River Estuary, through genetic identification of stomach contents. Glass eels were found in the stomachs of the channel catfish (Ictalurus punctatus) – an invasive species in the river system – and blackfin sea bass (Lateolabrax latus) confirming these species are predators of A. japonica. The level of influence of these predators on A. japonica is unknown, although blackfin sea bass occurs commonly in areas where glass eels recruit, and channel catfish may be a new predator, in rivers where its distribution has expanded.

Disease may constitute another threat for A. japonica. Japanese Eel endothelial cells-infecting virus (JEECV) causes viral endothelial cell necrosis (VECNE), which has an experimental mortality of ~60% (Okazaki et al. 2016). Since the 1980s, this has caused economic loss within eel farms (Okazaki et al. 2016). Infection of wild caught A. japonica at both yellow eel (Okazaki et al. 2015) and elver (Okazaki et al. 2016) development stages has now been reported.
population:
Most population genetic studies have previously indicated that Anguilla japonica consists of one genetically homogenous, panmictic population (Ishikawa et al. 2001, Han et al. 2010, Minegishi et al. 2012, Gong et al. 2014). Recent research (Igarashi et al. 2018), however, found genetic differences among eels captured in different rivers in Japan, providing some evidence to the contrary. However, Gong et al. (2019) did not find any genetic population differentiation between eels from China and Japan, suggesting the weight of evidence still supports panmixia at present.

Several studies using microsatellite analysis have suggested that Japanese Eel elvers show little genetic variation between years. A genetic study carried out by Tseng et al. (2003), for example, suggests that the effective population size (EPS) of the Japanese Eel is declining and the authors speculate that historically this has been due to large scale oceanographic changes. While EPS does not offer a true measure of the number of mature, reproductive individuals in the population, a reduction in this value suggests an overall loss of adaptive genetic variation.

Catch effort can be variable in fishing data, and under-reporting and, in some cases, an absence of reporting of landings, is a serious problem across the range of A. japonica. Thus, landings data of glass eels cannot be accepted as a precise measure of population status (Kaifu 2019). However, due to the large scale of landings data, it can to some extent reflect true changes in fishing yields and is still helpful to understand stock status.

To date, there is only one published stock assessment study of A. japonica. This study, by Tanaka et al. (2014), estimated stock size through ‘exploitable’ (yellow and silver) eel CPUE for Japanese inland waters, glass eel CPUE in Japan, and an age- and sex-structured model. Results from this study estimated that stock size of individuals aged ≥1 year had recovered since 1990 from less than 10,000 tonnes (t), to 18,700 t in 2010, equating to 24% of the carrying capacity. A study by Kaifu (2019) discussed some of the challenges facing a stock assessment of A. japonica. Illegal, unreported and unregulated (IUU) glass eel catches occur in Japan, making it difficult to assess the stock using this life stage, as the catch cannot be translated directly into recruitment (Kaifu 2019). For example, glass eel catch during the 2014 fishing season (1 November 2013 to 31 October 2014) totalled 17.4 t in Japan, but the total reported catch was only 8.0 t, 46.0% of the actual (Kaifu 2019). Other challenges arise when using catch statistics for yellow and silver eels. Particularly in inland waters where fisheries occur in Japan, stocking is known to take place, which biases eel abundance and their natural biological parameters. Using recently developed methods based on otolith stable isotope ratios (Kaifu et al. 2018a), research is beginning to highlight the scale of the presence of stocked eels in inland waters, and the necessity for their consideration within stock assessments (Ministry of Environment 2016, Kaifu et al. 2018b, Itakura et al. 2018, Kaifu 2019).

Glass Eels:

The data sets used in the analysis were as follows: Ministry of Agriculture, Forest and Fisheries (MAFF) compiled glass eel data (Japan), CPUE (catch/fisherman) data sets collected from nine Japanese prefectures; Chiba, Aichi, Tokushima, Oita, Kagoshima, Shizuoka, Mie, Kochi, and Miyazaki. Glass eel catch in these prefectures accounted 70.5% of the entire reported glass eel catch in Japan in 2018 fishing season (November 2017 to October 2018).

According to MAFF statistics, inland and coastal area glass eel catch reported in Japan in 1995 and 2019 – three generation lengths difference - was 20.0 t and 3.7 t, respectively, with large fluctuations between years. Indeed, at the time of writing, the catch in 2020 was higher than in 2019. However, fisheries catch does not necessarily reflect the abundance of the population because of potential fluctuation of fisheries effort.

Glass eel CPUE (glass eel catch per fisherman) in nine different Japanese prefectures (data from Tanaka (2014) updated based on communications with the nine prefectures) in 1994 and 2018 was 0.4483 and 0.2365, respectively. CPUE has decreased by 47.2% over 24 years (three generations). Based on GLM analysis, the glass eel CPUE in the nine prefectures has significantly decreased for both periods of 1977–2018 and 2003–2018 (Kaifu and Yokouchi 2019).

The estimate of exploitation rate of glass eel (or elver) in an estuary in northern Taiwan indicated that this life stage was heavily fished, which will influence the population size of yellow/silver eels in the river (Tzeng 1984, Lin et al. 2015, 2017b, Lin and Tzeng 2018).

Yellow/Silver Eels:

The most recent FAO statistics (in 2017) suggest that landings are as low as 119 t although there is no indication of effort from these data (FAO 2019). In 2013 the Japanese Eel was assessed as 'Endangered' on the Japanese Red List (published by the Ministry of Environment, based on the catch data of inland eels compiled by the MAFF). This report indicated a 72–92% decline in the species over three generations (12–45 years). Total annual yellow and silver eel catch across the 47 prefectures significantly decreased from 1,413 t to 71 t during 1987–2017, a reduction of 95.0% over three generations (Anon. 1958–2018). A recent study using otolith Strontium isotope ratios (87Sr/86Sr) reported that the otolith ratios of spawning adult Japanese Eels captured at the spawning area were most similar to the ratios of Japanese water, rather than that of Korea, mainland China and Taiwan waters (Otake et al. 2019). This indicates population dynamics of yellow and silver eels in Japan might be an appropriate indicator of the whole population dynamics of A. japonica. Although the MAFF data suggest widespread declines across the 47 prefectures of Japan (Anon. 1958–2018), the data only consider eels in inland waters, i.e. rivers/lakes, and it is estimated that  56–86% of Japanese Eels remain in estuarine/saline waters throughout their lives (Tsukamoto and Arai 2001, Tzeng et al. 2002, Arai et al. 2003, Kotake et al. 2003, 2005, Tsukamoto et al. 2009, Mochioka et al. 2012, Yokouchi et al. 2012). It has been suggested that a latitudinal cline exists, in the degree to which Japanese Eels utilise either freshwater or saline environments in Japan and Taiwan (Tsukamoto et al. 2009). In southern regions, a higher proportion of eels enter freshwater habitats, whereas in northern regions more eels remain in saline habitats (Tsukamoto et al. 2009). This behaviour appears to coincide with productivity, and therefore food abundance, which is greater in marine environments in the north, and similarly in freshwater environments in the south (Tsukamoto and Arai 2001, Tsukamoto et al. 2009).

It is suggested that eel stocking in Japan has biased assessments of the population dynamics of this species (Kaifu 2019). Otolith stable isotopes have been recently used to determine the proportion of stocked eels in some locations in Japan. In Okayama prefecture, 98.1% of sampled eels in three rivers where stocking had occurred were identified as stocked individuals (Kaifu et al. 2018b). In the Tone River watershed, wild eel proportions differed with site, and dominance of stocked eels was highest closest to release sites, suggesting reduced dispersal of these individuals (Itakura et al. 2018). A study by the Ministry of Environment of Japan found 62% of eels (n = 92) captured from 10 water systems in Japan to be stocked after application of a discrimination model (Ministry of Environment 2016, in: Kaifu 2019). Stocking affects population dynamics by introducing additional individuals into wild eel populations. Moreover, in an age-based cohort model, stocking-related ageing error strongly affected estimates of total biomass (Kullmann et al. 2018). Data on eel biological characteristics, such as survival rate, growth rate and sex ratio, are essential for assessments of their population dynamics (e.g. Tanaka 2014); however, these characteristics can differ significantly between naturally recruited wild and cultured-and-stocked eels (Kaifu et al. 2018b, Kaifu 2019). Therefore, yellow and silver eel population dynamics should be investigated where the possible bias of eel stocking is expected to be relatively low to minimise error.

Japanese Eels are fished in both inland and coastal waters in Japan, while eel stocking has been conducted only in inland waters. The standardised yellow and silver eel CPUE was significantly decreased in four of the six fisheries cooperative associations in coastal and estuarine areas of Japan (Kaifu and Yokouchi 2019). Significant relationships between CPUE and year were not found for the other two associations. Catches between 2003 and 2016 in coastal waters of Okayama Prefecture, where naturally-recruited wild eels are dominant, peaked in November and December (Kaifu et al. 2018b). This is when Japanese Eels start their spawning migration, although monthly catch and peak values were found to decrease over time, and longline and setnet CPUE decreased between 2003 and 2016 by 79.6%, and 79.5% respectively (Kaifu et al. 2018b). In addition, a survey of 1,509 fisheries cooperative associations in Japanese coastal waters where stocking of eels has not taken place reported that 93.4% of the 227 fisheries cooperative associations that confirmed they catch eels stated that they believe the Japanese Eel stock to be declining or relatively declining (Kaifu and Yokouchi 2019).

Han and Tzeng (2006) report an 81–88% female bias in sex ratio of yellow and silver eels caught at one locality, the Kaoping River, in south-western Taiwan. Furthermore, in the lower reaches of this river, density was revealed to be 0.01 eels/m² in 2001 and 2002 and the estimated abundance of eels in Kaoping River ranged from 7,137 to 31,360 individuals in 2001, and from 3,324 to 22,040 individuals in 2002 (Han and Tzeng 2006). Studies have found males to dominate at higher densities and so the low density and female bias in this River supports this theory (Han and Tzeng 2006).

When considering all the available data on its multiple life-history stages, A. japonica is estimated to have suffered at least a 50% population decline over a period of three generations (24 years; see ‘Habitat and Ecology’).
range:
It is known that Anguilla japonica occurs as a native species in Japan, China, Taiwan, Province of China (hereafter referred to as Taiwan) and Republic of Korea (hereafter referred to as South Korea). The range of this species extends from the Pacific coast of Japan and south to Hainan Island covering large areas of mainland China, Taiwan and South Korea. There are some records of recruitment along the coasts of the Sea of Japan, Yellow Sea and in low abundance in Northern Luzon Island, Philippines, the Chao Phraya basin in Thailand and Cambodia. It is thought that these vagrant individuals might not contribute greatly to the population as they are outside the influence of currents that are essential to the successful completion of the life cycle.

Eggs and preleptocephali for this species have been collected in the North Equatorial Current (NEC) along the western side of the West Mariana Ridge (14–17oN, 142–143oE) to the west of the Mariana Islands and were captured during new moon periods (Tsukamoto 2006, 2009, Tsukamoto et al. 2011, Aoyama et al. 2014). Timings of egg and preleptocephali catch also overlapped with catch of breeding-condition adult eels from the same area, confirming this area, west of the Mariana Islands, as the spawning location for this species (Chow et al. 2009, Kurogi et al. 2011, Tsukamoto et al. 2011). The possible spawning depth of adult eels has been suggested to lie in a vertically narrow depth stratum of 150–200 m, just below the upper limit of the thermocline sitting at 150 m (Tsukamoto et al. 2011). The NEC and Kuroshio Current are the predominant transport mechanisms for this species (Tzeng et al. 2012) but the latitude of spawning events, varies between years depending upon oceanic conditions (Kimura and Tsukamoto 2006, Miller et al. 2009, Aoyama et al. 2014). Spawning is thought to occur between April and August (Shinoda et al. 2011). The early, vagrant recruitment of Japanese glass eels occurs around the north-eastern coast of Luzon Island in the Philippines in late October and then in greater abundance in Taiwan in early November, with the main fishing season there being between November and February (Han 2011). After two to four weeks, recruitment occurs in the Fujian Province of China and the Pacific coast of southern Japan, where the main fishing season is between December and February (Han 2011). In the Zhejiang and Guangdong Provinces of China, Jeju Island, and Pacific coast of central Japan, the main fishing season occurs between January and March (Han 2011). From February to April, recruitment is concentrated in the southern Jiangsu Province of China (around Yangtze River estuary), the southern coast of South Korea, and east coast of Japan (Han 2011). In the northern Jiangsu Province of China and the west coast of South Korea, the main fishing seasons are between March and May (Han 2011). The final recruits occur on the north-western coast of South Korea and the Yalu River estuary in northern China between April and June (Cheng and Tzeng 1996, Han 2011, Han et al. 2019). However, recruitment peaks have been observed in June in 2010 and 2011 in the Pacific coast of central Japan (Aoyama et al. 2012). The results indicate that variations in the recruitment season may occur.  

The natural range of A. japonica within countries such as Japan is difficult to determine because of widespread restocking activities. Recently, coastal regions of Kyushu, Seto Inland Sea, and in Honshu, the Pacific side south of Aomori Prefecture, and the Sea of Japan side south of Kyoto Prefecture, were identified as the main areas of distribution for naturally recruited yellow-phase A. japonica in Japan (Yoneta et al. 2019).
useTrade:
The various life stages, ranging from glass to silver, of all anguillid species are harvested and traded on a global scale for farming and consumption, with current demand predominantly driven by East Asian markets, in particular Japan, South Korea and China. A concerning pattern of exploitation is already apparent – when one Anguilla species or population becomes over-exploited, industry moves to the next in order to fulfil demand (Gollock et al. 2018).

Together with A. anguilla (the European Eel), A. japonica has one of the longest histories of fishing, stocking and farming for consumption purposes of all the Anguilla species. Japanese Eels are utilized/traded live, fresh, smoked, canned and frozen and eaten steamed, broiled and baked and also to some extent in East Asian medicines. A. japonica was historically caught in waters throughout its range, with large eels caught destined directly consumption or juvenile eels destined for farming, from the early 1900s onwards (Shiraishi and Crook 2015).

Global FAO catch data for the Japanese Eel is available for the period of 1950–2017. From the 1950s to 1986, annual catches (not life stage specific) fluctuated between 2,000 and 3,600 tonnes (t) (in 1969), averaging 2,600 t per year. From 1987 onwards reported catches gradually declined by 50–100 t on average per year, and in 2017 they were only 119 t. Over 90% of these catches were reported by Japan, with Taiwan and South Korea only reporting small quantities, and mainland China none. See ‘Population’ section for more detailed and national catch statistics for A. japonica.

According to FAO data, total annual global Anguilla production (catch and aquaculture) has steadily increased since the 1950s, mainly due to the expansion of farming in East Asia. In 2016, eel farming accounted for 98% of total eel production (over 290,000 t), with mainland China responsible for nearly 86% (FAO 2018). Eel farming is reliant on wild-caught juvenile eels (glass eels/elvers) as “seed” as breeding in captivity and producing glass eels is not yet commercially viable. The preferred species for farming in East Asia is A. japonica and high demand for this declining resource has resulted in dramatic increases in price for this species. According to the Joint Press Release (Anonymous 2017) and other sources annual A. japonica glass eel input into farms in mainland China, Japan, South Korea and Taiwan between 2008 and 2017 has declined significantly, however with some fluctuations between years (due to large variations in A. japonica glass eel recruitment), e.g. input was 24.1 t in 2012–2013,  but then 98.5 t in 2013–2014. Declines in availability and ongoing demand has led to increase in harvest and trade in juveniles of other Anguilla spp. in recent years and this is particularly apparent during poor A. japonica recruitment years such as in 2012–2013 (Shiraishi and Crook 2015, Gollock et al. 2018). See Shiraishi and Crook (2015) and Gollock et al. (2018) for a detailed analysis of Anguilla spp. and A. japonica farming production.

Live eels and meat are traded globally for consumption and to a much smaller extent Anguilla skins and leather products are also in international trade. Global Customs trade data for live, fresh, frozen and prepared/preserved eel (non-species-specific) are available for the last 40 years.  According to FAO and UN Comtrade, global annual exports of Anguilla averaged around 20,000 t in the late 1970s, after which annual exports showed a steady increase to a maximum of over 130,000 t in 2001. Since then annual exports have been declining, to just over 80,000 t in 2008–2011, increasing again slightly to ~90,000 t in 2013–2015. The export value of these commodities has steadily increased over the past 40 years, reaching USD ~1.6 billion in 2012. Over the last decade, of the four commodity types, live and prepared/preserved eel accounted for nearly 80% of total exports by weight, and China has been the main eel exporter and Japan the main importer. As noted above, a high percentage of eel in international trade is derived from eels having been grown out in farms, and A. japonica is believed to make up a significant proportion of this. A detailed analysis of recent international Anguilla trade, including A. japonica is provided in Gollock et al. (2018).
conservationActions:
Due to their broad geographic range and multiple life stages, conservation measures for Anguilla japonica can be challenging to implement. Research resources appear to have been focused on the aquaculture and ecology of oceanic life stages, although some recent studies have begun to address population dynamics (e.g. Tanaka 2014, Yokouchi et al. 2014, Fisheries Agency 2018, Kaifu et al. 2018b, Kaifu 2019), habitat restoration (e.g. Chen et al. 2014, Yokouchi et al. 2014, Itakura et al. 2015a,b, Ministry of the Environment 2016, Kume et al. 2019) and restocking (e.g. Lin et al. 2010, Kaifu et al. 2018a, Itakura et al. 2018) in order to promote conservation and sustainable use of Japanese Eels.

In 2003, a study was published documenting the first successful captive production of glass eels in Japan from reared larvae and the life cycle was fully closed in 2010 (Masuda et al. 2012). For mass production of eels in Japan to become biologically and economically viable, however, better feed, disease prevention and a simplification and shortening of the rearing process are still required (Masuda et al. 2012). In 2014, the Alliance for Sustainable Eel Aquaculture (ASEA) was established by Japan, South Korea, China and Taiwan, under the structure of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC), to increase collaboration, and discuss effective laws relating to eel resource conservation and management (Tzeng 2016).

In Japan, catch of juvenile eels is only permitted with a license, which is issued in order to capture seed for aquaculture or research within a limited fishing period. Illegal and unreported catch still remains a significant problem, with this catch potentially representing at least double the legal reported catch (Kaifu 2019). The capture of silver eels is prohibited or restricted in ten prefectures and voluntarily suspended in eight other prefectures, with the aim of preserving spawning eels in these areas. Restocking rivers and lakes with young eels for stock enhancement has also been carried out for many years in Japan. However, stocking can disrupt population dynamics, through differences in survival and growth rates, and sex ratios between cultured/stocked and naturally-recruited wild individuals (Kaifu 2019). It may be that moving eels from one location to stock another, results in an inability to migrate to the spawning area (Westin 2003). The International Council for the Exploration of the Sea (ICES) concluded that huge knowledge gaps still exist as to the benefits of stocking, and further research and consistent monitoring is necessary to better assess and understand the effects (ICES 2016).

In China, the numbers of fishing licenses are restricted. In Taiwan, a regulation to control export of juvenile eel was introduced in 2007, banning export between November and March (Shiraishi and Crook 2015). The last available information for glass eels used for farming showed in 2014–15 the harvesting period was reduced to four months (1st November 2014–28th February 2015) (Shiraishi and Crook 2015). With a view to protect eel habitat, Yilian County, historically the major glass eel harvest region, has prohibited fishing (Han 2018). In addition, catch of young and larger eels has already been prohibited in 33 rivers of other regions (Han 2018). Regulations have been amended with regard to the control of eel farming activities since November 2014 (Han 2018). The Fisheries Agency reviews and updates the amount of glass eels to be input by fish farmers annually, and each fish farmer is subject to the control and management of a license system and individual input limit (Han 2018). The upper limit for glass eel input for Japanese Eel is set at 10 metric tons (Han 2018). Japanese Eel are also stocked into rivers (Han 2018). Anguilla japonica has recently been listed on the Red List of Taiwan as Nationally Critically Endangered (Yang et al. 2017).

At the international level, co-operation among Japan, China and Taiwan began in 2012, who aimed to establish strengthened management of Japanese Eel fisheries as well as the introduction of traceability schemes. In September 2014, a ‘Joint Statement’ was adopted by China, Japan, South Korea and Taiwan, for the conservation and management of the Japanese Eel, through a restriction on the amount of eel seed that can be used in aquaculture production annually (Anonymous 2014). Based on the Joint Statement (Anonymous 2014), the annual input of Japanese Eel seed since the 2015 season (1 November 2014–31 October 2015) has been limited to 78.8 t, 80% of the input in the 2014 season. The same input quota has been still in place up to the 2020 season (Fisheries Agency of Japan 2019b). The actual quantities reportedly used for aquaculture were lower than the quota: 37.8 t and 40.8 t in the 2015 and 2016 seasons, respectively (Kaifu et al. 2019). From 2017 onwards, a complete data set is not available.

The Philippines has legislation that applies to trade of all anguillid species (i.e. export ban on juvenile eels ≤15cm in length), though A. japonica is a very low proportion of catches in this range State (Gollock et al. 2018).

In summary, there has been a focus to date on fisheries regulation for A. japonica, and interventions relating to the many other threats facing the species are essential.

rationale: The Spinetail Devil Ray (Mobula mobular) is a large (to 350 cm DW) pelagic species which is circumglobal in tropical and subtropical waters from the surface to 1,112 m deep. Within this broad range, populations appear to be patchily distributed and the global population size is unknown. The species has a conservative life history, producing only one pup on average every 1–3 years and likely has a very low intrinsic rate of population increase. The Spinetail Devil Ray is a large component of targeted fisheries and a bycatch of many small- and large-scale fisheries, with much of this catch unreported or aggregated as Mobula species. The depths and regions used by the Spinetail Devil Ray coincide with many artisanal and industrial fisheries raising concerns about previously unreported and continued bycatch. Steep population declines are evident in the Indian and Pacific Oceans, including India and Indonesia. The lack of species-specific catch records, fishing effort, and population data necessitates the use of genus-wide inferences to assess some population reductions, however notable declines in landings of 50–96% over 15 years have been documented in Indonesia, and extinction is suspected in areas with intense and growing fishing pressure. The Spinetail Devil Ray has a widespread global range and in some parts of its distribution such as Australia, New Zealand and some Pacific countries, the threat would likely be far less than elsewhere due to lower fishing pressure and strong fisheries management. The Spinetail Devil Ray is used locally and sometimes nationally, and often traded internationally, with the rise of the valuable gill plate trade increasing pressure on the species. Unlike for some of the other mobulid species, the development of localized marine protected areas is unlikely to provide this species any significant protection from fisheries due to its large-scale movements. Based on actual levels of exploitation, steep declining population trends, a conservative life history, and the increasing trade demand, a global population reduction of 50–79% over the past three generation lengths (38 years) is suspected, with a further population reduction suspected over the next three generation lengths (2018–2056). The Spinetail Devil Ray is therefore assessed as Endangered (A2bd+3d).
habitat: The Spinetail Devil Ray is a pelagic species that resides in coastal and continental shelf waters. It spends the majority of its time in less than 50 m of water but occasionally dives to depths of 1,112 m (Canese et al. 2011, Croll et al. 2012, Holcer et al. 2013, Francis and Jones 2017). The species exhibits large-scale movements, up to 1,800 km at minimum speeds of 63 km per day likely driven by seasonal patterns in prey availability (Freund et al. 2000, Canese et al. 2011, Croll et al. 2012, Francis and Jones 2017). The species reaches a maximum size of 350 cm DW (Notarbartolo di Sciara et al. 2020), with significant geographical variation in size across its distribution. Males mature at 200–220 cm disc width (DW) and females mature at 215–240 cm disc width (DW). Reproduction is aplacental matrotrophic with a gestation period of 12 months, and generally a single large pup (though two per litter occur occasionally) of 90–160 cm DW. The reproductive cycle is 1–3 years, with resting periods between pregnancies in some years (White et al. 2006, Last et al. 2016, Rambahiniarison et al. 2018, Stevens et al. 2018). Female age-at-maturity is estimated as 5–6 years and maximum age estimated as 20 years (Cuevas-Zimbrón et al. 2013, Pardo et al. 2016); generation length is therefore 12.8 years.
threats:
Mobulid species, including the Spinetail Devil Ray, are both targeted and caught incidentally in industrial and artisanal fisheries (Couturier et al. 2012, Croll et al. 2016, Stewart et al. 2018). These rays are captured in a wide range of gear types including harpoons, drift nets, purse seine nets, gillnets, traps, trawls, and longlines. Their coastal and offshore distribution, and tendency to aggregate makes mobulids particularly susceptible to bycatch in purse seine and longline fisheries, targeted capture in artisanal fisheries, and incidental entanglement (Croll et al. 2016, Duffy and Griffiths 2017).

Mobula rays, including Spinetail Devil Rays, are caught in at least 13 targeted artisanal fisheries in 12 countries. Some of the largest documented fisheries have been in Indonesia, the Philippines, India, Sri Lanka, México, Taiwan, Mozambique, Gaza, and Peru (Courturier et al. 2012, Ward-Paige et al. 2013, Croll et al. 2016), where sometimes thousands of manta and devilrays are landed per year (Alava et al. 2002, Dewar 2002, White et al. 2006, Lewis et al. 2015). While many artisanal fisheries have grown into trade fisheries, some still target these rays mainly for food and local products (White et al. 2006, Essumang 2010, Rohner et al. 2017). These species are also caught incidentally as bycatch throughout their ranges in tuna fisheries, in nine large-scale fisheries in 11 countries, and in at least 21 small-scale fisheries in 15 countries (Croll et al. 2016). Despite being unintentionally caught, mobulids are typically kept because of their high trade value and even when discarded alive, they are often injured and have high post-release mortality (Tremblay-Boyer and Brouwer 2016, Francis and Jones 2017).

Even after Appendix listings on the Convention for the Conservation of Migratory Species of Wild Animals (CMS) and the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Flora and Fauna (CITES), and dozens of national fishing bans, many fisheries remain open and active. Robust, quantitative assessments of the Spinetail Devil Ray are challenging because multiple mobulid species are caught and landed simultaneously, and species identification continues to be a source of error in this group (Croll et al. 2016).

Global landings of mobulid species, including Spinetail Devil Ray, have been increasing steadily due in large part to the recent rise (from the 1990s onwards) in demand for gill plates (O’Malley et al. 2017). Many former bycatch fisheries have become directed commercial export fisheries (Dewar 2002, White et al. 2006, Fernando and Stevens 2011, Heinrichs et al. 2011). Between 2000 and 2007, total landings of ‘Mantas, devil rays nei’ ('nei' refers to 'not elsewhere included') increased from 900 tonnes to over 3,300 tonnes according to the FAO Fishstat Capture Production database (Lack and Sant 2009). While this equates to an average of 1,593 tonnes being landed per year, reported landings are likely to represent only a fraction of total fishing-related mortality (Ward-Paige et al. 2013). 

In the markets of Guangzhou, China, where 99% of mobulid products are routed, mobulid products are sourced from over 20 countries and regions (O’Malley et al. 2017). The source locations for the largest amounts of product are Indonesia, Sri Lanka, India, China, and Viet Nam (O’Malley et al. 2017). Demand for products has driven up the price and traded volume of these products in recent decades. Between 2011 and 2013, there was an increase from 60 to 120 t of mobulid product moved through shops in Guangzhou (O’Malley et al. 2017).  

In the Mediterranean Sea, a directed fishery for the Spinetail Devil Ray exists in the Levantine Sea off Gaza and this species has been recorded in the Sardinian tuna trap fishery (Storai et al. 2009). Purse seiners have targeted these rays, which seasonally aggregate in the region, since the 1970s. The catch, which averaged 169 animals per year between 2013 and 2016 but can exceed 500 individuals, is used for local consumption (Couturier et al. 2013, Abudaya et al. 2018). Bycatch moralities of the Spinetail Devil Ray have been reported in a range of gears in the Mediterranean Sea (Akyol et al. 2005, Orsi Relini et al. 1999, Bradaï and Capape 2001, Hemida et al. 2002, Scacco et al. 2009, Holcer et al. 2013, O’Malley et al. 2017, Abudaya et al. 2018). 

In the Western Indian Ocean, Romanov (2002) estimated that between 253 and 539 manta rays and devilrays were being caught per year as bycatch in purse seine fisheries. In Pakistan, the Spinetail Devil Ray represented 60% of the mobulids landed by number in tuna gillnet fisheries (Nawaz and Khan 2015). In India, it is estimated that ~1,215 Spinetail Devil Rays are landed yearly (Heinrichs et al. 2011). From July 2012 to December 2013, a total of 1,994 devilrays were recorded from landing site surveys in India, of which 95% were Spinetail Devil Rays (G. Mohanraj pers. comm. 10/11/2018). In Kerala, this species represented 75% of devilrays landed in 2012 (Nair et al. 2013). It is the most common species landed in Sri Lanka, representing 87% of devilray landings by number, with targeted fisheries reportedly landing ~48,357 individuals yearly (Fernando and Stevens 2011).

In the Western and Central Pacific from 2010–2015, observed bycatch of mobulids (excluding Giant Manta Ray (Mobula birostris)) in purse seine fisheries was 4,324 individuals, and in longline fisheries was 410 individuals. Some of these were identified as Spinetail Devil Ray, although the numbers of those reported were low (from 1995–2015, 78 individuals in purse seines and 112 individuals in longlines) and the numbers reported as Mobula spp. much higher, hence many were not identified to species (Tremblay-Boyer and Brouwer 2016). Few individuals were released in good condition, with most released dead or alive but injured, suggesting high post-release mortality (Francis and Jones 2017). Between 2005 and 2014, this species was caught in 8.2% of all observed Skipjack Tuna (Katsuwonus pelamis) purse seine sets in New Zealand waters (Francis and Jones 2017) and 24.5% of sets in aggregation hotspots for the species. 

The Inter-American Tropical Tuna Commission (IATTC) purse seine vessels operating from 2015 in the Pacific reported landings of 71 tonnes of mobulid species, including Spinetail Devil Rays (Miller and Klimovich 2017). The Eastern Pacific purse seine fisheries show a substantial increase in the bycatch of mobulid species, including Spinetail Devil Rays, from 20 tonnes per year before 2005 to 150 tonnes per year by 2006, which was then reduced to 10 tonnes per year by 2009 (Hall and Roman 2013). Peru is ranked as having the 15th largest global batoid landings, representing 11% of total landings worldwide between 2005 and 2011. Mobulid landings were 28% of total batoid landings, with the largest proportion of landings coming from the northern coast (Gonzalez-Pestana et al. 2016). In a small-scale fishery off northern Peru, over 6,000 devilrays are estimated as landed per year with 97–99% of these landings being the Spinetail Devil Ray (Alfaro-Cordova et al. 2017); it is unlikely that these catches are sustainable. 

Indirect and sublethal sources of mortality include habitat destruction and degradation, climate change, ocean acidification, recreational foul hooking, vessel strikes, oil spills, and other pollution and contaminants (e.g. heavy metals) (Essumang 2010, Ooi et al. 2015, Stewart et al. 2018). Furthermore, shallow water lagoon systems have been identified as important nursery habitats of other mobulids where the effects of habitat destruction and degradation and pollution may affect the survival of juvenile Spinetail Devil Rays (Stewart et al. 2018).
population:
There are no current or historical estimates of the global abundance of the Spinetail Devil Ray. Despite a broad worldwide distribution, populations appear to be patchily distributed. Abundance also appears to vary substantially and may be based on food availability and the degree that they have been, or are currently being, fished. Like many mobulid species, the Spinetail Devil Ray is often solitary but may aggregate in large numbers to feed or reproduce. Abundance estimates have been attempted with aerial surveys in some areas like the northwest Mediterranean Sea, where a population of up to 12,700 individuals was estimated (Fortuna et al. 2014, Notarbartolo di Sciara et al. 2015).

In the Mediterranean Sea, the population trend is unknown, but it is suspected to be decreasing.

In India, population reductions are suspected based on declines in devilray catches, while effort has increased in several regions, including Kerala, along the Tuticorin coast, and Mumbai (Mohanraj et al. 2009, Couturier et al. 2012). Landings data from trawlers operating out of Mumbai revealed maximum landings of 6.3 tonnes (t) for 'M. diabolus' (an invalid name, possibly referring at least in part to the Spinetail Devil Ray) in 1993–95 surveys, declining to 4.8 t in 1996–98, and then to 3.1 t in 1999–2001 and 2002–2004 (Raje and Zacharia 2009). This represents a 51% decline in landings over approximately 10 years during which time fishing effort almost doubled. From this decline in catch and increase in effort, local population declines can be inferred. Such declines are unquantifiable to species-level given the potential grouping of several species under one synonym and the difficulty of identification. In Sri Lanka, fishermen have reported declines in mobulid catches over the past 5 to 10 years as targeted fishing pressure has increased (Fernando and Stevens 2011). Data collected since 2011 shows a steady decline in both 2013 and 2014, although fishing pressure has either remained stable or increased (D. Fernando unpubl. data). Overall, the rate of population reduction of devilrays appears to be high in the region. The scale and effects of devilray fisheries in Sri Lanka and India suggest considerable population reduction regionally (Heinrichs et al. 2011).

In Southeast Asia, mobulids have been increasingly targeted in many countries, most notably the Philippines and Indonesia. In Indonesia, the landed catch of 'mobulids' and 'Mobula spp.' has declined by 63–94% over a 15-year period in three main landing sites (Tanjung Luar, Lombok; Lamakera, Solor, and Cilacap, West Java), despite evidence of increased directed fishing effort at two of the sites (Tanjung Luar and Lamakera; Lewis et al. 2015). From 2001–2014, landings of Spinetail Devil Ray declined by 96% in Tanjung Luar, and by 50% in Cilacap (Lewis et al. 2015). Local population depletions can be inferred from an increase in the number of operating fishing vessels concurrent with these landed catch declines. Intense and increasing fisheries for mobulids (which includes the Spinetail Devil Ray), including some fisheries that have been operating for many decades, are now facing depletion of stocks, with the fishery either collapsing or fishers having to seek out new fishing grounds often significantly further distances away (Dewar 2002, Lewis et al. 2015). Intense, directed fisheries (over 22 active fishery sites) for mobulid species have existed in the Philippines, particularly the Sulu Sea, for over a century with steep historical declines suspected based on fishing effort and landings data (Alava 2002, Acebes and Tull 2016, Rambahiniarison et al. 2018). As in Indonesia, depletion is suspected in areas, although targeted fishing continues in some locations (Rambahiniarison et al. 2018).

Throughout most of its range, populations of the Spinetail Devil Ray appear to be in decline, due to directed fishing and incidental capture as bycatch. Declines can be inferred in many regions based on declines in landings or sightings concurrent with increasing effort (Couturier et al. 2012, Ward-Paige et al. 2013, Croll et al. 2016). Furthermore, reports from fishers and traders of devilray gill plates indicate that they are becoming harder to source, with prices escalating as the supply continues to decline (O’Malley et al. 2017). Regional extinction is suspected in areas with intense and increasing fishing pressure (Lewis et al. 2015). In some parts of its distribution such as Australia, New Zealand, and some Pacific countries, the threat would likely be far less than elsewhere due to lower fishing pressure and in the former two countries, strong fisheries management. Globally, based on current levels of exploitation and declining population trends, the suspected population reduction is 50–79% over the past three generation lengths (38 years), with a further population reduction suspected over the next three generation lengths (2018–2056).
range: The Spinetail Devil Ray is circumglobal in temperate and tropical waters throughout all oceans. Notably, it is present in the Mediterranean Sea but absent in the Red Sea (Notarbartolo-di-Sciara 1987, Notarbartolo di Sciara et al. 2017) and its occurrence is patchy throughout its distribution (Lawson et al. 2017).
useTrade: Mobulids are widely used for their meat, skin, liver oil, and gill plates (Couturier et al. 2012). The gill plates fetch high prices in Asia and are used for Chinese health tonics (O’Malley et al. 2017). The meat from mobulids is often used for food and shark bait or attractant, and the skin is sometimes used for leather products (shoes, wallets, and knife handles). Mobulids including the Spinetail Devil Ray are used in aquarium display tanks, e.g. in some Gulf countries (R. Jabado pers. obs. 06/02/2017), the USA, Europe, and Japan.
conservationActions:
The success of actions agreed through international wildlife and fisheries treaties depends on implementation at the domestic level; for elasmobranchs, such follow up actions have to date been seriously lacking.

Mobulids were listed on Appendix I and II of CMS in 2014, reflecting Parties’ commitments to strictly protect the species and work regionally toward conservation, respectively. Implementation, however, has been slow. This species is also covered by the CMS Memorandum of Understanding for Migratory Sharks and a special suite of 'Concerted Actions' (based on the IUCN Species Survival Commission Shark Specialist Group's (SSG) Global Devil and Manta Ray Conservation Strategy; see Lawson et al. 2017), which are aimed at facilitating conservation. Mobula species were listed on Appendix II of CITES in 2016, which requires CITES Parties to provide a non-detriment finding to determine whether trade of Mobula products is sustainable.

This species is included among 24 elasmobranch species listed in 2001 on Annex II (Endangered or Threatened Species) of the Barcelona Convention Protocol concerning Special Protected Areas and Biological Diversity in the Mediterranean. In 2012, the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM) banned retention and mandated careful release for these species. Implementation by GFCM Parties, however, has been slow.

In 2015, IATTC prohibited Mobula species caught by large-scale fisheries in the IATTC Convention Area from being retained, sold, etc., and mandated prompt, careful release; exceptions for small-scale Eastern Pacific fisheries are meant to allow only domestic consumption. The Western and Central Pacific Fisheries Commission (WCPFC) added Mobula species to their 'key shark species' list (for assessment only) in 2016 and adopted safe release guidelines in 2017. Proposals to ban retention of Mobula species under the WCPFC and the Indian Ocean Tuna Commission (IOTC) have been unsuccessful to date.

On national and local scales, 'Manta' rays tend to be subject to more protections than devilrays.

To allow recovery, it is recommended that mobulid landings be prohibited, in line with several international agreements, at least as long as the global populations are threatened. Short of that, improved reporting of catch and discard data, regional and national limits on catch based on scientific advice and/or the precautionary approach, efforts to minimize bycatch mortality, protocols for safe release, and codes of conduct for responsible tourism are urgently needed, as is full implementation of additional commitments agreed through international treaties. The IUCN SSG Global Devil and Manta Ray Conservation Strategy provides more detailed information regarding priority conservation actions (see Lawson et al. 2017).

rationale: This species is undergoing a continuing decline in quality of habitat, its range is severely fragmented, and its area of occupancy (AOO) is approximately 11.5 km². This species therefore is listed as Endangered under B2ab(iii).
habitat:
Lupinoblennius paivai dwells in coastal streams and rivulets under tidal influence in salinities ranging from 0 to 35 ppt (Sazima and Carvalho-Filho 2003). It is the only American blenniid recorded thus far from freshwater (at ebb tide) along with two primary freshwater fishes, since the other two species within the genus are recorded from brackish water only. In larger streams such as the Rio Claro and Rio Picinguaba, its range extends for about 500-600 m upriver (Sazima and Carvalho-Filho 2003).  

A benthopelagic species, adults prefer the tunnels drilled by ship-worms in submerged branches of bank vegetation. At ebb tide, it may seek vacant hollows and endure hours out of the water. L. paivai feeds on isopod and amphipod crustaceans (Sazima and Carvalho-Filho 2003). It occasionally swims like a half-waterlogged leaf moving in the slow current. This species is oviparous; eggs are demersal and adhesive (Breder and Rosen 1966). Egg clutches found within drilled tunnels by ship-worms are attended by the male (Sazima and Carvalho-Filho 2003). There is an apparent sexual dimorphism with males showing a higher dorsal fin and prominent flap on its anterior edge. Territorial males adopt a dark colour while flashing the bright turquoise spot of the dorsal fin. Contests are size-dominated and may be restricted to displaying dark colours and turquoise spot, or the opponents may enter in physical combat, nipping at each other. Larvae hatch at about 3.5 mm and settle at about 8 mm SL (Sazima and Carvalho-Filho 2003).
threats:
Lupinoblennius paivai may be at risk of habitat degradation due to the steady decline of streams and mangroves along the Brazilian coast.  According to (Sazima and Carvalho-Filho 2003): "L. paivai inhabits coastal streams and rivulets under tidal influence, habitats currently under serious threat in Brazil due to continued deforestation, urbane development , and sewage disposal ... In the seventies, L. paivai was much more common and widespread in the Rio Escuro than it is nowadays (I. Sazima pers.obs) and its conspicuous population decline is probably related to sewage disposal from several recent and continuously growing human settlements along the stream. The algal cover on branches (important for L. paivai larval settlement and development of both juveniles and small adults) became very thin and sparse there, and in most sites it disappeared completely or was replaced by mats of blue-green algae (Cyanophyta), an additional indication of sewage pollution.  Moreover, local people cut down bank vegetation for fences and firewood, a practice which takes away shelters as well as spawning sites for L. paivai.  Although its population visibly declined in the Rio Escuro, L. paivai still thrives in streams where human-induced habitat changes are lower, such as the Rio Picinguaba and Rio Claro. The widespread and increasing habitat loss and decline, combined with its apparently narrow range in the lower reaches of coastal streams, qualify L. paivai to the lower risk (LR nt) according to the IUCN (1996) Red List system."

There are approximately 88 small streams and 17 larger rivers along the coast of Brazil within this species' range (as estimated from Google earth maps).  The distance between the rivers and streams is often significant and therefore the habitat is severely fragmented.  The average width of the mouth of small streams is approximately 0.05 km while the approximate average width of the larger rivers is 1 km. The length of the habitat up stream from the ocean for small rivers is a maximum of 300 meters, while for larger river this extends up to 600 meters (Sazima and Carvahlo-Filho 2003). Therefore, at about 11.5 km², the AOO of this species is greater than 10 km² but much less than 500 km².
population:
This species is elusive in fresh and brackish water because of its cryptic behaviour and habitat. However, it is not uncommon (Sazima and Carvalho-Filho 2003).

In the 1970s, L. paivai was much more common and widespread in the Rio Escuro than it is nowadays (I. Sazima, pers.obs 2013)
range: This species is found in tidal streams and mangroves along the coast of Brazil (Moura and Sazima 2000) from Mucuri, Bahia to Florianopolis, Santa Catarina (Sazima and Carvalho-Filho 2003).
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Lupinoblennius paivai, but it is a widespread species that may occur in protected areas.

rationale: The Tonkin Numbfish (Narcine prodorsalis) is a small (to 40 cm total length) numbfish with a patchy distribution in the Indian, Western Central Pacific, and the Northwest Pacific Oceans ranging from India to China, including Sri Lanka, Java, Indonesia, and Viet Nam. It is demersal on the continental shelf down to a depth of 100 m. This species is bycatch in industrial and artisanal fisheries with multiple fishing gears including trawl, gillnet, and longline. It is mostly discarded due to its small size with and likely has a low post-release survival rate. Inferred and suspected declines over three generation lengths (14 years) based on landings of sharks and rays range from 22–82% and fishing pressure is high across much of its known range. The species is rarely recorded, and it is unknown if this is due to natural rarity, unrecorded captures, or as a result of fishing pressure causing population reductions. Dramatic declines have been documented in populations of similar species, where they are heavily fished. It is suspected that the Tonkin Numbfish has undergone a population reduction of 50–79% over the past three generation lengths (14 years) due to levels of exploitation, and it is assessed as Endangered A2d.
habitat: The Tonkin Numbfish is a small species that reaches at least 40 cm total length (TL) and occurs on the continental shelf to a depth of 100 m (Weigmann 2016). Reproduction is viviparous but nothing else is known of its biology. Age parameters are unknown but can be inferred from the only species of numbfish with age data. The Cortez Numbfish (Narcine entemedor) has a female age-at-maturity of 6 years and a maximum age of 15 years, resulting in a generation length of 10.5 years (Villavicencio-Garayzar 2000). The Cortez Numbfish is larger than the Tonkin Numbfish (93 cm vs 40 cm TL) and thus based on scaled-size, the generation length is inferred as 4.5 years for the Tonkin Numbfish.
threats:
This species is subject to fishing pressure across its range. It is taken as bycatch in industrial and artisanal fisheries with multiple fishing gears including trawl, gillnet, and longline, and mostly discarded. Post-release survival is likely low, as Narcine species are soft bodied and easily damaged (Carvalho et al. 2009).

In India, there are high levels of fisheries exploitation. There were about 6,600 trawlers operating in the Indian state of Gujarat in the early 2000s (Zynudheen et al. 2004). This number increased to 11,582 trawlers in 2010 (CMFRI 2010). Trawling is also intense elsewhere with 3,678 trawlers in Kerala and 5,767 trawlers in Tamil Nadu waters, with severe declines in fish stocks, including of elasmobranchs (Raje et al. 2002, Mohanraj et al. 2009, CMFRI 2010, Karnad et al. 2014). In Sri Lanka, fishing effort has been increasing since 1950 across subsistence, artisanal and industrial fisheries (Pauly et al. 2020). The number of vessels across all sectors has increased substantially from 14,000 vessels in 1950 to 63,745 vessels in 2014, with most of the increase since 2000 and >90% of the fleet subsistence and artisanal fisheries operating in coastal fisheries on the continental shelf (Pauly et al. 2020). The coastal fisheries are likely to be increasingly overfished due to the high fishing effort with offshore fisheries increasing in effort since the early 1980s (Samaraweera and Amarasiri 2004, Dissanayake 2005).

In Indonesia, small-scale fisheries comprise most (~90%) of fisheries production (Tull 2014). In some regions, effort by these small-scale fisheries has tripled when taking population growth into account (Ramenzoni 2017). Sharks and rays are an important resource in Indonesia and are the main livelihood for some communities (Sadili et al. 2015). Indonesia catches the highest number of chondrichthyans in the world with the catch of rays rising as shark fisheries collapse. In 2003, rays comprise over 50% of chondrichthyan landings, up from 32% in 1981 (White et al. 2006).

Most marine stocks in Viet Nam have been declining since the 1990s and are now considered fully or over-exploited with a lack of adequate enforcement leading to essentially unregulated fisheries (Teh et al. 2014, FAO 2020). The fleet is dominated by small-scale artisanal and subsistence fisheries that have accounted for 60–85% of the fleet since the 1950s (Teh et al. 2014, Pauly et al. 2020). The artisanal and subsistence motorized fleet has tripled from 1950 (~24,280 vessels) to 2014 (~ 78,000 vessels) but has also substantially increased in effort in terms of engine power, particularly over the last two decades (Pauly et al. 2020). Approximately 33% of the total marine captures in Viet Nam consists of ‘trash’ fish that are too small for human consumption but are still retained to produce fish meal feed for the aquaculture industry and also to manufacture fish sauce (FAO 2020). Illegal fishing by foreign vessels is an additional threat in Viet Nam waters (Teh et al. 2014, FAO 2020).

The South China Sea has been heavily over-exploited, with fish stocks having declined by over 70% in the inshore, offshore and outer shelf areas between the 1960s and 1990s (Wang and Yuan 2008). Since the 1990s in the South China Sea, more than 70% of the catch is of low-value fish and juvenile fish (Pauly and Liang 2019). Since the 1980s, demersal trawls are the dominant gear followed by purse seines and small-scale gear (Pauly and Liang 2019). In China, the number of powered fishing vessels increased from ~10,000 in the late 1960s to ~200,000 in the mid-1990s, along with an increase in vessel size and more modern fishing gear. Since 1989, the catch-per-unit effort of fish stocks has steadily decreased and large, highly valued species have been replaced by small, less valuable species, with most of the catch now used as feed in aquaculture (MacKinnon et al. 2012).
population:
There is no information on the population of this species, but it is apparently very patchy within its range and only very rarely recorded. It is unknown if this is due to natural rarity or as a result of fishing pressure causing population reductions. It is caught as bycatch in India (K.K. Bineesh unpubl. data 2020) and likely also in Sri Lanka where fishing pressure is heavy and intensifying (O’Meara et al. 2011, Pauly et al. 2020). Although the species is typically discarded, the numbfishes are thought to suffer from high post-release mortality. The population of the Tonkin Numbfish is suspected to have declined off India due to overall declines in batoids from intense and increasing fishing pressure. For example, the annual average catch of rays landed by trawlers at New Ferry Wharf, Mumbai, between 1990–2004 was 502 t. During this period trawler hours doubled, and consequently, the catch rate declined by 63% from 0.65 kg/hr in 1990 to 0.24 kg/hr in 2004 (Raje and Zacharia 2009).

Although landings data are not a direct measure of abundance, these can be used to infer population reduction where landings have decreased while fishing effort has remained stable or increased. While not a whipray, the Tonkin Numbfish is in a similar depth range and susceptible to the same fishing gears as whiprays, thus the catch trends of whiprays are suspected to be similar to that of numbfishes. Catch of whiprays increased throughout Indonesia starting in the 1960s. In central Indonesia, whipray catch increased by 550% throughout the early-1970s to 2000, from 30 tonnes to >200 tonnes per year (Zeller and Pauly 2016). Catch decreased 45% since the early 2000s (Zeller and Pauly 2016). Research surveys from 1976 to 1997 shows more than a 90% decline in ray catch per unit effort throughout the Java Sea in 20 years (Blaber et al. 2009). With the increased catch through parts of Indonesia there has also been increased effort and therefore, catch per unit effort (CPUE) is likely decreasing, suggesting an overall decrease in the population of chondrichthyans (White and Dharmadi 2007).

There is no species-specific catch data for this species from any part of its range. Catches of sharks, rays, and skates from 1950 to 2014 have been reconstructed for the Sri Lanka, Viet Nam, and China Exclusive Economic Zones (EEZ), based on landings data (Zeller and Pauly 2016, Pauly et al. 2020). Although landings data are not a direct measure of abundance, these can be used to infer population reduction where landings have decreased while fishing effort has remained stable or increased.

In Sri Lanka, reconstructed landings data showed a five-fold increase over the 65 years from 1950 to 2014. Total catches have fluctuated greatly but continued to rise overall with foreign catches within the Sri Lanka EEZ increasing from the mid-1980s (Pauly et al. 2020). A population trend cannot be inferred as effort has also increased during this period.

In Viet Nam, reconstructed landings data showed a 97% decline in landings over 29 years from 1986 to 2014. Catches gradually rose from 1,560 t in 1950 to ~44,000 t per year in the mid-1960s, fluctuated and then rose steeply during the early-1980s to a peak of 466,445 t in 1986 followed by a fairly steady decline to 14,750 t in 2014 (Pauly et al. 2020). These declines in landings can be inferred to represent reductions in their populations, as the fishing effort has increased substantially since the 1950s and was increasing during the period of a decline in landings (Pauly et al. 2020).

In China, the reconstructed landings showed a 67% decline in landings over the 65 years (Zeller and Pauly 2016). The decline was from around 90,000 t annually in the early 1950s to around 30,000 t in 2014. Across China, fishing effort has increased substantially since the 1950s and continues to increase, despite efforts by the Chinese government since the 1980s to restrict effort in response to depletion of inshore fisheries resources due to bottom trawling and stake nets (Pauly and Liang 2019). Additionally, in China, anecdotal reports suggest a decrease in the size of sharks and rays captured (J. Zhang unpubl. data 2019), which reflects the broader trend across all fish stocks of smaller sized fish being landed in China as a result of fishing down the ecosystem; a consequence of intensive fishing that changes the size composition of the catch (Pauly and Liang 2019).

When these inferred and suspected declines are scaled to three generation lengths of the Tonkin Numbfish (13.5 years), they represent declines of 63%, 65%, 82%, and 22% in India, Indonesia, Viet Nam, and China, respectively. These levels of decline are not species-specific but are informative for understanding the broader levels of decline in batoids in the region. Historic and current fishing pressure (‘actual levels of exploitation’) is high across most of the range of the Tonkin Numbfish. Dramatic declines have been documented in populations of similar species, where they are heavily fished. Overall, based on inferred declines across most of its range, it is suspected that the species has undergone a population reduction of 50–79% over the past three generation lengths (13.5 years).
range: The Tonkin Numbfish has a patchy distribution in the Indian, Western Central Pacific, and Northwest Pacific Oceans ranging from India to China, including Sri Lanka, Java, Indonesia, and Viet Nam (Last et al. 2016).
useTrade: Numbfishes are not consumed as human food and presumably discarded due to their small size (Last et al. 2016).
conservationActions:
No species-specific conservation measures are in place. In Indonesia in 1980, trawls were banned, however, large numbers of mini or baby trawls (Lampara) are still used throughout the country (Chong et al. 1987). In 2015, an additional ban on seine nets (Cantrang) was to be fully implemented in February 2020 (Ambari 2019). There are currently plans in place to lift both these bans in the near future, where the Ministry of Marine Affairs and Fisheries (MMAF) plan will allow the operation of the fishing gear with restrictions on the area of fishing pressure (Dharmadi unpubl. data 2020). Throughout Indonesia there are 196 MPAs making up 239,428 km2 that may provide some refuge to this species (CTI 2020). Most MPAs in the region are not well enforced and unlikely to provide any tangible relief from fishing pressure.

In China, since the late 1990s, regulations have specified varying annual seasonal fishing closures on commercial demersal trawling in the South China Seas to 12°N (Yu and Yu 2008). The closure times have varied over the years and between regions, but most now commence in May and are in place for 3–4 months. In 2018, this seasonal closure was widened to also include all other commercial fishing gears (e.g. gillnet and longline) with the only exception being for rod and reel to allow small-scale artisanal fisheries and recreational fisheries (J. Zhang unpubl. data 2019). Since 2017, enforcement of the seasonal closure has strengthened (X. Chen unpubl. data 2019). The effectiveness of the closures is debatable as overfishing remains a threat (Yu and Yu 2008, Pauly and Liang 2019). It is estimated that ~20% of the Chinese coastline is included in Protected Areas (MacKinnon et al. 2012).

Research is required to better define the population size and trends, and life history of the Tonkin Numbfish, and catch rates should be monitored.

To conserve the population and to permit recovery, a suite of measures will be required which may include species protection, spatial management, bycatch mitigation, and harvest measures. Effective enforcement of measures will require ongoing training and capacity-building (including in the area of species identification). Catch monitoring is needed to help understand population trends and inform management.

rationale:
Seret’s Butterfly Ray (Gymnura sereti) is a medium-sized (to at least 75 cm disc width) coastal ray distributed throughout the Western Central and Southeast Atlantic from Mauritania to Angola. It occurs on sandy and muddy habitats and also enters estuaries ranging from the surface to a depth of 60 m.

This species is captured in industrial and artisanal fisheries using demersal trawl, gillnets, and beach seine nets. It is retained and sold fresh, dried or smoked. There is no species-specific population trend data, although reconstructed catches of all sharks, skates and rays from the Senegal, Guinea-Bissau, Ghana, and Nigeria Exclusive Economic Zones infer declines 32–89 % over the past three generation lengths (21 years). These levels of decline are not species-specific but are informative for understanding the broader levels of decline in rays in the region and most of these steep declines have occurred in the past decade. West African fisheries are likely to be depleted and butterfly ray populations have declined dramatically in the region.

Overall, it is suspected that the Seret’s Butterfly Ray has undergone a population reduction of 50–79% over the last three generation lengths (21 years) due to actual and potential levels of fishing pressure, and hence it is assessed as Endangered A2d.
habitat: Seret’s Butterfly Ray occurs on sandy and muddy habitats and also enters estuaries ranging from the surface to a depth of 60 m (Yokota and Carvalho 2017, L. Yokota pers. comm. 14/06/2020). It is likely to reach a maximum size of approximately 100–110 cm disc width (DW), though the largest measured specimen was 74.8 cm DW (Yokota and Carvalho 2017); males mature at 33.8–45 cm DW and females mature at 66.5 cm DW (Yokota and Carvalho 2017). Reproduction is matrotrophic viviparous and size-at-birth is estimated at 18–22 cm DW (Yokota and Carvalho 2017). Generation length is inferred from the larger Spiny Butterfly Ray (Gymnura atavela), which is 11 years (see Spiny Butterfly Ray Red List assessment), and this was scaled down to 7 years to account for the smaller size of Seret’s Butterfly Ray.
threats:
The species is taken as bycatch, and possibly targeted, in industrial and small-scale fisheries with multiple gears, including trawl, gillnet, and beach seine net, and retained for its meat. In Eastern Central and Southeast Atlantic, elasmobranchs were first exploited by semi-industrial fisheries during the 1950s, although these fisheries gradually collapsed (Walker et al. 2005). Elasmobranchs were also caught as bycatch by small-scale fisheries and the flesh salted and dried for consumption. The total artisanal total fishing effort increased by 10-fold between 1950 and 2010 (Walker et al. 2005, Belhabib et al. 2018). Industrial fisheries have increased with demersal and shrimp trawlers dominating with more than 64% of the total number of industrial vessels increasing from 190 vessels in 1950 to 1,200 vessels in 2010 (Belhabib et al. 2018). The reported landings of elasmobranchs has risen steadily since the 1950s and the mid-1990s (Walker et al. 2005). Sharks and rays constitute 1–2% of all reconstructed catches, and a large fraction of the catch is reported in the Canary Current Large Marine Ecosystem with nearly one-quarter taken by Morocco and a significant fraction taken by Nigeria (D. Belhabib pers. comm. 25/08/2020). Elasmobranch meat is an important source of protein for many countries in Africa (Walker et al. 2005). A large market for salted and dried flesh is centralized in the Gambia and Mauritania region where a Ghanian community operates an export business to Ghana via Senegal. Guinea and Mali import important quantities of smoked elasmobranch flesh from the West Africa region. Overall, there has been a 34% decline in total catch-per-unit-effort (CPUE) between the 1950s and the 2000s, driven mainly by 60% decrease in the artisanal CPUE (Belhabib et al. 2018).

In Central Africa, fishing pressure on both sharks and rays is significant. For example, in Gabon, even if there is no fishery focused on sharks and rays, they are caught daily. For example, in 2018 sharks and rays catch represented 6.3% of the trawling total catch, with at least 3,900 individuals per fishing trip (6o tonnes of total catch for 28 days at sea and 115 trawling operations) (G. De Bruyne and E. Chartrain unpubl. data 2020).

Seret’s Butterfly Ray was recently described but it is assumed that general patterns for butterfly ray catches apply to it as well. Butterfly rays were formerly common all along the West African coast. Seret's Butterfly Ray may be targeted along with other benthic sharks and rays and caught in large mesh benthic gillnets targeting guitarfishes in West Africa. Butterfly rays are taken as bycatch of industrial bottom trawl and shrimp trawl gear and in artisanal fisheries using demersal-set gillnets and longlines (I. Seidu, G.H.L. Leurs and A.B. Williams unpubl. data 2020). In Ghana, they can comprise 1.5% of rays captured in demersal trawls. In the artisanal fishery, in Gabon, in 2018 Seret’s Butterfly Ray were caught by longlines in the delta of Ogouée with a CPUE of 41.2 kg/day per fishing boat, representing 15.9% of the catches (G. de Bruyne and E. Chartrain unpubl. data 2020). The pressure on Gymnuridae seems low, with less than 0.1% of rays observed but their catch is regular and it is the importance of both Dasyatidae and Rajidae catch that explain the apparent low catch rate and pressure upon Gymnuridae. However, without proper time-series of catch data for this species, we cannot exclude that this low rate of catches is due to a collapse of the population resulting from the higher fishing pressure in the past (G. de Bruyne and E. Chartrain unpubl. data 2020). These fisheries are not managed over a large portion of this species range and are intense and increasing in many areas. There is a long history of heavy fishing pressure throughout this species' inshore and shallow water habitat that is unlikely to be reduced in the coming years (M. Ducrocq unpubl. data 2007, 2020).
population:
There are no species-specific trend data for this species. In the Eastern Central and Southeast Atlantic, the greatest fishing effort and largest elasmobranch fisheries in the whole of Africa were the West African countries of Nigeria (13,238 t), Senegal (10,757 t) and Ghana (1,902 t) (Walker et al. 2005). Nevertheless, given the lack of reporting in artisanal fisheries and the large number of nations fishing in African waters, actual landings are likely to be much higher. Despite the lack of species-specific data, catches of sharks, rays, and skates have been reconstructed for the Senegal, Guinea-Bissau, Ghana, and Nigeria Exclusive Economic Zones, based on landings data (Pauly et al. 2020). Although landings data are not a direct measure of abundance, they can be used to infer population reduction where landings have decreased while fishing effort has remained stable or increased.

In Senegal, reconstructed landings showed a 30% decline, and maybe as much as an 80% decline, over 15 years from 2001 to 2016. Catches gradually rose from 3,644 t in 1950 to 20,180 t in 1972 then declined to 4,211 t in 1981, then rose steeply to a peak of 23,194 t in 2001 followed by a fluctuating decline to 4,734 t in 2016 (Pauly et al. 2020). These declines in landings can be inferred to represent reductions in their populations, as the fishing effort has increased substantially during the period of a decline in landings (Pauly et al. 2020). In Guinea-Bissau, reconstructed landings have been rising since the 1960s but showed a 22% decline over the years from 2012 to 2016. Historically, catches gradually rose 6-fold from 782 t in 1962 to 5,001 t in 1997 then steeply rose to a peak of 17,181 t in 2012 followed by a fluctuating decline to 13,485 t in 2016 (Pauly et al. 2020). These declines in landings can be inferred to represent reductions in their populations, as the fishing effort increased during the period of a decline in landings (Pauly et al. 2020). This recent steep decline in landings is associated with a 27% decrease in CPUE from 2012 to 2016.

In Ghana, reconstructed landings have been rising since the 2000s but showed a 27% decline over the years from 2013 to 2016. Historically, catches gradually rose from 154 t in 1950 to 15,536 t in 1975 then declined to 1,122 t in 1997, then rose steeply to a peak of 12,858 t in 2013 followed by a fluctuating decline to 9,422 t in 2016 (Pauly et al. 2020). Effort rose very steeply in 2002, but plateaued in 2010, and hence the recent decline in catch may represent signs of population collapse. In Nigeria, reconstructed landings have been rising since the 1970s but showed a 19% decline over the years from 2010 to 2016. Historically, catches quickly rose from 2,419 t in 1950 to 25,144 t in 1980 then rose to a peak of 31,273 t in 2010 followed by a fluctuating decline to 25,396 t in 2016 (Pauly et al. 2020). These declines in landings can be inferred to represent reductions in their populations, as the fishing effort has remained stable during the period of a decline in landings (Pauly et al. 2020). This steep increase landings coincides with a steep rise in fishing effort and an overall 50% reduction in CPUE  from 1980 to 2016.

Although large butterfly ray individuals are still landed sometimes from Mauritania and south to Guinea, artisanal fishers and other observers indicate that the abundance has dropped severely and that the median size has been dramatically reduced as most of the adults have been removed by fishing activities (M. Ducrocq unpubl. data 2007). Even in the Banc d'Arguin National Park, Mauritania, target captures occur and consist of more than 90% juveniles and subadults while large individuals were common in the 1980s (M. Ducrocq unpubl. data 2007). Pregnant Seret's Butterfly Ray females have been observed in the landings of artisanal coastal fisheries in Mauritania, Senegal, and Guinea-Bissau, suggesting that this species is giving birth in coastal shallow waters, where the fishing pressure is intense (M. Ducrocq unpubl. data 2007). Juvenile butterfly rays (up to 30 cm disc width) can still be seen very close inshore in Gabon (E. Chartrain unpubl. data 2020). This species is still commonly captured in Ghana (I. Seidu unpubl. data 2020), but rare in Congo and Cameroon (P. Doherty and A. Tamo unpubl. data 2020).

When the reconstructed landings declines are scaled to the conservative three generation lengths of the Seret’s Butterfly Ray (21 years) they represent population reductions of 89%, 72%, 89%, and 32% in Senegal, Guinea-Bissau, Ghana, and Nigeria, respectively. These levels of declines are not species-specific but are informative for understanding the broader levels of decline in rays in the region. West African fisheries are likely to be depleted and butterfly ray populations have declined dramatically and hence, it is suspected that a population reduction of more than 50–79% has occurred in the past three generation lengths (21 years).
range: Seret’s Butterfly Ray occurs throughout the Eastern Central and Southeast Atlantic from Mauritania to Angola (Yokota and Carvalho 2017, M. Dia unpubl. data 2020).
useTrade: The meat of butterfly rays is sold fresh for local consumption (e.g. Ghana and Nigeria) or dried and salted or smoked before being exported from Senegal and Mauritania to Ghana (A. Ba pers. comm. 28/08/ 2020).
conservationActions:
No species-specific management or protection is currently in place for this species. This species may have some refuge in two large protected areas.
